PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That Librarians and library users throughout the nation call for the exemption of books, periodicals and newspapers from the imposition of sales taxes.

The tax exempt status of libraries and schools will not protect them from general cost increases which sales tax and its collection will cause. Indeed, exemption claims on millions of items per year will themselves add to the cost burden of both libraries and suppliers.
This tax is socially injurious and unworkable, and a burden on education, science and culture.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will exempt books, periodicals including newspapers from the proposed sales tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child and Mr Les Johnson.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the Government's decision to impose a tax on books, magazines and newspapers particularly educational publications and books of a religious nature , is abhorrent to the notion of the right to information, a clear infringement of our democratic freedom, and that no such tax is levied on any other country with which Australia is usually compared.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw its announced intention to impose a sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling,Mr Hodgman and Mr Hurford.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed sales tax of 2.5 per cent on books, magazines and newspapers represents a tax on knowledge which should not be contemplated in a civilised country. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this proposed sales tax be withdrawn from the Budget proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hurford and Mr Macphee.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your Petitioners are gravely concerned by the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with educational books, clothing, footwear, newspapers, buildings and food wrappings, as these sales taxes impose a further burden on home builders, families and children; inhibit the free flow of information through books and newspapers; and reduce employment opportunities.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should exempt these items from the proposed Sales Tax legislation, as requested by the Senate.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ian Cameron and Mr Katter.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with home building, clothing, footwear, books and newspapers, wrapping for food.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament to exempt these items from the proposed Sales Tax as requested by the Senate to avoid such taxes on necessities of life becoming a further burden on home builders, families and children or inhibiting the free flow of information through books and newspapers or reducing employment opportunities for people in the industries concerned and beyond.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Government's Sales Tax legislation imposes an unreasonable burden on the community generally, especially pensioners, families, those in receipt of smaller incomes and small businesses.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron and Mr Humphreys.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :
That a person's pet is not a luxury item, particularly for pensioners, children , low income families, the physically and mentally ill:
That the Government's proposed 17.5 per cent sales tax on pet food will make it impossible for many people to continue to maintain and care for their pets.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will reconsider its budget decision to impose a 17.5 per cent sales tax on pet food.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:
1. The 17.5 per cent sales tax on pet foods places unreasonable financial strain on pensioners and other pet owners.
2. A pet is not a luxury item for many owners, it fills a vital part in their lives and, in many cases, is therapeutically beneficial, particularly for families and pensioners.

3. The added financial strain may cause many people to abandon or otherwise dispose of their pets, thus adding to the distress of already disadvantaged people and further overloading the resources of animal welfare societies.
4. In view of the abandonment of sales tax on veterinary drugs, it seems inconsistent to tax pet foods when food is as much a basic need as medicines.
We therefore request that this tax on pet food be immediately withdrawn.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Budget imposition of 2.5 per cent additional Sales Tax to both existing sales tax items and to previously exempt goods:
(a) will add to the regressivity of the tax structure by imposing a similar burden on all sections of the community-regardless of the capacity to pay tax;
(b) will be highly inflationary and a disincentive to economic performance in key sectors of manufacturing industry, e.g. car manufacturing, textile and footwear industries;
(c) is yet another breach of Government promise, given the Treasurer's undertaking in the Parliament on 12 March 1981, that there would be no increase in indirect taxes.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to repeal the Budget Amendments to Sales Tax Legislation which increases existing sales tax items from 19 August 1981 and to withdraw its Sales Tax Amendment Bills which add Sales Tax to presently exempt goods as from 1 January 1982.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Humphreys and Mr Willis.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Day
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the 26th January, 1788, is the date of first white settlement in Australia , and therefore marks the beginning of modern Australia,
and this event marks the most appropriate date on which to celebrate our national day.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will determine that Australia Day is to be celebrated on the twenty-sixth day of January each year, and that a public holiday will be declared on that day, regardless of which day of the week is the 26th.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Registration Fee for Periodicals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned, respectfully ask that the Australian Government request Australia Post to review the recently introduced annual registration fee for periodicals.

With many periodicals produced for distribution to members in small numbers only, this new impost, together with the recent increases in postage rates, considerably adds to the administrative costs of small clubs and organisers, whose activities are non profit, and are directly involved in community activities.
Accordingly, we earnestly request this review, with a view to smaller clubs and organisations, at least, being exempted from the requirements of annual registration.
We thank you in anticipation of your support.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Estate Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of effective Federal environmental protection legislation and urge that suitable legislation be enacted immediately.

Your petitioners are concerned that National Estate areas such as South West Tasmania, the Great Barrier Reef and the Western Australian Jarrah Forests cannot be fully protected until adequate legislation exists and is enforced. Your humble petitioners therefore call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that all provisions of the Heritage Act and the Environment (Impact of Proposals) Act are fully complied with in respect of National Estate Areas. In particular your petitioners call upon you to adopt the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment on South West Tasmania. Your petitioners believe that this is a national issue and must be resolved by the action of the Federal Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Toxic Shock Syndrome
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned by the threats to women's health and lives posed by Toxic Shock syndrome, and urge the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:

(1) Tampons, sanitary napkins, vaginal deodorants and similar sanitary products to be re-classified under Therapeutic Agents (not under 'Cosmetics' as at present), in order to bring them under the scrutiny of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. We believe manufacture must be under the strictest hygienic conditions.

(2) After re-classification, we urge an immediate government-funded inquiry into all aspects of manufacture and content of these products. This must lead to : (i) contents of product and instructions for correct usage to be shown on packaging; (ii) removal of synthetic fibres, chemicals or ingredients that are potentially or actually harmful to users.

(3) Allocation of extra funding for ongoing research by the National Health and Medical Research Council into these products, results of this research to be made public to ensure all health workers and potential users are fully informed. This campaign of public education would necessitate multilingual distribution of the information where appropriate.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert possible threats posed to women's health by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Ex-Servicemens' and Womens' Pension Association is a body formed for the express purpose of obtaining a Service Pension for all Ex-Service Personnel at Sixty years of age for Men and Fifty-five years of age for Women regardless of where they served during the 1939-45 war.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled should give urgent consideration to a favourable decision to the granting of the Service Pension to all Ex-Service Personnel who served their Country in time of need and who did not serve overseas through no fault of their own. The Service Pension is presently only granted to Returned Ex-Service Personnel.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That since 1788 discrimination has existed in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of sex, race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy and/or sexual preference;

That since 1788 such discrimination has been accepted and promoted by Australian laws and practices, particularly in the provision of work, in appointment to jobs, in promotion to positions of authority and lucrative incomes, in the provision of goods and services, in the provision of accommodation and generally in relation to political, economic and social institutions of power.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That adequate and appropriate laws be immediately formulated and passed through the Parliament to render unlawful discrimination in all areas over which the Commonwealth holds power, namely, in employment of all persons in the Commonwealth Public Service and employed in Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and other bodies, in the provision of Commonwealth accommodation and goods and services and also in all areas over which legislation for the Australian Capital Territory would be valid.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Child Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australian Parliament Assembled. Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament Assembled takes action as it deems appropriate:
a. to ensure that funding in the area of child care will not be cut or reduced.

b. to ensure that the Children's Service Programme Manual interpretation of the Child Care Act 1972-1973 be altered to allow part time occasional care centres to be funded as it seems possible under the Act Section 4(1) a.
c. to ensure that funds are allocated to half day occasional care centres which are meeting the needs of mothers who stay at home to care for their children.
Your petitioners, therefore humbly request that Parliament Assembled take immediate and positive action on the above mentioned issues.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed changes to assistance to the Passenger Motor Vehicle and Components Industries after 1984 shall lead to the collapse of the vehicle manufacturing industry in Australia. Your petitioners therefore pray that the industries assistance commission report be not given effect.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting Licences
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Represesentatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :
That Family Radio Ltd represents the largest single interest group in the community-i.e. Christians-who do not have a voice in public broadcasting commensurate with their representation.
That prime time access to existing broadcasts by Christian groups is virtually non-existent, and access at other times is fast disappearing.
That, by comparison with other capitals, Brisbane is entitled to at least one more category 'S' FM broadcasting licence.
That there appears to be no prospect of the release of further category 'S' FM licences in the near future for Brisbane.
That satisfactory fulfillment of the aims of Family Radio and its expansion can only be achieved by broadcasting in its own right under licence.

That Family Radio has a responsibility to the large support groups which have contributed substantially to its development, to achieve the aims in broadcasting and community work for which it was established.

That there is an urgent need for the kind of service and support that Family Radio can provide to other community groups through the particular type of integrated programming proposed by the company under the full-time licence.
And that pruned Government resources are obviously insufficient to advance the development of public broadcasting as originally intended.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will support Family Radio's application for a broadcasting licence and will enable more category 'S' FM licences to be made available in Brisbane.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantage in employment, education, accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment;
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Non-interest Bearing Accounts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That any proposal by the Government to threaten pensioners' entitlements to fringe benefits by establishing a ceiling on the allowable amount of savings in non-interest bearing accounts is completely unfair and does not take account of the natural need of all pensioners to maintain some savings for occasional expenses such as house maintenance.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government will not proceed with any such proposal, and should instead direct its attention to those pensioners who enjoy extremely high levels of extra income yet manage to remain within pension eligibility guidelines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Planning Association
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia/N.S.W. respectfully showeth that many thousands of women in Wagga and district who have access to the services of the Women's Health and Support Centre and the N.S.W. Family Planning Association:

1. Express their concern that Family Planning Services in country areas of N.S. W. have been abolished due to the reduction of funding to the Family Planning Association by the Federal Government. They also express their concern at the decision of the Federal Government to pass to the states, the responsibility of funding the essential services of Women's Health Centres, Women's Refuges and Rape Crisis Centres.
2. Call on the Federal Government to reverse these decisions;
3. Request that the Government ensure that there is one department which will administer all funds for the above under the heading of Women's Services;
4. Propose that future funding should be on a guaranteed triennial basis which must take into account the needs of country areas;
5. Request definite government policy commitment to a substantial injection of funds to consolidate existing services and develop new ones including country N. S.W.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australia in Parliament as assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia who respectfully showeth their anger and condemnation at the unrealistic low priority given to children's vacation programmes and other children's services which has resulted in the withdrawal of funds from programmes which provide an essential community service.
We protest at the disastrous effects this will have on parents and children.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government provide public funding for all children's services including vacation programmes to ensure quality services are available for all children and parents who require it.
Further that funds be immediately released to prevent closure of vacation programmes for the 1981-82 financial year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Theatre in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned by proposed reduction in funds to Theatre in Australia. This will result in the reduction of the theatre's contribution to the quality of civilised life, refinement and projection of national identity, and its contribution to tourism; and the reduction of employment opportunities in the arts.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
Support Theatre in Australia by increasing grants to a realistic level.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef: Oil Exploration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of the Commonwealth submits:
That off shore oil exploration within the Great Barrier Reef Region constitutes a serious threat to the richest and most varied living system on earth.
Your petitioners request that your Honourable House will:
1. Declare the whole Great Barrier Reef Region a Marine Park under the Federal Government's Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975,
2. Prohibit oil exploration within the Great Barrier Reef Region (as defined by the 1975 Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act).
3. Retain full Federal Government control over the whole Great Barrier Reef Region,
4. Provide the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority with staff and resources sufficient for effective management of the region.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Marie-France Claude
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Marie-France Claude is the Vice-President of the Christian Democrat Party of Haiti. The party is opposed to the government of President-for-Life Jean-Claude Duvalier, but it does not use or advocate violence. Because of her activities in the Christian Democrat Party, Marie-France Claude has been sentenced to fifteen years imprisonment with hard labour.
A number of other members of this opposition party have been sentenced to similar terms of imprisonment.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government pass on to the Haitian Government the concern of the undersigned citizens, and their wish that Marie-France Claude be released from prison.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aspect House for Handicapped Children
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. All children in Tasmania are not treated equally.
2. Persons with intellectual, physical and multiple handicaps in particular will be denied access to Aspect House, 6 Warragul Avenue, New Town in Tasmania if the house is closed.
3. Aspect House is faced with imminent closure because of lack of Government policy and on-going funding.

4. Aspect House is the only community-based facility in an ordinary house in an ordinary suburban setting which provides relief to parents and families engaged in the onerous and demanding task of rearing their handicapped children in the community.
5. That the rights of all children to live with their families should be respected.
6. That we seek Government to take immediate action to prevent the closure of this unique facility.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Use of Live Animals in Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.
2. That no central records exist on such inhumane use of live animals for experimentation purposes, yet research institutions in several Australian States engage in such a practice.
3. That there exists no uniform legislation between the States concerning responsible standards of research conduct, indeed, in some States there is a complete lack of legislation altogether.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will enact legislation to require:
(a) the Australian Bureau of Statistics to produce annual statistics on the numbers of live animals involved in research, and provide information as to research purpose; and

(b) the National Health and Medical Research Council to develop humane and responsible standards of conduct for researchers using live animals in all Government, industry and educational research laboratories.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhuman use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of cosmetic companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
Legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology and environment of the Island.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the Register of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Hertiage Commission Act 1975 take into consideration the protection of the island.

3. That the Queensland Government has given approval to the sand mining of Moreton Island despite the advice of conservationists and despite the opposition of the majority of electors in the Moreton Region.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will request the Government to refuse export permits covering mineral sands mined on Moreton Island.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Roads Construction Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners believe that:
The decision to subject the National Roads Construction program to the tendering system will:
(a) threaten the jobs of 790 workers employed in 17 main roads depots in N.S.W.
(b) impair the day labour system and undermine the capacity of Department of Main Roads to train staff and test road construction concepts.
(c) have a disruptive effect on the employment opprtunities available in small communities.
(d) reduce the flexibility of the Department of Main Roads to handle emergencies caused by flood and fire.
(e) ultimately increase the cost of road construction at taxpayers' expense.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government withdraw this disruptive proposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. there is a lack of public information about the content and intention of the proposed legislation on plant variety rights;
2. there is concern that the ethical and moral issues of granting private proprietorial rights over genetic resources have not been properly and publicly considered;
3. there is evidence to suggest that such legislation may lead to a reduction in the existing plant diversity;
4. there is reason to fear that farmers may be restricted in their activities due to the controls placed on the use and propagation of seed and stocks;
5. evidence suggests that plant variety rights legislation will lead to higher costs for the farmer, the consumer, the plant-breeder and the taxpayer, and
6. evidence suggests that plant variety rights legislation will lead to a further increase in foreign control of Australian resources.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament defer introducing the legislation until full and informed public discussion of the issues involved has taken place.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of Disabled
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The failure of the Federal Government to seek information from the census re disabled people-i.e. partial or total disability-to enable for adequate planning of, and for, types of services needed by disabled people to be undertaken.

2. The failure of the Federal Government to lead the way in employment of disabled people by employing a greater number of such people within the Commonwealth Public Service-note the small number currently employed within the Service.

3. The wastage of the Federal Government funds perpetuating large, bureaucratic institutions and organisations where there are often few disabled people on their boards and little emphasis is placed on consumer participation in decision making.
4. The failure of the Federal Government to encourage independence of disabled people, or to develop ''normalised'' support systems-attendant care.
5. The failure of the Federal Government to provide ''non-institutionalised'' specialised accommodation for those people who would not be able to benefit from , or cope with attendant care.
6. Failure by the Federal Government to alter, or create a 'disability' allowance means test free for all disabled people-this would assist with necessary equipment and mobility costs.
7. Failure to provide a national compensation scheme thus saving time and enabling people to be automatically covered in the event of a disability.
8. Failure by the Federal Government to abolish tariffs on all equipment available to the disabled-e.g. Optacon.
9. Mismanagement of Federal I.Y.D.P. Funds-e.g. non-receipt by some States of funds through unresolved negotiations.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that immediate action be taken to remedy the above stated and that the Federal Government recognise that disabled people are citizens who should have equal rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives as in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are aware that the proposed sales tax is only one aspect of a Budget needed to support the growth and development of our country.
And that every Australian, whether rich or poor must aid this aim.
But that the social conscience of a country must be judged by the way in which it responds to the needs of its poorest, most helpless citizens.
And that this latest imposition will be responsible for Australia being judged not only by its own people but by the rest of the world.
We, the citizens of Queensland most humbly pray that:

In the cause of justice and equity, your honourable members will reject any attempt to impose a sales tax on all essential goods including packaging of foods, shoes, clothing, literature and building materials.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ian Cameron,Mr Jull and Mr Moore.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Commission: Melbourne Showband
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that:
As regular viewers and listeners of the ABC Melbourne Showband we were disappointed to learn of the dismissal of seventeen members of this outstanding orchestra.

We have had a great deal of pleasure over the past eight years viewing and listening to this band's fine music. It is the only full-time light orchestra in Australia and we are disgusted to think that such talented musicians should be dismissed in this manner.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to rescind this decision and make more money available for the continuance of the full Showband.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representativess in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned members of the electorate of Hughes respectfully shows our concern regarding the proposed introduction of fees for post-graduate researchers in universities and colleges of advanced education, since it appears likely that this action will have a serious and detrimental effect on cultural, scientific and technical research and development within the Australian community.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Government will change the decision to introduce tuition fees for post-graduate study.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister Mr Anthony M.P. and the Minister for Primary Industry Mr Nixon M.P.

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75% and that at 1-10-81 the amount of principal outstanding was $15,005.

(2) That in 1970 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Nixon M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $30,352 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 6.25% and that at the 1-10-81 the amount of principal outstanding was $28, 404.

(3) Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government immediately extend these most generous terms to the many thousands of young couples in South Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives, Federal Parliament, Canberra.
The humble petition of the undersigned residents of Hindmarsh Division, State of South Australia.

Petition that competition between banks and finance companies by giving ever increasing rates to obtain the investors' capital, is against the nation's best interest. It penetrates every form of activity by constant demands for higher wages to meet these explosive conditions.

It is an intolerable burden to the younger generation of family life, that by necessity are the recipients of these excessive interest rates that are catastrophic to house purchase and natural living. We therefore respectfully petition for an urgent annual realistic controlled reduction right ''across the board'' on all existing and future interest rate agreements. With a maximum interest percentage ceiling on investors' capital, and a scale of interest charges for loans as appropriate.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will give effect to our submissions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Prime Minister. I refer to the staggering and continuing collapse of the Australian share market in the face of the Government 's fierce credit squeeze and particularly to the financial calamity this is causing for small investors, such as the lump sum superannuated. Is the Prime Minister aware that, for example, a lump sum superannuation settlement of $100, 000 invested in blue chip portfolios the day after the 1980 election is now worth less than $60,000 in real terms and is still falling? Is he aware that the rate of return on investment is only 5 per cent per annum, less than half the rate of inflation? In the name of decency and compassion--

—I share the scepticism of honourable members opposite, and they know him better than I do. In the name of decency and compassion, will the Prime Minister acknowledge the disaster this sort of experience is proving for tens of thousands of small investors, especially the retired who are now increasingly confronted by the spectre of poverty, and therefore will he reverse the vicious and unwise monetary policies of his Government?

—The developments on the Australian share markets in recent weeks mirror very significantly what has happened to share markets in other parts of the world. Inevitably different people will have different views as to why movements of this kind should occur in our share markets and also share markets in other parts of the world. I believe that in significant measure they are a reflection of expectations regarding interest rates around the world. It is a phenomenon that when expectations regarding interest rates worsen they do have consequences on share markets. I think that underlines the necessity for governments to follow policies which take as much pressure as possible off interest rates and that means not expanding Budget deficits or taking other measures which will only increase pressures further on interest rates.

—Will the Minister for Housing and Construction confirm or deny reports that the Government has shelved its plans to revamp the Homes Savings Grant Scheme and introduce supplementary forms of assistance to first home buyers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure the honourable member and the House that the Government has not shelved its plans to revamp its housing policies. I was disappointed to note recent statements in the Press that all plans had been shelved. Quite obviously, in this case the information that fell from the back of a truck was a decoy. It is a highly complex issue. The Government is not prepared to make ad hoc policies, as was the practice of the Opposition when it was in government. We are making our decisions in line with an examination of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and, of course, it is necessary to look at any assistance in the overall budgetary context.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer, in answer to a question earlier this week, indicated that the Government's response to assistance can depend only on the overall budgetary context. Recent actions in the Senate have not made it easier to give assistance to home buyers. Additionally, I remind honourable members that not every house owner or aspiring house owner in Australia has problems. Let us look at the situation. We have the highest home ownership rate in the world-71. 9 per cent. That is up from--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is going down. You cannot count because you do not have enough toes.
—The Leader of the Opposition will remain silent.

—Stop trying to be a lion when you are nothing but a house-trained pussy-cat. We have a home ownership rate of 71.9 per cent. The figures show that 38.3 per cent of house occupants own their homes outright and 33.6 per cent are in the process of purchasing their homes. Incidentally 43 per cent of home owners purchased their homes before 1970 and 63 per cent before 1975. Quite obviously their problem is not as pressing as the problem of people who purchased their homes since.
—I ask the Minister to draw his answer to a conclusion.

—There is a continuing examination. We are proud of our rate of home ownership. It has been maintained by a succession of Liberal-National Country Party governments and our statistics, compared with those for the rest of the world, are very, very good. Australia's home ownership rate is 71.9 per cent; West Germany's is 33 per cent; in France it is 47 per cent; in Great Britain it is 50 per cent; in Canada it is 63 per cent and in the United States it is 65 per cent. Our record is good and we are proud of it.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. No doubt he is aware of the disastrous bushfires that have occurred in Tasmania. What aid has already been given and what does the Government intend to do about future aid? Is the Premier of Tasmania visiting the Prime Minister today for talks on this subject? What will the Prime Minister be telling the Premier?

—Over the last two or three days there has been a very serious situation in Tasmania which has been relieved to some extent yesterday and this morning, I understand, by more favourable weather conditions. The possibility of a very serious situation is likely to remain for some time. As soon as we heard of the difficulties I assured the Premier that the Commonwealth would stand ready to do whatever it could to assist. The night before last 150 troops were flown to Tasmania to relieve fire fighters who had been at it for a long while. I think they flew down overnight and were at the fire very early in the morning. That was a very prompt response by the Minister for Defence to that request. The honourable member for Denison was down there to see for himself the concerns that people had and he has spoken to me about that. This is a very serious matter and the honourable member is right to ask what the Commonwealth is doing and can do to assist. The Premier is coming to see me this afternoon, not just about this matter. I have not talked to him since he became Premier and I understand that he wants to discuss one or two matters before the Premiers Conference tomorrow. I had a very useful and productive discussion with the Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania yesterday.

—Has the Prime Minister noted that his Minister for Housing and Construction appears indifferent to the result of an Australian Bureau of Statistics survey which has revealed that the level of home ownership in Australia has fallen from 73.8 per cent in 1978 to 71.9 per cent in 1980? As this serious trend is continuing, I ask the Prime Minister whether his Government has any plans to redress this extremely serious situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of changed conditions there are two main problems in the housing area. One is obviously the quantity of funds available for lending for building purposes. This has arisen because of the changed structure of interest rates. It is a matter that is obviously very serious. In addition to that there is the problem of price. That can be influenced not only by the interest rate that has to be charged but also by the capital cost of the land or of the land and the house. The Government is examining both of these matters against the background of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. It ought to be understood that we in these parties have an overriding concern to make sure that access to home ownership in Australia remains as a high national priority, capable of being achieved by average Australians. We are conducting our discussions against that background.

ANSWER.PARA: I add only that it is not just the policies of the Commonwealth that are important in relation to these matters but also the policies of the State governments. In Victoria it would take about three years of average earnings to buy a decent, average house. In New South Wales it would take about 4 1/2 years of average earnings to buy a house in the Sydney area. The Commonwealth policies are the same in relation to each so the difference is obviously the Wran Labor policies which are making it enormously difficult and costly for people in the Sydney area to buy their homes. The honourable gentleman knows also that Victoria has the highest household income of any State; it has the highest rate of home ownership of any State. What the honourable gentleman has just suggested is a nonsense. Victoria also has the highest savings bank savings of any State. On these grounds the Wran Labor Government needs to look very much to its record and what it has done to the people of New South Wales. If the honourable gentleman is capable of working out the differences in the weekly payment charges on average families in New South Wales compared with Victoria he will find that the increased capital value of a house and land in Sydney is adding enormously to the repayment problems of Australians in the Sydney metropolitan area. Mr Wran has got to take responsibility for that and I hope that he is addressing himself to the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to comments made by the Victorian Minister of Housing that the Federal Government did not deserve to stay in power if it did not increase funds for housing. Is the Prime Minister aware that Commonwealth advances to the States for public housing have fallen by 80 per cent in real terms since 1975-76? Is he aware that the Victorian Government has cut its own contribution by $9.40 per head over the 1978 and 1979 financial years? If this grave deficiency in housing finance in Victoria is the fault of the Federal Government, will he undertake an immediate special allocation of funds to that State for the urgent provision of more housing? If the deficiency is the fault of the Victorian Government, will he act promptly to require it to fund housing construction in that State more responsibly?
—My communications with the Victorian Government on housing matters are with the Premier, not with Mr Kennett.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the Government's firm support of measures by President Reagan and the Western alliance in condemning the imposition of martial law in Poland. Does the Prime Minister agree that there is a need for humanitarian assistance for the long suffering people of Poland? If so, is the Australian Government's attitude in conflict with this need?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has in place significant measures in condemnation of martial law in Poland. These complement measures that the United States has taken and indeed measures that other Western allies have taken. Also, there is no doubt about the complicity of the Soviet Union in events in Poland. It certainly had prior knowledge of the imposition of martial law and has been standing behind the regime very significantly in support of it. There is no credible sign yet that General Jaruzelski is prepared to allow an end to martial law or to release political detainees. The restrictions and the repressions that are obvious in Poland continue. There has been no resumption of the process of political dialogue which had been taking place before as a result of discussions between Solidarity and the earlier Government.

ANSWER.PARA: While we condemn what has happened in Poland very strongly we are, at the same time, very concerned also about the hardship for many Polish families and the very real difficulties which would be hard for most people in Australia to envisage but which are part of daily life in Poland. If any honourable members have had discussions with people who have visited Poland recently they will have learnt of and will understand the very great human suffering that is present daily in Poland. That is why many people have sought to encourage humanitarian aid. That is flowing through. It is being managed and organised very significantly by the Catholic Church. On the advice available to us it is being delivered to the really needy people in Poland. The Government earlier made a donation of $1m to the fund for the support of Poland. There have been significant contributions from people around Australia to that appeal. The matter is a very serious one. As a result, the Government has made a decision that donations to the fund during the course of this financial year should be tax deductible. It would remain, obviously, within our capacity to review that particular matter at the end of the financial year, if there were a continuing need for further encouragement of donations from Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Treasurer, follows the question that I asked of the Prime Minister a few minutes ago and which he helped the Prime Minister by answering. He will recall that I pointed out that the collapse in the Australian stock exchange as a result of the Government's fierce credit squeeze had, for instance, reduced a $100,000 investment from a lump sum superannuation settlement to a real worth of less than $60,000 in the period from October 1980 to this month. He will also recall that he claimed that the experience here was comparable to that of other advanced countries of the world. Is he aware, in fact, that the experience in Australia is far in excess of the experience of the stock exchanges of the industrialised capitals of the world? Is he aware that, for the period stated, the nominal fall in the Australian stock exchange index exceeded 30 per cent, that in the United States of America it was only 4 per cent, in Germany 3 per cent and that, in fact, in the United Kingdom there was an increase of 16 per cent and in Japan an increase of 25 per cent? In view of this, I ask the Treasurer: Will he address himself to the heart of the question that I put to the Prime Minister, namely, will the Government withdraw from the vicious credit squeeze it is now imposing on the Australian community, which is destroying the value of equity investments on the Australian stock exchange for tens of thousands of small investors and especially for the retired who are now increasingly confronted by the spectre of poverty?

—In response to the earlier question from the Leader of the Opposition I made two points. First, I rejected his claim that the Government's monetary policies represent a vicious credit squeeze. That is a total misreading of the present situation. As a corollary to that point, I also made the observation that any change in policy which exacerbated interest rate pressures would further compound the difficulties to which the honourable gentleman's question was addressed. There is no doubt that world stock markets have gone through difficult times in recent months. The honourable gentleman has produced some statistical comparisons. I will analyse those comparisons and then provide any further response I can. Quite obviously, the validity of the proposition of the Leader of the Opposition regarding those statistical comparisons depends upon the relative buoyancy or otherwise of Australian stock markets in earlier months and upon the commencement date of the comparisons. I certainly do not intend to be drawn into giving a flat yes or no answer on the basis of the Leader of the Opposition's self-chosen statistical comparisons.
—I ask the Prime Minister: Will the Commonwealth Government continue its full support for the two joint royal commissions being conducted in Victoria ?

—I can assure the honourable gentleman, and indeed all Victorians, that the Government will give its fullest support to those two royal commissions. We regard the maintenance of that support as very important indeed. The two reports, when they are available, will be highly significant and very important ones. I think it needs to be understood that, in relation to one report-that concerning the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union-you have a history of violence, of gun fights, of ballot rigging, of criminal offences and of fraud in obtaining pay cheques. Obviously, there is a history surrounding that particular union which is vastly disturbing. In relation to the Builders Labourers Federation, it has been condemned even by elements of the union movement. We all know of the bans on Loy Yang, the picketing of the Omega navigation facility and the reports of what happens in parts of the building industry in the city of Melbourne which had, in fact, been strangled by the activities of the Builders Labourers Federation.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order.
—Here is the agent for the unions in this Parliament.
—The honourable member for Melbourne Ports, a point of order.

—I take a point of order. I do not want to restrict what the Prime Minister says but, as I understand it, both these matters are subjects of inquiry by a royal commission and I would have thought, having regard to the way in which you, Mr Speaker, have enforced the sub judice rule, that you would draw to the attention of the Prime Minister the operation of that rule. It is uniformly bad practice, having regard to past practices of this House, for the Prime Minister to be making the kind of gratuitous comments about unions which are currently the subject of what are in fact judicial inquiries.

—I uphold the point of order. I indicate to the right honourable gentleman that it has been the practice of parliaments and of myself to observe the rule that statements in the Parliament ought not to prejudice the outcome of an inquiry in train. That does not necessarily mean that no comment can be made, but the comment ought not to deal with anything that is currently before a commission.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I just wanted to emphasise that the support of this Government for the two royal commissions remains very strong. It needs to be understood that the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria, Mr Cain, has described the two royal commissions as political stunts. He has made it virtually clear that, no matter what recommendations came out of the royal commissions, he would be doing his best to see that the recommendations of the commissions were not implemented.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Hawke

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie.

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members- That is a lie. Lies, lies, lies.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a liar. He did not say anything of the sort and you know he didn't. Why don't you tell the truth for once, you liar?
—He is a liar.

—The honourable member for Ballarat will remain silent. The House will come to order. The Prime Minister used words which obviously brought a response from the Opposition benches. I will not, no matter how much-
—He has never told the truth in his life.

—I warn the honourable member for Ballarat. The fact is that the parliamentary tradition is that, despite a disagreement with what has been said, there is no entitlement for any member to call another a liar. I will not permit that. Therefore, while the statement was made by many honourable members, that which I heard most clearly was from the honourable member for Wills. I ask the honourable member for Wills to withdraw.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Hawke

TALK.START.PARA: —I find myself unable to, Mr Speaker.

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members-Hear, hear! He is a liar.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister is a liar.
—The honourable member for Corio will remain silent.
—Make Fraser withdraw and act like a man.
—The honourable member for Corio will remain silent.
—I repeat that this is the Parliament of the nation. There are rules to be observed.

—One of the rules that is well established in this House is that no honourable member is entitled to call another a liar. It is by such statements that the Parliament falls into disrepute. I ask the honourable member for Wills to withdraw.
—If it is a question of the repute of this Parliament, the repute of this Parliament is brought into question and it is reduced to a shambles when lies are told--
—The honourable gentleman will withdraw or will not withdraw.
—If the Prime Minister will withdraw his lie, I will withdraw my comment. I cannot, in conscience, withdraw my comment.
—I finally call upon the honourable member for Wills to withdraw or I shall be forced to name him.
—Unfortunately, Mr Speaker, in the circumstances, I cannot.
—Mr Speaker--
—I name the honourable member for Wills.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Hayden

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker--

INTERJECT.PARA: That the honourable member for Wills be suspended from the service of the House .

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker--
—Mr Speaker, can I have your attention?
—The honourable member for Fremantle will remain silent. The honourable member for McMillan also will remain silent. The Leader of the Opposition is asking for my indulgence.

—Mr Speaker, I think there is a way of resolving this problem, and the honourable member for Wills did put it. If the Prime Minister withdraws his comment, the honourable member for Wills will withdraw his statement. Let me put this point to you, Mr Speaker, calmly. It is quite obvious that the statement of the Prime Minister was exceedingly inflammatory. It is also obvious, I think you will know from your experience, from the reaction from this side of the House it is a potentially explosive situation that the Prime Minister has developed. It will not reflect on the credit of anyone if it keeps going in the way in which it is. The Prime Minister must accept the whole responsibility for deliberately and dishonestly--
—Order! The Leader of the Oposition will resume his seat.
—Misquoting the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria.

—Order! The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. The fact is this: Despite the strongest disagreement with anything which is said by any member there is no entitlement to call that member a liar. There were many calls and the one that I heard most clearly was from the honourable member for Wills. I asked the honourable gentleman to withdraw. He has failed to do so.
—Mr Speaker--
—A motion has been proposed. I put the question that the honourable member for Wills be suspended from the services of the House.
—Mr Speaker, maybe I can clarify the matter.
—I would hope so.
—I will give the right honourable gentleman indulgence to speak.
—Mr Speaker--
—Oh! You! You!
—The honourable member for Fremantle will remain silent.

—I can understand the sensitivity of the Opposition, Mr Speaker. Mr Cain called these royal commissions political stunts and said: 'I am not going to see the resources of this State used for political stunts'. The implication--
—That is not what he said.
—Get him to repeat the line.
—Order! Honourable gentlemen will remain silent.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker.
—He is compounding it, Mr Speaker.
—Honourable gentlemen will remain silent-and also the honourable member for Henty.
—But, Mr Speaker, I want to--
—The honourable lady will resume her seat. It is my wish that the Parliament conduct itself in appropriate terms.

—It is not my wish to name the honourable member for Wills. I think the honourable member for Wills ought to withdraw his statement; then we can deal with the matter of substance. I give the honourable member for Wills another opportunity to withdraw.
—If I can finish what I was saying, it might help.
—I call the Prime Minister.
—The quotation from Mr Cain, as I have indicated, is: 'I am not going to--
—Read the whole part; stop being selective. You are telling lies.
—The honourable member for Holt will remain silent.

—The quotation from Mr Cain is this: 'I am not going to see the resources of this State used for political stunts'. There is a very clear implication from that that he is not going to have any part of those royal commissions. The only conclusion that can be made from that remark is a legitimate conclusion, and that is the conclusion that I drew.
—I raise a point of order.
—I will not listen to the point of order for the moment.
—The honourable member for Batman will remain silent. Really, the conduct of the House this morning is not good enough.
—The honourable members for Batman and Maribyrnong will remain silent . The issue here is an allegation that the Prime Minister lied.

—That is an allegation. But there is a way in which it can be put to the test, and that is not by continual interjections of the kind that have occurred. I remind honourable members-I have reflected on this matter-that the honourable member for Wills has not had long service in the House. Regardless of that, the honourable member for Wills knows well that there is a means of pursuing this allegation within the Standing Orders, not by way of continual interjections.

—Mr Speaker, in the interests of your own position: You have singled out the honourable member for Wills when at least 30 others said the same thing. You will lose this Parliament today because every member will be named. The simple solution is for the Prime Minister to withdraw his statement, which was a false accusation against the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria. He has made two attempts to get around it. In the interests of your own position , would you ask him to withdraw that statement? There would then be no trouble with this side.

—Mr Speaker, further to the point, could I just read to you what the Press has said about this question? Mr Cain, who is a very influential person in politics in this country has been interviewed about this matter. Let me quote--
—Order! Honourable gentlemen on my right are not helping by being noisy. I ask them to remain silent.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Young

TALK.START.PARA: —A newspaper article states:

INTERJECT.PARA: But he denied claims that Labor would ignore the commission findings or that it would automatically withdraw from the two inquiries if their reports came after the poll.
What the Prime Minister told this House is in fact a lie, Mr Speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would ask the honourable member for Wills to withdraw. Then I can deal with the other point.
—Mr Speaker, could I have your indulgence?
—Yes, the honourable gentleman may.

—I make my position quite clear. Everyone in this House knows where the fault is. If the Prime Minister withdraws his statement, which I will not again describe as it should accurately be described and which every member of this House knows its character to be, I will gladly withdraw.

—The position in which I have been placed was accurately stated by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. I regret very greatly that I am faced with a situation where there would be a very considerable dislocation of the Parliament and the proceedings could not go on. I indicate to the Leader of the House that, although I have named the honourable member for Wills and the motion has been moved, I have not proceeded to put the motion in the hope that there could be in all sincerity an attempt to make the Parliament a workable place. I have not put that motion in order to see whether there can be a reconciliation. I indicate to the Prime Minister that clearly a statement made by him-and I am not to judge the accuracy or inaccuracy of it-has produced a situation whereby, if it is persisted with, there will be a persistence in the response from the Opposition side, so that if we have a stalemate-a continuance of the allegation and a continuance of the response-the Parliament unfortunately will not be workable today. I ask the right honourable gentleman whether he would consider a conciliatory statement.
—Mr Speaker, if somebody calls two royal commissions a political stunt and if he says that he is not going to see the resources of this State--

—Order! I ask honourable members on my left to remain silent so that I can hear what the right honourable gentleman is saying. I ask honourable members on the Opposition benches to remain silent so that the matter can be proceeded with in calmness.

—Mr Speaker, if somebody calls two royal commissions of this kind a political stunt and if that person says that he is not going to see the resources of this State used for political stunts, what conclusions can be drawn ? The only conclusion that can be drawn is that he is going to have no part of these royal commissions because that is the definitive statement. Under pressure he quite plainly tried to hedge the situation--
—Order! It is not possible for me to hear what the right honourable gentleman is saying while the noise continues.

—Mr Speaker, the Opposition quite clearly knows how damaging this is in Victoria for Mr Cain. There have been editorials about it in the Victorian newspapers. Let me say again: If he says that he is not going to use the resources for political stunts, having named the royal commissions as political stunts, there is only one conclusion that can be drawn and that is that he is not going to do anything about those royal commissions. That is my conclusion from those remarks.
—I call the Leader of the Opposition.

—Mr Speaker, this is a deplorable situation which has been created for this Parliament and a quite intolerable one for you. I sympathise with you. That , I think, you should understand is an expression of the general feeling of the Opposition. This situation has not been created by you but by the comments of the Prime Minister and we are placed in the incredible position where the honourable member for Wills is expected-the parliamentary forms have it that he should withdraw but in fact the implication of it is apologise-to apologise for the offence of the Prime Minister. No self-respecting person is going to accept that. Within that transcript which the Prime Minister has obviously read it is declared that under Mr Cain a Labor government would not ignore the findings of a royal commission, that it would consider those findings even after the election and that it would accept that the inquiries continue after the election if they are still in train. This is a despicable misrepresentation. I ask a simple question: Is there any infamy in the political life of this country to which the Prime Minister will not stoop?
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.
—We now face a situation where this Parliament is about to stop today- -
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.
—And the person responsible for it is the Prime Minister.
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. I think we will have 30 seconds silence.
—You know you are going to bring the Parliament to a stop; that is obvious. I can see it.
—I ask the Leader of the Opposition--

—I would like all honourable members to reflect on the issue. I think that the only point we can proceed from is that there has been an allegation, hotly denied with words that were unparliamentary. I named the honourable member for Wills. I have reflected on the matter and I have come to the conclusion that I need to take a solution which is going to enable the Parliament to proceed and I am therefore not going to put the motion in relation to the honourable member for Wills. I will not call the right honourable gentleman to continue with the answer. I will call the next question. I call the honourable member for Kalgoorlie.
