SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the constant themes of Government statements during the period of office of the present Government has been to the effect that the Commonwealth is exercising restraint in raising revenue, that it is attempting to reduce the size of the deficit and that it is attempting to contain the growth of the public sector. If the Government wants to pursue those types of statements, it is all very well, but joined with those statements has been an assertion by the Government that the separate States of this Commonwealth have to share part of the burden and that the States have to tighten their belts.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall a number of discussions that I had on a number of occasions with a very good friend and colleague, Mr Michael Maher, the former State member for Drummoyne, when I was a member of the New South Wales Parliament. Both Michael Maher and I were concerned about many of the things that we were wanting to achieve for our individual electorates. On many occasions we were told that the things we were wanting to do simply could not be done because of the insufficiency of funds being made available by the Commonwealth Government. Despite that type of response, Michael Maher's dogged persistence in promoting the interests of his electorate achieved many outstanding results. The excellence of Michael Maher's representations and the commitment that he had to his constituents saw him increase his majority from something like 100 to about 12,000, a magnificent effort which reflected the dedication and the competence of Michael Maher and the sound judgment of his constituents.

I recall in particular one statement that was made to me by my colleague Michael Maher because of that response. He said: 'If these problems are being created in Canberra by the Government in Canberra perhaps that is where we should be'. I am delighted that Michael Maher has now made a decision to join us in this place and to attempt to influence the decisions that are made concerning the ability of the New South Wales and all the other State governments to meet the increasing demands that are made upon them. The reality is that the present Commonwealth Government has been reducing the financial capacity of the State governments to do the things that they are expected to do. In addition to that the present Government has been divesting itself of responsibilities and passing those responsibilities on to the States without giving the States the financial capacity to carry out those responsibilities.

In view of the fact that the Commonwealth Government and spokesmen for the Commonwealth Government have denied that assertion, I think it is as well that we should examine the facts. The facts are these: Since this Government came to office during the financial year 1975-76 Commonwealth Government revenue has grown from $18,276m to $40,716m this financial year, representing an increase of 123 per cent. During the same period the consumer price index of costs and prices in Australia has increased by only 80 per cent. If Commonwealth revenue had increased at the same rate as the rate of inflation-that is, if it had maintained its real value during the term of the present Government-it would have increased by $14,621m. In fact, total Commonwealth Government revenue has increased by $22,440m. In other words, Commonwealth Government revenue in real terms this financial year is $7,819m greater than it was when this Government came to office in 1975. That is the position concerning Commonwealth Government revenue.

Let us look at the postion of the States. In the first financial year of this Government, as a result of the last Budget of the Labor Government, total funds allocated to the States were $8,555m. This financial year they totalled $13,663m , representing an increase of 60 per cent. As I said, the level of inflation during that period was 80 per cent. If total funds allocated to the States had increased at the same rate as the level of inflation had increased-that is, if the real value of funds allocated to the States had been maintained-they would have increased by $6,844m during that period. In fact, they increased by only $5 ,108m. In other words, the States are worse off in real terms to the extent of $ 1,736m in this year alone. The total amount over the past six years by which the States are worse off is well in excess of $3,500m. The disadvantaged position in which the States have been placed has been brought about as a result of deliberate decisions by this Government, which then goes out to the public and maintains to the contrary.

The position for the States and their residents is even more horrific in relation to capital funds. In the current financial year, 1981-82, general purpose capital funds are at a level of $1,307m. In 1975-76 general purpose capital funds totalled $1,291m, which means that they have increased during the period of this Government by 1.2 per cent. I remind the House that inflation during that period has increased by 80 per cent. That is a damning indictment of the financial policies, the federalist policies, being pursued by this Government. To keep pace with inflation those general purpose capital funds to the States should have increased by $1,033m. In fact, they increased by only $ 16m. In real terms State capital grants are worse off to the extent of $1,017m in 1981-82 compared with 1975-76. How frustrating it is for members of the New South Wales Parliament, when they receive all these demands and requests from their constituents, to have to say: 'I am sorry but in many cases I cannot deliver the sorts of things you are seeking because of the insufficiency of the funds being made available by the Federal Government'.

This situation does not relate to all the States. The unfortunate reality at this time is that New South Wales alone has been deliberately sabotaged by the Fraser Government. As an example I refer to the figures per head of population for Commonwealth funds to the States in the way of general purpose grants for this year. The average for the States is $460 per head. For Queensland the figure is $559 per head; for South Australia it is $576 per head; for Western Australia it is $617 per head; and for Tasmania it is $754 per head. But what is it for New South Wales? New South Wales, the most populous and the largest State , receives $387 per head-about half the amount granted to the highest per capita grant State.

Not only can details of that kind be compounded but we can also look at other examples. The Commonwealth Grants Commission was charged with reporting on the allocation of funds to the States and it reported early last year, following a 2 1/2-year inquiry. The report was available for the Premiers Conference held in June 1981. It recommended that New South Wales be allocated an additional $118m, that Victoria be allocated an additional $68.2m and that Queensland be allocated an additional $108.3m. Despite the fact that New South Wales should have received an additional $118m, it received only $24.5m. I look forward to welcoming a great representative of the people, Michael Maher, when he takes his seat in this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was my good fortune in January to join an Australian parliamentary delegation which visited Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, the Union of Arab Emirates, Oman, Egypt, Israel and Jordan. The delegation was extremely well received in all those nations I have mentioned. Indeed, Australia is held in the greatest esteem. However, I want especially to talk about our visit to Egypt. Egypt is a country with which Australia has very good trading relations. It purchases huge quantities of our wheat, less quantities of our wool, our meat, our lead and our iron ore. We in turn, of course, do not buy very much from that country. Possibly we buy some cotton fabrics and some dried vegetables. So the balance of trade is very much in favour of Australia. Recently a very large sale of Australian wheat was made to Egypt and it is interested in other exports from this country. Egypt's main revenue, of course, is derived from oil, the Suez Canal and tourism.

SPEECH.PARA: What did concern the members of our delegation were the very poor facilities the Australian Government provides for the Ambassador and his staff. We were shocked at the conditions of the facilities provided by Australia for the Ambassador, the trade commissioners and the members of our staff. They are housed in a Mobil Oil building. The conditions are shocking. The lighting is bad . The ventilation is shocking. The reception room is dismal. The air conditioning does not work. The Ambassador's office and those of the other officials are totally inadequate. The building is most unsatisfactory. We should be doing something about improving it. There is also another section for the Australian immigration office which is a little better than that provided in the Mobil Oil building overlooking the Nile.

While we were there we accompanied the Ambassador across the city of Cairo to a new building which has just about been completed and the Ambassador would like to have two floors of the accommodation that is available there. He has made tentative arrangements. Indeed, this new building is in a very fine part of the city of Cairo and would provide most suitable accommodation for the Ambassador, the members of our immigration staff and the whole embassy staff. I think we have about 27 or 28 members on our staff in the embassy with four or five staff members in our immigration department. We as a government should be looking at providing this suitable accommodation which is so necessary for the increasing of trade and the prestige of Australia.

I hope that the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony), the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) and the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) will take note of the very poor conditions for our staff in Cairo. The image of Australia is certainly impaired as a result of the poor conditions. I have made a submission to the Deputy Prime Minister, pointing out to him the problems associated with our embassy there. Let us hope that we will achieve some results. If we are to develop our trade and if our ambassadorial officials are given decent conditions, it will be to the advantage of all concerned. I might add that the Ambassador's residence is excellent. There is no problem with the personal accommodation of the Ambassador and, I understand, that the staff are also quite happy with their conditions. While the delegation was in Cairo it took part in the Australia Day celebrations, which was attended by more than 400 guests. It was a splendid occasion for Australia. More than 400 ambassadors and their staff turned up to celebrate Australia Day.

Once again, I cannot but stress the importance of improving the situation in Cairo. I know that a tight financial situation exists, not only in this country but throughout the world, but if we are to develop our trade and elevate Australia's image we must do something about the situation of our officials in Cairo. Egypt has 40 million people and will be increasing its trade with Australia. Let us provide our staff with decent facilities. This will improve our standing in Egypt, will be to the benefit of this country and will bring in the valuable export income which is so necessary to our economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was fascinated by the travelogue delivered by the honourable member for Paterson (Mr O'Keefe), but I would like to come a little closer to home and talk this morning about building schools rather than building palaces on the banks of the Nile. I enter this debate to deplore the deficiencies in federal policy and funding as they affect the quality of education in New South Wales. There can be no doubt that successive cuts in Federal funding have placed schools in that State in a very bad position indeed. The New South Wales Minister for Education said last year that Federal funds had declined, in real terms, by between 11 per cent and 12 per cent since the election of the Fraser Government. During that time New South Wales schools have lost $43m. The guidelines issued last year left New South Wales schools another $23m down. The Minister described it as a disgraceful blow against public schools and their pupils. Despite these difficulties the New South Wales Government has made valiant attempts to work in the interests of school children throughout the State. It is very pleasing to note that one of the State's newest and largest high schools was opened recently at Concord.

SPEECH.PARA: Tertiary sector students in the State fare little better. They are battling along on the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance, which is below the poverty line and is paid only to those whose families qualify under a restrictive and unfair means test. The prospects for an improvement in TEAS are nil as this Government pushes ahead with its ill-judged student loans scheme.

In the area of technical and further education, despite all the self- congratulation that this Government and this Minister appear to be addicted to as some kind of escape from reality, the reality is that TAFE is still the poor relation of the education family. Despite the fact that TAFE serves about 60 per cent of all post-secondary students, it receives only about 11 per cent of federal funding. It is small wonder that TAFE has been squeezed and that services in some areas have had to be cut in the face of this funding crisis.

I turn now to migrant education. It is important to note the extreme deficiencies in this area through failure in government policy and failure in federal funding. Last year, in School Report, a publication produced by teacher and parent organisations, the following statement under the heading 'Help for Migrants is Meagre' appeared:
It is an unfortunate fact that Australian governments have been quick to bring migrant workers to Australia and slow to provide for their welfare and for their children's education.

It is well known that many workers migrate in order to get a better deal for their children, and although it is obvious that poor knowledge of English is a severe handicap in Australian schools, government efforts in English teaching for migrant children have been pitiful.

Substantial programs were started only in the early '70s, and they still cover only slightly more than half of the children needing attention. In spite of this inadequate effort, conservative governments in the late '70s have been cutting back on spending for migrant education.

I concede that there was a miserable increase in last year's Budget but that increase was inadequate. At the end of 1980, in Australian schools, there were 576,000 students from non-English speaking backgrounds, 211,000 of them in New South Wales. That is one fifth of the total school population. The migrant education program for these children is far from adequate. I would like to consider some of the reasons for this and suggest some ways in which the situation could be improved. Obviously, first of all, this situation has arisen because of inadequate band-aid 'ad hoc' funding, but it goes a little deeper than that.

Migrant education is unsatisfactory in this country because it is subjected to a mishmash of administrative arrangements. The system for migrant education is far too complex. The programs involve a number of State and Federal Government departments and a number of statutory bodies, including the Schools Commission and the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs. At the delivery end there is a whole range of bodies-government schools, non-government schools, colleges and community organisations. There is clearly a need, if the system is to work in the interests of migrants and their children, for reorganisation and rationalisation of the administration of migrant programs. In addition, the system of teacher employment is quite unsatisfactory. For example, most adult migrant education teachers are casual teachers. In New South Wales less than 20 per cent of the adult migrant education teachers are permanent. The New South Wales Government recognises the difficulty. It would like to take on additional permanent teachers; in fact it is willing to take on 160 additional permanent teachers in this field if the Federal Government will recognise its responsibility and make those funds available.

Migrant education has also suffered through the destruction of research, planning and review mechanisms-mechanisms, I might add, destroyed by this Government. The Curriculum Development Centre has done valuable work in migrant education. The Education Research and Development Committee has commissioned and done work itself of great value in the field of migrant education. But both the CDC and the ERDC, which have done great work in this field, were axed by the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the razor gang report, in April last year. A further vehicle for planning, co-ordination and review, and for bringing together the different threads of effort in this field, has also been axed. In his statement of 4 June last year the Minister for Education said that the State co-ordinators of the multicultural education program would no longer be meeting regularly on a national basis and they would be no longer publishing separate reports on their work.

In the field of adult migrant education there have been numerous criticisms of the deficiencies of that system-criticisms too numerous for me to mention in detail this morning. They include the fifth report of the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty, a statement by the Australian Council on Population and Ethnic Affairs in 1977, a statement by the Good Neighbour Council of Victoria and, of course, the report of the Galbally Review of Post-arrival Programs and Services to Migrants Committee. In addition, a great deal of implied criticism is contained in the education policy of the Greek Welfare Association. There is no doubt that the Government has failed in this field of migrant education, and this failure shows up in particular geographic areas and in particular electorates. The 1976 census showed the areas and the electorates favoured by migrants and it shows, therefore, the clusters of need. The census grouped together electorates on the basis of the proportion of population born in non- English speaking countries. The electorate with the highest population of people born in non-English speaking countries is in fact Grayndler in New South Wales with 31.62 per cent. Most of the electorates with a high population of people from non-English speaking countries are in the cities. The electorate of Melbourne, was second highest, followed by Wills, Lalor, Gellibrand, Sydney, Kingsford-Smith, Melbourne Ports and then Prospect in New South Wales.

Number 10 in the list is the electorate of Lowe in New South Wales, where 23.3 per cent of the population were born in non-English speaking countries. I am glad that the people of Lowe will very soon have an opportunity to register their disapproval at this shoddy treatment and neglect by this Government. In speaking of shoddy treatment in relation to Lowe, I should comment on the shoddy treatment that the former right honourable member for Lowe received in this place on Tuesday. Even though the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) was tongue tied on that day, I would have thought that someone on the Government side, if not the Prime Minister, might have been gracious enough to have marked the departure of Sir William McMahon with some words of tribute and farewell. After all, the former member was a Prime Minister and a Treasurer and occupied five other portfolios. He served as leader and deputy leader of his Party. Possibly the greatest service to his Party was to hold his seat for 33 years under very difficult circumstances. I have no doubt that he survived some close shaves because of the service that he gave to his electorate.

On that point, the electors of Lowe are indeed fortunate that they have available Michael Maher of the Australian Labor Party, a man with an even greater commitment to elected service. He is a family man and lives in the electorate. He is an experienced parliamentarian and has long experience in working for electorates and for the betterment of people and their families. I have no doubt that Michael Maher will serve the electors of Lowe with distinction when they elect him on 13 March as their member to represent them in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish today to express to the House my confidence in the Thompson Government in Victoria. The new leadership of Premier Lindsay Thompson has given Victoria a new look and will continue to do so into the 1980s . The Victorian government led by Lindsay Thompson is the Government to take Victoria into and through this decade. I would like to examine in an unemotional way today the damage that a Labor government would do to Victoria. I will just reveal the facts of who controls the Australian Labor party in Victoria and the facts about the damage that would be done to that State if a Labor government were elected.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at who controls the Labor Party. It is well known-nobody will deny it-that the Labor Party in this Parliament and in the other parliaments of Australia is in fact the party of the trade union movement. The history of the matter is that the Labor Party was formed out of the union movement early this century and late last century to represent in Parliament the unions and what they could not achieve outside Parliament. That continues today. The Labor Party is the party of the union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —And doing a great job.
—I am glad the honourable member acknowledges that. That fact has been recognised by the Opposition.
—A good job.

—I note that another Labor member acknowledges that. Let us take this aspect a little further and look at the Victorian conference of the ALP. There is a faction there called the socialist left. Who belongs to the socialist left? What is it? We read about it a lot. Let us look at some commentators' definitions of the socialist left. The first reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Hard to define, but it is possibly the single most radical rump of any Labor Party in the Western world.
The second states:
The socialist left is a party within a party, dedicated to a radical reformation of society.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition members are getting upset. Just look at them! The third example reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The socialist left faction is often portrayed as a stony-hearted pro-Marxist faction within the ALP, pushing for a peaceful overthrow of capitalism.
Those are some commentaries on the socialist left.

TALK.START.PARA: —Source the commentaries.

—Does the honourable member want to know? When John Halfpenny resigned from the Communist Party of Australia and joined the ALP he joked that he could not see the difference between the Victorian branch of the ALP, which is dominated by the highly organised socialist left faction, and the Communist Party. The Australian of June 1980, in reporting Mr Halfpenny's remarks, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: There is some evidence that the Socialist left faction, led by Mr Jim Roulston . . . is some ways more revolutionary--
Mr Halfpenny is saying this about the ALP-
and radical than the ageing and ineffective Communist Party.

Those are the facts. Honourable members opposite should look at the Australian of June 1980. They asked for facts; they got them. I would now like to look at the 1981 ALP Conference. As honourable members know, the conference of the Labor Party controls the Victorian parliamentary party. There were 466 delegates to the ALP conference in 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—The facts say that. Of those delegates there were 284 representing the union movement and 182 representing constituencies. That means that approximately 60.9 per cent of the delegates to the State conference of the Labor Party are union representatives and 39.06 per cent represent constituencies. That gives more proof to the claim that the union movement controls the Labor Party. As we know, resolutions of that conference are binding on the Parliamentary party in Victoria. That is another interesting fact that needs to be established today. It establishes clearly the bias of the Labor Party towards the trade union movement. We know that decisions made at State ALP conferences are binding on the parliamentary party. We saw that clearly in the Newport row.

SPEECH.PARA: An interesting paper on this subject was prepared by a New South Wales ALP education officer, Mr Michael Easson. Mr Easson looked at the position of the socialist left and the ALP in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. There is no education-research officer for the New South Wales Labor Party by the name of Mr Easson. My point of order is that the honourable member is misleading the House.
— Order! There is no point of order.

—I will correct that. Mr Michael Easson is apparently the education officer of the Labour Council. I am sure the honourable member for Grayndler recognises it. Let us look at what Mr Michael Easson says about the socialist left and the control of the conference in Victoria. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The combined vote of the Socialist Left and the Independents-who are embraced in an alliance to control the Victorian ALP-fluctuates between 58.37 per cent and 56.50 per cent.

That is interesting because it means that the socialist left controls the State conference of the Labor Party in Victoria, that at any time among other factions and other alliances there will be wheels and deals within the Labor Party at the conference, and that between 43 per cent to the mid-50s and from the mid-50s to 60 per cent of that conference can be controlled by the socialist left. That is easy to do because 13 per cent make up the independent faction with which, I think, Mr Cain and Senator Button are aligned. The other factions are known. There is the socialist left faction and there is the centre unity faction of the Labor Party. So the pro-revolutionary socialist left, which is sympathetic to the Palestine Liberation Organisation and the Irish Republican Army, controls the Australian Labor Party in Victoria. People in the Victorian Labor Party may say that the Party is not controlled by the socialist left but that is fiction and false. No one can represent the Labor Party in Victoria without representing the socialist left.

There are international implications in this control of the Labor Party. Let us look at the Omega navigation base in Gippsland. Omega is used for navigation by commercial aircraft and merchant shipping. It is also used by submarines. The ALP's foreign affairs committee has passed a resolution in Victoria in favour of dismantling the Omega tower and navigation base in Gippsland. That is what the Labor Party would do. Having the power to control the conference, the foreign affairs committee will take that resolution to the next ALP State conference--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at how upset Opposition members are getting when I tell the truth. Such a decision would become binding on any ALP government.
—I take a point of order. The honourable member is misleading this House with his untrue statements.
—There is no point of order. If the honourable member wishes to state a point of order he should do so in accordance with the Standing Orders .

—Members of the Opposition are deliberately interrupting me so as to take up my time because they cannot stand the truth. Let me move on. Let us see what control the socialist left, through the Labor conference, would have over the ALP in Victoria in union matters. The ALP platform in Victoria commits a Labor government to repealing any legislation which in any way restricts union activities.
—Disgraceful.

—As the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs says, it is disgraceful. That is why the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria has had to say that a Labor government would review Victoria's role in respect of royal commissions. He says that a Labor government would not automatically withdraw from this area. He cannot say that it would for electoral reasons. We all know what he would be forced to do by the socialist left because the unions would run riot in Victoria. The Labor Party would be forced by the socialist left, through the conference in Victoria, to withdraw from the royal commissions.
—That is a lie.
—That is not a lie. I will quote from an article in the Sun News- Pictorial of 19 February. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Cain also said that industrial legislation such as essential services and secret ballot legislation which the ALP has said it would repeal were not needed if a government did its job.

Mr Cain, the Leader of the Labor Party, is saying that the ALP will repeal essential services legislation which was responsible for getting milk to mothers and children who were denied it by the trade union movement during a strike last year. Mr Cain is going to repeal all that legislation. There will be no secret ballots in Victoria. There will be no essential services legislation in Victoria to control unions. Even the Vital Projects Act, which is similar to the New South Wales Act, will be repealed because Mr Cain does not have the power that Mr Wran has in New South Wales. That is what is going to happen. The unions are going to run riot in Victoria, as they are running riot in New South Wales. Let us look at today's headlines in respect of New South Wales, which is under a Labor government. They read: 'Food, petrol crisis'. This is what is happening in New South Wales under a Wran government today. The headlines also state: 'Trains back but cars, shops hit'. That is what will happen. The glitter has gone off Mr Wran. This will happen if Labor gets into office in Victoria. There will be no power; there will be strikes. Sydney is the strike capital of Australia. There will be no investment in New South Wales because there is no electricity for factories. There will be investment in Victoria because of the industrial capacity of the electricity commission in that State. Victoria will be the investment capital of Australia under a Liberal government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us get back to talking sense after the drivel that has just been spoken. I want to direct the House's attention today to some of the drivel that has been spoken by this man's leader during election campaigns. In 1975 this man's leader, the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), promised that the real value--
—I take a point of order. I was referred to as 'this man'. If I could be named by my electorate I would appreciate such a courtesy.
—I thought the honourable member was going to object to my saying that the Prime Minister was his leader.
—Order! I draw the honourable member's attention to the Standing Orders in respect of the way in which a member is addressed in this House.
—The temporary member for Hotham, who persists in speaking drivel in this House.
—Higgins.
—I take a point of order.
—He speaks so infrequently that one does not get to know who he is .

—I am sure that the honourable member for Hotham, who is a member of the Australian Labor Party, will be pleased to hear his colleague the honourable member for Grayndler say that he is the temporary member for Hotham!
—Order! There is no point of order.

—To be quite serious, I think it is most important to look at the iniquitous ways that this Government has treated the pensioners of Australia, the people who have made this country what it is. In 1975 the present Prime Minister promised that the real value of pensions would be preserved. In 1975 when that statement was made the age pension was 23.2 per cent of average weekly earnings. It is considerably less than that now. I will come back to that in a few moments. The present Government also made a number of outrageous promises which it has subsequently breached in relation to pensioners. Since this Government came to power in November 1975 it has done a number of things that have drastically reduced the living standards of pensioners and those on social security benefits in this country. At one stage it reduced pension increases from twice yearly adjustments to once yearly adjustments. It restricted the cost of living allowances for pensioners over 70 years of age as well as their eligibility under the means test. The Government reversed the Labor Government's decision to pay free of means test pensions to people aged 69. It reduced the subsidy on aged persons housing from two to one. The announced Fraser policy of a three-year program costing $225m has been cut to $150m for three years and this is about two-thirds of what the previous Labor Government spent on housing the aged in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, on 26 February last year I drew the attention of this House and the Minister to the fact that the Government was even then proposing to tax the amount of money earned by pensioners who are in receipt of fringe benefits. At that time I warned the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) that the Government needed to bring in supplementary legislation to change the tax threshold as it affected pensioners. Last year I brought to the attention of the House the situation that people would be paying tax on the amount of money they earned over and above the pension, even though they were on fringe benefits. As I said, the Government did nothing and indeed last year 250,000 pensioners paid income tax on the $20 they earned above the pension which is rather an iniquitous circumstance for a government to apply. This year many more pensioners will pay income tax on the amount of money they earn above the pension. By November this year more than 270,000 single aged pensioners on fringe benefits will be added to the number of pensioners who pay income tax. Under the present system nine out of every 10 single pensioners on the maximum rate will pay tax this fiscal year. The reason for this is that single pensioners who have been receiving a total income of $89.70 a week, that is the $69.70 pension plus the $20 they are allowed to earn and still retain the fringe benefits, have gone through the tax free threshold which is $80.70 a week. Each one of those pensioners will pay $150 in tax this year. The Government is taking $3 a week out of the pockets of the pensioners of Australia. I do not know how people can live on $89.70 a week but the Fraser Government obviously believes that they can live on at least $3 less than that a week.

Obviously this Government does not care what happens to the pensioners of this country. But I am sure that the iniquitous way in which this Government has treated the pensioners of this country will be brought home to the Government in the Lowe by-election to be held in a few weeks. My electorate of Grayndler and the electorate of Lowe have a higher number of pensioners than most electorates in Australia. In my electorate 12 1/2 per cent of the population are age pensioners. In the electorate of Lowe 14 per cent of the population are age pensioners. Those people will take a very close look at what this Government's policy is doing to the aged when they vote in the Lowe by-election on 13 March. When they do look at the Government's policy they will see a very sorry policy. But when they have a look at how the Government looks after itself and the previous right honourable member they will see that the Government has been rather more generous. Last year we saw the Government put through this House a Bill which specifically gave Sir William McMahon, the former right honourable member for Lowe and a man who admits that he receives the age pension, $500,000. That was very nice for Sir William McMahon. I think in the latter years of his life as the right honourable member for Lowe he forgot where the place was because he did not go near it and in that time he received an age pension--

TALK.START.PARA: —He received a pension?

—That is quite correct, and he got $500,000. But his colleagues in this Parliament have decided that this year they will take $3 a week off the rest of the pensioners. The 15,110 pensioners who live in the electorate of Lowe will have $3 a week taken off them. The sums are rather interesting. They will probably be paying for Sir William's pension.
—Do you want Mr Whitlam's pension reduced?

—I do not think Mr Whitlam got half a million dollars in cash. Indeed he knew where his electorate was and when Mr Whitlam was Prime Minister it was the only time in this country that pensioners received justice. This Government only gives the pensioners a tax bill. It takes $3 a week out of the pockets of every pensioner living in the electorate of Lowe so that it can pay out to the former member $500,000. I think that is absolutely scandalous.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like the Parliament and the Australian people to look at what has happened to pensions as a percentage of average weekly earnings in this country. I will seek the permission of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown), when he resumes his position at the Table, to incorporate in Hansard a table prepared by the Parliamentary Library Statistics Group which sets out details on the pension as a percentage of average weekly earnings.
