TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister is so concerned about the plight of pensioners that he has gone to sleep on the back bench. I also believe it is most important to have a look at the major candidates who will be contesting the Lowe by-election.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is enough for us to have to suffer having the honourable member here without his juvenile asinine remarks and he would be of great benefit to his constituents if he got on with his speech.
—There is no point of order.
—The Minister has woken up. That is fine to hear.
—I do object to that, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I ask you to call upon the honourable member to withdraw that remark.
—Order! I call the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs on a point of order.
—I will be happy to withdraw, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I think the honourable member has just withdrawn the remark.
—Thank you. The Chair did not hear the words. The honourable member for Grayndler has withdrawn.

—It is important to have a look at the candidates for the Lowe by- election-Michael Maher, a man who has worked very hard for his electorate and for the pensioners in the area, and Phillip Taylor, who is the Liberal Party candidate. Mr Taylor's experience on the Burwood Council of which he was mayor was to oppose an allocation of petrol to Meals on Wheels drivers during the petrol strike-taking food out of the mouths of pensioners. He opposed a donation of $500 to the local orphanage. He is even against children and orphans. He opposed a donation of $550 to the local ambulance appeal. He is against the sick as well. The balance sheet in the Lowe by-election in a few weeks time lies between one candidate Michael Maher, the previous member for Drummoyne who has worked hard for the pensioners in his area, and Mr Taylor, the Liberal candidate , who is against the aged, who is against orphans and who is against the sick. It is a very sorry sort of balance sheet but obviously Mr Taylor is a man in the mould of the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser).
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sainsbury Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about some of the problems that I face at the present time living in the country in New South Wales. But before I do that I just want to put to rest a quite mendacious statement by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), who alleged that somehow at some later time this year $3 a week will be--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. My recollection is that Mr Speaker and you have always ruled the word 'mendacious' as being unparliamentary.
—Order! There is no point of order. I accept the word mendacious as being a parliamentary decription.

—I did not want to use the word that was bandied around here so falsely this morning but I do want to point out that there is absolutely no truth in the allegation made by the honourable member for Grayndler that pensioners in the electorate of Lowe or any other part of Australia will be put in a position of paying extra tax this year. If they move into a higher tax bracket without changes to the tax scales, as would happen with any other citizens of this country, that might happen. But to say that 15,100 pensioners in the electorate of Lowe will automatically be paying $3 in tax a week this year is absolutely untrue and misleading. In fact if one looks at the number of pensioners who paid tax in 1975-76 under the Hayden Budget one sees that some 400,000 pensioners had to pay tax and with one stroke of the pen when we reformed the tax scales some 18 months later the Liberal Government took off about 250,000 people. I just hope that in the campaigning in the eletorate of Lowe these statements that are meant to put fear into the hearts of pensioners- older people who genuinely worry when such statements are bandied around-will be understood and that the pensioners will understand what the truth is. They will get the truth if they read statements from the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Chaney) and if they listen to statements that are made by people on this side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk as a citizen of New South Wales living in a country area because things are really going bad in my State. I wanted to speak on this subject when I received the call in the grievance debate irrespective of whether there was a by-election for Lowe or whether a State election was coming on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member for Eden-Monaro has been speaking for about five minutes but the clock has stopped.
—I thank the honourable member for Prospect. There is a technical fault in the equipment.

—There is no fault with the other clock. Perhaps the honourable member ought to look behind him occasionally. New South Wales has been suffering for some time with mismanagement in general. That is beginning to catch up with the State Government; but in particular we are suffering from a misallocation of resources away from country areas to the cities of New South Wales. As a person who represents the country areas, it does concern me a great deal.

SPEECH.PARA: I will acknowledge that the Federal Government has some direct input into the allocation of resources in country areas in Australia. I am always vocal with my own Government when I see any misallocation of that nature occur. In particular, in recent months I have had quite a lot to say about the tariff debate because, after all, the export industries which are very strong in my electorate suffer a great deal because of the privileges given to certain industries usually located in the cities. My views are well known nationally on that issue. I do not propose to pursue it today. I also acknowledge that in one area where my Government has control, namely in that of Telecom Australia and Australia Post, at the present time there may well be a misallocation of resources towards people in the city.

On that score I am prepared to take up the matter with my own Government and pursue it vigorously. Nevertheless, most people in Australia have their every- day activities constrained usually by State governments-not Federal governments- in the sense that the State governments control the roads, the hospitals, the rail services, the police services and the educational services. Whenever decisions are made in those areas they are essentially ones for the State government. The honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) noted earlier some misgivings in relation to New South Wales, in particular in terms of how much money the New South Wales Government has got from the Federal Government in recent years. I just want to mention one point there. He raised some figures and I acknowledge that the Federal Government has some sort of an input in this area . But I would like to note that between the 1977 and 1981 Budgets there was an increase of $1,324m in the amount provided to New South Wales from all sources from the Federal Government. That represents an increase, on my calculations, of about 41 1/2 per cent. The honourable member for Hunter might say that that does not quite keep up with inflation. I have not done that calculation, but it must be very close to keeping up with inflation. I want to point out that on top of that $1,324m some other factors ought to be taken into account. Firstly, in this year the New South Wales Government has some sources of revenue from health collections that it did not have before-they were created by our own measures. Secondly, there was a substantial increase in funds available through the New South Wales Government ceasing to pay teacher scholarships and by the Commonwealth picking up the tab by way of Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme scholarships. That ought to be remembered. Thirdly, there has been-this is an indirect effect-an enormous increase in the amount of Commonwealth funding by way of transfer payments to people in New South Wales; so through pensions and other benefits there has been a very high capacity on the part of people to pay charges which are being collected all the time by the State Government quite directly from revenue given to individuals in New South Wales. On top of that, the increase in population we experienced in the time that we needed capital works for schools just is not occurring in New South Wales. As we all know, the strong growth states are Western Australia and Queensland where there are more enlightened governments. That has meant that the pressure on capital works in schools is far less than it was when a Liberal-Country Party government came into power in New South Wales in the mid 1960s and when, concomitantly, there was a big increase in spending on schools. If we really look at the situation there has been around a 50 per cent increase in usable funds by New South Wales from the Federal Government. In the face of all that, what is the State Government doing to my area? The rail services are shot to pieces. There was a very big stunt in New South Wales just prior to the last State election when the express passenger transport train travelled around. It was called by many people 'Mr Wran's train'. I tell honourable members that there is no prospect that my electors will see or be able to use this train for many a long day. In a town like Goulburn, which is on the main Sydney-Melbourne line, I can promise, under the present policies of the State Government, that very few passengers will be able to get on that train. Perhaps this time next year I will be able to catalogue that disaster.

The freight costs for people in country areas have been savagely increased on at least two occasions by the State Government. They represent a very strong impost on wheat growers. They have been a very strong impost on the coal industry, an industry which is suffering already under the industrial policies of the State Government.

Centralisation has begun to occur again in New South Wales. Our road system is suffering drastically especially in the national highways area in New South Wales. In my own electorate there is now a reallocation of resources towards the magic Sydney-Newcastle axis, an area which, in terms of national highways, is not one of national significance; it is more one of intrastate significance. We are finding that funds are being chiselled out of the Hume Highway projects and the Federal Highway projects in favour of the more parochial areas, the stronger Labor areas of Sydney and Newcastle. In terms of general mismanagement in New South Wales, leaving aside the wages demands that were deliberately fostered by the State Government, especially in the electricity area, we need to focus on the disaster in electricity in New South Wales. Very poor maintenance-which means, in my terms as an engineer mismanagement in the electricity area-has meant that the New South Wales people are beginning to suffer in terms of services and in terms of costs.

The State Government has used up all the resources as far as we can see that were left around for a rainy day and the statutory authorities of New South Wales. Frankly, it is looking to us as citizens in the country of New South Wales as if our own State is going broke. It is the old situation that whenever the socialists get into power they spend everybody else's money and tear down the enterprise of the State or Commonwealth they are looking after. It happened in Canberra for three years. I certainly hope it is not allowed to happen in Victoria in the upcoming election. Thankfully the tide is beginning to turn. I think that the New South Wales people are understanding that the policies of New South Wales that are milking and have milked our State and tended to turn it bankrupt are not suitable for the State and this will be shown in the coming by- election in Lowe.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable members time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, today I wish to grieve for all Australians, for that 50 1/2 per cent of Australians who were seduced, traduced and misled at the last election to elect this Government and for the other 49 1/2 per cent who have suffered along with them under the policies that the Fraser Government has delivered to Australians. One of the great characteristics of the Australian population is that they share similar beliefs. They believe in a fair go, they believe in honesty, they believe in decency and they believe in fidelity. Is it any wonder that they are disillusioned when they see the record of the present Federal Government and when they see the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)-who can be labelled as being a dishonest person-in Parliament this morning causing an enormous blow-up. Is it any wonder that they are disappointed that the Government they believed in, that they wanted to elect has delivered them so little in the way of service and so much in the way of disappointment?

SPEECH.PARA: I particularly want to refer to the electorate of Lowe because, along with the Deputy Clerk of the House, Mr Blake, I was born, bred and lived in the electorate of Lowe for a long time. I think I have a fair understanding of the sorts of people who live in the electorate of Lowe.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't play football for them.
—Oh yes I did. I played with Western Suburbs. I do not tell the Parramatta people that, they might not like it. As a matter of fact, I played with the Deputy Clerk.
—Is that why you are getting such a good go?
—I did not hear that interjection, but I have no doubt that it is inane as it came from--
—I ask the honourable member to ignore interjections and proceed with his remarks.

—I suggest that the residents of the electorate of Lowe would make a fair representation of a total cross-section of the Australian community. The residents of Lowe come from all sorts of socio-economic groups, from the rather wealthy up in Strathfield to the middle-class in Burwood, to the working class in Concord and Five Dock where, of course, the Deputy Clerk and the incumbent member for Parramatta were born and bred.
—Don't they live in the other suburbs?

—We will forget about the other suburbs. That is a fair enough grouping. There is a very big migrant complement in the seat of Lowe. There are a lot of schools and churches in the area and it has a very interesting socio- economic mix. Despite all the variances in income, background and social affinity, the people of Lowe probably share the aspirations of the rest of the people of Australia. They want to own a home. They want to see that the education system works properly. They want to see that there are employment opportunities for their kids. Generally, they want a better life for themselves. I feel that in this month of February in 1982 the people of Lowe and the rest of Australia are suffering great disillusionment. They look at this country, a country so rich in so many ways, but a country that is mismanaged by a government in which they placed their trust. They feel frustrated and disappointed.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1949 the residents of Lowe have supported a Liberal government. They have supported the right honourable Sir William McMahon, even in his dotage. Even in the last bursts of his senility in 1980 they supported him. Probably the greatest claim to fame he had in his declining years was that he was the only politician in Australian history to get a parliamentary salary, an old age pension and the family allowance all at the same time. That is probably his apotheosis. On 13 March the people in Lowe will have an opportunity to exhibit their disappointment and disillusionment with this Government and to elect a Labor member for the first time since 1949. Of course, that Labor member will be Michael Maher, the present State member for Drummoyne. I suggest that when they elect Michael Maher to this Parliament--

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the name?

—His name is Michael Maher. The honourable member will know his name; he will learn it very quickly when Michael Maher comes here. He is a very competent politician and a member the people in Lowe, my forebears, will be very pleased to have as their member.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer particularly to a couple of areas in which the people of Lowe are suffering the same disappointments, the same disillusionments and the same frustrations as the rest of Australia. I refer in particular to interest rates for home loans. The mismanagement of the monetary system is undoubtedly one of the greatest failings of the Fraser Administration-along with a lot of others, of course. Business journals are now predicting higher interest rates across the board in 1982. Prime overdraft rates are already in the range of 16.25 per cent to 16.5 per cent and are predicted to go higher, to as high as 18 per cent, in the June quarter. In those circumstances it is highly unlikely that there will be a reversal of recent trends towards the collapse of lending for small business and housing. Our national savings are being syphoned off only to the most glamorous and high-paying areas, such as resource-based investment and the speculative areas. With a depleted money supply, thanks to the unduly restrictive monetary targets of this Government, there are simply not enough funds for the less glamorous yet equally essential forms of investment in such areas as housing and small business. Of course, the so-called 'dries' of the Liberal Party of Australia-I notice at least one of them in the House at the moment--

TALK.START.PARA: —What, only one?

—There is one I can identify. Those so-called 'dries' are calling for the deregulation of interest rates on housing loans and small overdrafts as a means of attracting more money to those areas. That response shows that those Liberals are not only economic 'dries' but also morally parched. The increase in housing loans and small overdraft interest rates that would occur could be three or four percentage points if interest rates were to reach the levels predicted. What would a 3 per cent rise in interest rates do to a modest loan of $30,000 for a house? Monthly repayments would increase by $66. The people of Australia recognise that. It is no wonder that the popularity of the Government is at such a low ebb. Under those circumstances thousands of people in Australia would suddenly be faced with the prospect of having to sell the homes for which they had worked so hard. New home buyers would virtually disappear from the market. There can be no doubt that the deregulation of housing interest rates in the present circumstances would lead to a massive transfer from poor to rich in this country. Is it any wonder that the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) on AM this morning suggested that now is not the time for the Government to go to a poll? He will find that out very forcibly when the Government does go to a mini poll on 13 March. The people of Lowe will let him know that what he said this morning on AM is correct. It is unlikely that that situation will change before December 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: The shortage of funds in the housing and small business areas can be overcome only by a change in the Government's economic strategy, including a rejection of its restrictive monetary policies. Restrictive monetary targets are destroying the job opportunities of thousands of Australians, ruining the hopes of home owners and buyers and maintaining an extraordinary pressure on small businesses, leading to the highest rate of bankruptcy in Australia's political history.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not true.
—It is true.
—Give us the figures.
—I do not have the figures with me.
—Then don't make the statements.
—Order! Honourable members will refrain from directly addressing each other.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will produce the figures for the honourable member for Mitchell if he wants them. They are true and irrefutable. The rate of bankruptcy in Australia under this Government is the highest in our history.
—No--
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell will remain silent.

—Why has the Fraser Government acted so blatantly to destroy worthwhile opportunities for Australians? It has done so because it is ideologically bankrupt, with no effective anti-inflation policy-this is evidenced by the increasing level of inflation, now back to double figures-no wages policy, no business policy and a callous disregard for the consequences of this policy vacuum. All that this Administration has offered for six years is restrictions, not only in the public sector but also in the private sector. That is the reason that business confidence in the Government is fleeing and people are turning to the Australian Labor Party as an alternative. That is the case in New South Wales and it will continue to be so.

SPEECH.PARA: Again this morning the Treasurer (Mr Howard) blamed overseas trends. Many countries have lower interest rates than Australia has at the present time. Clearly it is the domestic administration of policy which is the principal determinant of domestic monetary conditions. The Fraser Government, no matter what it states, cannot run away from that. This Government is presiding over the highest rate of bankruptcy in Australia's history. I repeat: It is presiding over a steady decline in the level of home ownership; it has presided over the highest levels of unemployment and interest rates in the post-War period. It has the worst record of any Government in Australia's history. Is it any wonder that Lowe, after 32 years of Liberal ownership, will fall to the Labor Party on 13 March? I, as an old-time resident of Lowe, look forward to that date when the people with whom I lived for so long will be properly represented in this Parliament by a man of honour, a man of dignity, a man who will represent them thoroughly and decently. That man is Michael Maher.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I begin my remarks on a matter of major moment today, may I say how disappointed I am that the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) let slip his usual very high standards in this House by making a personal attack on Sir William McMahon. I think that what he said about Sir William in his later days in this House was grossly unfair and grossly untrue. I regret that the honourable member for Parramatta who, as I said, has a high standing in this place should have descended in an unaccustomed way to making remarks such as he did. I simply pay tribute to the contribution Sir William McMahon made to this House and to this nation. I believe that it is inappropriate for the honourable member for Parramatta to behave as he did.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter I raise today is in fact a plea to both the New South Wales Government and the Federal Government to preserve, to save from extinction, the underground coal mining industry in New South Wales and particularly in my electorate. I am particularly concerned about the impact on underground coal mining of the 25 per cent increase in rail freights now being imposed by the New South Wales Government. Without question that will bring about the closure of coal mines in my electorate; it will bring unemployment to coal miners in my electorate; and it certainly will bring very severe economic problems to a large section of what was a prosperous, thriving community until the Wran Government came to power in New South Wales.

I include the Federal Government in my request because it imposes an export levy of $1 a tonne on coal produced from those mines. This is done at a time when those mines are not in a situation in which they can adequately cope with that kind of levy, which is based not on profitability but on volume. I accept the fact that the present Government has reduced this levy from the $6 a tonne that was introduced by the previous Federal Labor Government, but it is still $1 a tonne. I have made repeated submissions to the Federal Government to get this levy reduced and have been advised that the Premier of New South Wales has threatened that if the levy is withdrawn by the Federal Government the State Labor Government will reimpose it in order to get additional revenue for the State Government. While I can be critical of the Federal Government for not having withdrawn the levy, it is incredible that a State Labor government would seek to perpetuate the damage being done to the underground coal mining industry and to jobs by threatening to impose such a levy if the Federal Government withdraws it.

I want to concentrate my concern on the matter of the Labor Government in New South Wales increasing by 25 per cent rail freights for coal mining companies. These companies are already suffering severe losses. The employees of those companies are suffering severe reductions in income because of the loss of bonuses and other additional income on which they base a reasonable standard of living. It seems incredible that, in order to finance the massive transport losses generated in the city of Sydney by the State Rail Authority, the country people and coal producers of the State should have offensive and enormous increases in coal freight rates imposed on them.

Is it not disgraceful that the State Rail Authority of New South Wales will so increase freights in order simply to subsidise the city, after all, that is a typical Labor Party stunt as it is concerned only with the cities? Even more offensive is the fact that the imposition of this enormous increase of 25 per cent, which will bring about the closure of mines in my electorate, has taken place at a time when the State Government has dictated in an incredible way to these companies that they must not use any other form of transport. The State Government has behaved in a way Chicago gangsters traditionally behave. It has said to the companies: 'You are not permitted to use any other form of transport '. I know of no other industry in Australia which has been subjected to that kind of dictatorship. Having done that, it has said: 'We will now increase the price by 25 per cent'. I regret to say that the coal miners in my electorate have committed a heinous sin as far as the Labor Party is concerned in that they have tended to vote Liberal. There is no doubt that those who are left in jobs will continue to do so because they recognise what the Labor Party has done to them. They have had to suffer because, I presume, they have had the good sense, at least in Federal elections, to return a Liberal member for their area. They are suffering as a result of that sin. It seems incredible that a State Labor government should do this.

I notice today that at last the Premier of New South Wales has been forced to talk to the coal miners, the coal mining industry and the unions about this matter. He has continually ducked going into the area to talk to them. He refused to turn up for the opening of the Tahmoor mine, even though he was supposed to open it and his name was on the plaque. He ducked going there because he knew that the representatives of the Japanese steel industry would complain bitterly at the official opening-as they did-about the anti-coal, anti- shipping and anti-transport attitudes of the New South Wales Labor Government. However, today an injunction was taken out to prevent the State Rail Authority collecting the increased rates and, as a result of that injunction, the Labor Government at last has conceded that it will talk with the industry. As a result , that injunction has been suspended. I plead with the New South Wales Government, for God's sake, for the sake of the miners and their families who live in my electorate, to give the mining industry a fair go. Please listen to the industry-I make this point to the Labor Party in general-when it says that unemployment is being caused. The policies of the State Labor Party in New South Wales are anti-coal and anti my electorate and are causing distress--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is now 12.15 p.m. In accordance with Standing Order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The critical situation in the home building industry as a consequence of the Government's economic policies.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning during Question Time the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) were questioned in regard to falling home ownership in Australia. Figures were given that home ownership had fallen from 73.8 per cent in 1978 to 71.9 per cent in 1980. The Minister for Housing and Construction, who is at the table, always argues that Australia has the greatest rate of home ownership in the world. That may have been the case, but it has been falling over the last few years and it is still falling. The situation is becoming drastic because the housing sector is a major victim of the Government's economic policy. Next to unemployment, housing is the most serious social problem in this country. The housing sector is faced with high and rising interest rates, a flow of funds away from the housing sector and dramatic cutbacks in Commonwealth funds for State housing. They have all acted to stifle the housing sector and to bring about stagnation in the home building industry.

SPEECH.PARA: This stagnation is a direct result of this Government's policies. Let us be clear about that. It is not a by-product of other policies; it is not an oversight. It is a deliberate policy to downgrade housing in order to make room for an expansion of investment and foreign capital inflow into resources development for the sake of a few jobs in a few regions and big profits for a few companies. On the whole, those companies are foreign-owned. This was the message of the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Stone, in his Stan Kelly Memorial Lecture in November 1981. That line has been endorsed by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and it dominates the thrust of this Government's economic policies. It is a view which suggests that Australians are overhoused and a view which has led this Government to sacrifice the housing sector while the Treasurer, like Pontius Pilate, washes his hands of responsibility for the consequences and effects on the Australian people. Most Government supporters do not want to be seen to hold this position for it flies in the face of common sense. It runs against the expectations and aspirations of ordinary Australians. I stress, as I have stressed over and again, that we in the Australian Labor Party stand for private ownership of homes for individuals and wherever we can we will assist a worker to own his own home. We support that principle because the major saving of most workers in their lifetimes is the home in which they live. It is our aim , wherever we can, to get Australians to own their own homes.

We have seen the Minister for Housing and Construction go before Cabinet with his housing programs gimmicks which, in fact, have contravened the whole economic thrust and policies of the coalition Government. That has to be clearly understood. The sad situation is that he is given wide publicity by the newspapers every time he puts forward one of these gimmicks. They build up false hopes in many people in this country. However, on each occasion these proposals have been rejected or deferred by Cabinet. They are only cosmetic cover-ups, at best, and the Minister's submissions are not deserving of any real support. They are ad hoc, knee jerk, instant coffee responses to the wrong problems, such as more wasted money for the discredited Home Savings Grants Scheme. Within that industry it is called the home decorators' account because it gives too little too late to be used by people in meeting a deposit gap of something like $20,000 . People get the money nine months after they get their own loan. No wonder they call it the home decorators' account.

The housing sector is the building block of the nation's social structure and the nucleus of its industrial structure. Never before in Australia's history has a government shown so little regard for the social and economic importance of stable national investment, both private and public, in the housing sector. Never before have we seen members of the Federal Government so consistently attacked for their housing neglect by the Premiers and housing Ministers- including those who belong to their own parties-in every State. Only yesterday the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory issued a Press statement saying:
Unless there is a change of heart on the part of the Commonwealth, the average Australian's dream of owning his own home will soon cease to be a reality.
He went on to say:

The present Commonwealth housing policy, combined with excessively high interest rates is also causing considerable harm to the construction industry which relies on housing for a very large segment of its work.
Look at what happened in January when the Premier of Western Australia issued a booklet entitled the Fight for Fairness-I give it to the Minister to read-in which he stated:

We are concerned to show that home buyers, people seeking low-cost housing and the building industry are all suffering because of the Commonwealth's failure to take action to relieve the present situation.
The Western Australian Premier went on further to state:
Our intention is to highlight the low priority which the Federal Government is currently giving to housing.

Let us have a look at the Minister's old friend, the Victorian Minister of Housing. In September last year he said that the Federal Government did not deserve to stay in power if it did not increase funds for housing. In November he wrote an open letter to the Prime Minister calling for an urgent increase in housing funds for the States. In January this year he sent the Prime Minister a telegram saying that unless the Federal Government made urgent policy changes it would soon be too late to regenerate the housing industry. These are the remarks of National Country Party and Liberal Party Ministers who are leaders within their own States and regions. The fact is that I have not referred to any of the leaders of the Australian Labor Party States. I could mention what is happening in New South Wales where 40,000 families are waiting on the Housing Commission list, and the number is growing at a very fast rate. But I have not referred to that. I am just quoting the Minister's own colleagues, but why are they saying these things? It is because the shattering of the housing sector is causing widespread social and economic chaos within their States and regions.

Let us consider some of the economic effects of the issues involved such as falling loan approvals, falling building approvals, falling building commencements, builders and suppliers going to the wall, rising unemployment and the growing housing needs of the people. In 1977 the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry estimated that a feasible level of housing industry activity relative to capacity was 161,000 dwellings in 1979-80. In the 1980 report the Council estimated housing industry capacity for 1979-80 at only 142, 000 dwellings. It further projected the capacity for 1981-82 at 135,000 dwellings. These declining estimates reflect a downturn in housing industry capacity over the last four years of 26,000 dwellings or 16 per cent.

In Victoria the housing industry capacity estimates for 1981-82 are down 10,000 dwellings or 24 per cent on the estimates of four years ago. In that State particularly we have seen a substantial number of small and large home builders and suppliers go to the wall in recent years. Let us look at the more serious situation that is occurring in Victoria. The housing industry capacity in that State for 1981-82 is estimated at 32,000 dwellings. Activity in Victoria according to the November 1981 report of the Indicative Planning Council is estimated at only 26,000 dwellings. That means that the Victorian housing industry, which has already suffered a loss of capacity, will be operating at 19 per cent below capacity in 1981-82.

In Western Australia housing industry capacity is estimated at 20,000 dwellings in 1981-82 but activity is projected at only 15,500 dwellings. This year the Western Australian housing industry is operating at actually 23 per cent below capacity. Labor's condemnation of the Government is a basic one. At this time, with the unmet and growing housing needs of the Australian people, when the building industry has surplus capacity and a high level of unemployment, the housing sector, both private and public, is being squeezed when, in fact, the industry should be stimulated because this is a labour-intensive industry. It is an industry that can do a great deal of social good in our community.

Let us consider the economic impact of the squeeze. According to the Bureau of Industry Economics the value-added multiplier for the housing industry is 2.4. The employment multiplier is 2. That means that for every $100 output in the housing industry, production to the value of $240 is required from other parts of the economy. Australia's manufacturing industry supplies over 70 per cent of those goods. For every person employed in the housing industry two more are required throughout the Australian economy. For every $100m of private expenditure on dwellings, employment increases by 1,635 jobs for the home building industry and by 2,900 jobs in other parts of the economy. That is a total of 4,543 jobs. For every $100m of government expenditure on dwellings, employment increases by 1,884 jobs in the housing industry and by 3,351 jobs in the rest of the economy, a total of 5,235 jobs.

The message is straightforward and I want to give it to the Minister right between the eyes. If he wants to house the Australian population, if he wants a broad-based economic growth and if he wants stable employment growth, then build houses and provide stability in the housing industry; stable flows of housing funds and stable supplies of skilled workers are needed. On the other hand, if the housing sector is allowed to run down that brings on widespread disruption, unemployment, the closure of firms and far-reaching erosion of the manufacturing industry. Stagnation in the housing industry is a sign of a sick economy. Under this Government over the past six years we have seen the most stagnant housing industry in Australia's post-war history. If this Government's policies persist Australia will not have the capacity to make up the backlog of existing unmet housing needs. It will not have the capacity to address the housing needs of future generations.

Let us consider some of the reasons. In 1981-82 this Government is spending one -third of the amount on public housing that was spent by the Federal Government seven years ago. In 1974-75, the last full year of a Labor government, in today' s prices we made $789m available. This year the comparative figure is $225m. In other words, at the 1974-75 level there has been an underspending on public housing of $534m. We need a stimulus not only in public sector housing. We need also a program which will give first home buyers an opportunity to own their homes. We need a program that will protect those who are already living in and paying off a home but who, because of the increase in interest rates, are now in trouble. We need a building industry with a steady flow of finance, we need to stimulate the building industry so that it will not only create employment but also will give stability and security to many of the people who need it so much. We need a government with some compassion that will do something about the housing of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) indicated, in the closing stages of his speech, that he was going to give me something right between the eyes. He either missed the mark or his attempt did not have much strength to it. I assure him that in a very short time I shall demolish his argument of straw. I am very disappointed because, once again, he rose in this House, as he does with rather monotonous regularity, to announce the death of of the housing industry. That industry, in common with Mark Twain, could very well reply, 'The reports of my death are greatly exaggerated'. Like the Associated Press announcement of Mark Twain's death in 1897 the constant attempts of the honourable member for Reid to undermine confidence are the cause of distress and concern in the community. They are equally wrong and equally irresponsible, and if he were the man of concern, the man of compassion that I had thought he was up to the present, he would not have risen in this House and tried to destroy the confidence of the Australian people. Heaven forbid! The elderly, the unfortunate and the disabled should be spared from having that vote of non-confidence permeate their thinking as a result of these consistently irresponsible and wrong statements.

SPEECH.PARA: If we study the number of dwelling approvals we will see that in 1981, under this Government, they were at the highest level since 1973. This follows the commencement in 1980-81 of close to 150,000 dwellings. It is true that we do not expect the industry to repeat this feat in 1981-82, but the decline is nowhere near as bad as the honourable member, the disciple of gloom, would like us and the community to believe. My Department and the Housing Industry Associations would agree, I am sure, that there will be about 138,000 housing commencements in 1981-82.

I want to make my position quite clear. I am not happy about any drop in housing commencements. No member of this House feels more genuinely for the housing industry and the housing aspirations of the ordinary Australian than I do, but let us keep this forecast of 138,000 dwelling commencements in its proper perspective. It would be higher than for any year other than 1976-77 except, of course, for the outstanding performance of 150,000 commencements in 1980-81 under this government. Thank goodness this industry is more resilient than the honourable member for Reid would like us to believe. Thank goodness it has shown continuously its ability to adapt to change in market circumstances and to produce a product which matches the needs of the market.

For once, I agree with the honourable member that the cost and availability of housing finance is a worrying problem. It is an issue we are currently grappling with, but these are very important matters; we must get our decisions right. They must reflect a careful balancing of all of the economy's needs and the community's expectations.

Having said that, I point out that there are some encouraging signs. Lending by permanent building societies has recovered in each of the last two months to the level of early 1981. Obviously, the honourable member for Reid was too interested in coming up with his false propaganda to realise that today encouraging figures were released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in respect of savings and trading banks. They show that loans approved by them increased in December. I repeat: Loans approved by trading and savings banks increased in December. This, together with the improved lending performance to which I have already referred on the part of the permanent building societies, resulted in total lending by those societies and by banks combined that was significantly up in December. That is the sort of confidence that the honourable member should be talking about, rather than destroying the hopes and aspirations of Australians.

In December the number and value of loans for dwellings approved by savings banks rose by 8.6 per cent and 7 per cent respectively to 8,639 and $219.7m. The figures for trading banks rose by 1.3 per cent and 0.5 per cent respectively to 3,552 and $77.9m. The figures for savings banks and trading banks combined rose by 6.3 per cent and 5.2 per cent to 12,191 approvals and a grand total of $297. 6m loaned. The figures for banks and permanent building societies combined rose by 6 per cent and 5.3 per cent respectively to 16,838 approvals and $462.6m loaned.

If we take 1981 as a whole we find that the number of loans for dwellings approved by savings banks increased by 1.5 per cent to 109,917. Those are figures which reflect confidence. The honourable member for Reid did not give the House that sort of information because he wants to destroy the home ownership aspirations of the Australian people. We must not forget the fundamentals. A healthy housing industry depends on a healthy economy. It depends on income growth. Clearly, the honourable member does not even understand basic economics. The housing sector is sensitive to overall government economic policy. It needs an economic policy which maximises long-run economic growth, provides sustained demand through lifting real family incomes, maintains a healthy rate of population growth, ensures that young people can get jobs and consequently form households, keeps building costs within reason, promotes efficient finance markets, minimises inflation and price increases and assists a steady availability of housing finance. The very sort of investment that the honourable member attacks constantly is what is needed to provide this long term growth.

Let us look at some of the recent statistics. Gross domestic product increased at a rate of 3 per cent in the six months to September 1981, following a 3 per cent growth rate in the three months to March 1981. Private business growth fixed investment expanded strongly, at a rate of 22.2 per cent, in the six months to September. Non-dwelling construction investment increased at a rate of 31.5 per cent in that period. In the first half of 1981-82 the value of private non-residential approvals rose by nearly a quarter, compared with the same period in 1980-81. This has all been reflected in the incomes that families have been receiving. Real household disposable income-which is the pertinent thing-is estimated to have increased at a rate of 3.2 per cent in the six months to September-up from a rate of 2.5 per cent in the previous six months. Thus, we are improving the prospects for Australians.

Building material costs represent another area of importance to housing. Again, as comes from this side of the House all the time, we can announce more good news. In the 12 months to December 1981 the index rose by 9.2 per cent. This was significantly below the 14.5 per cent increase in the 12 months to December 1980 . Quite obviously we are good business and finance managers. I am not trying to say that everything in the economic garden is rosy. Obviously our economy is a very open economy. We are one of the world's great trading nations. We must be affected by the relatively lower economic performance of the other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. We must be affected in part , in regard to interest rates, by what happens in the United States.

However, labour costs represent another important area. I hope that the honourable member for Reid is listening because the people whom he represents are ripping the guts out of this country. The Housing Industry Associations organisation of Victoria has estimated that the cost of an average new house in that State will rise by $1,600 as a result of the newly-agreed tradesman's award . I repeat, the cost of housing will go up to $1,600. How are the young marrieds of Australia to bridge the deposit gap if they have to find an extra $1,600 because of union activities that are supported by the honourable member? I consider that to be a reasonable estimate of the flow-on effects of a 38-hour week. What would the farmers of this country do? They must laugh when they find out that carpenters are to work 38 hours a week. I suggest that in a lot of cases if they work for 38 hours it would not be quite as bad as what happens at present. I mention also an immediate $22 a week pay increase awarded to tradesmen. However, that does not take into account further pay rises granted under the new award due to be paid this month and in July.

Using the formula of the Housing Industry Association, I would expect that the new award would increase the price of a modest average home in Melbourne by about $2,500 rather than the $1,600 estimated by the industry. Therefore, if a modest first home in Sydney costs, say, $60,000, the new award, which the Opposition champions, can be expected to increase the price of a house in Sydney by $3,600 because of the insatiable greed of unions and the people they represent who are denying their fellow Australians the opportunity to have a job . That is one of the reasons that there has been a slight downturn in the activity in the building industry.

It is absolutely vital that we bear down on these rising labour costs, the sorts of extravagant rises that honourable members opposite would undoubtedly applaud and encourage if they were sitting on the Government benches. They are not interested in home ownership. They just want to talk about it. But the housing industry can remain confident that the Government will not abandon the fundamentals. The fundamental is to stick to policies which protect this country 's international competitiveness, which exercise some discipline over industrial chaos and preserve the incentive for personal effort and investment. Of course, as honourable members are aware, we are not a government which forgets the aspirations or needs of ordinary men and women, especially in this vital area of housing. The Government is very concerned about, and sympathetic towards, young home seekers, home buyers, pensioners who rent their dwellings, Aborigines and other special groups who are being helped through the Commonwealth-State housing agreement. We showed this by taking firm action in the 1980-81 Budget to lift our overall spending on housing and accommodation. I tell this to the honourable member for Reid because he will not go around this country quoting the true statistics. He tries to go back to what is obsolete. I tell him now that in the Budget we increased our total spending on housing and accommodation by the grand total of 18.9 per cent, from $555m to $660m. He should tell that to the people of Australia. He will not, because it is true.

As I pointed out to honourable members earlier today, the Government is reviewing the whole range of housing policies in conjunction with its examination of the recommendations on interest rates in the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. This review underlines our willingness to respond to changing circumstances. We have not yet finished considering the various assistance proposals. But housing responsibilities are not just a Commonwealth concern. The States and local government share this responsibility. I mention two areas of concern. Firstly, State and local governments bear a very heavy responsibility for housing costs. Statistics from the Australian Bureau of Statistics indicate that the cost of building an average 150 square metre private house in Sydney is around $44,000 compared with $36,000 in Melbourne. In New South Wales, under a Labor government , the cost of building a modest home of 150 square metres is $44,000 compared with a similar house in Melbourne at $36,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because they have more strikes in New South Wales.

—The honourable member is so right. In New South Wales there is no government concern and no government interest in Australian home ownership. They do not want people to own their own homes. A more modest 120 square metre home in Sydney would cost about $35,000 to build and in Melbourne less than $30,000.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I refer to conveyancing and stamp duty. In Sydney a first home buyer purchasing a house and land package costing $65,000 pays about $1,300 in stamp duty, the only concession being that this can be paid in five interest-free instalments over five years. In Melbourne a similar house and land package would cost about $40,000 and the stamp duty would not be $1,300 as in Sydney under Wran's Government; it would be only $800 under Lindsay Thompson's Government. For first home buyers who are eligible under the Commonwealth Homes Savings Grant Scheme that figure is reduced to $400. Therefore, Victoria is cheaper in the first instance and is halved if a buyer participates in the Homes Savings Grant Scheme. In New South Wales, under the Labor government, there is no such concession. It is out to destroy home ownership for the ordinary Australian. As I indicated to the House earlier today, Australia still has one of the highest rates of home ownership in the developing world. I note that the honourable member for Reid, in his opening comments, gave due significance to the fact that the home ownership rate had dropped slightly and marginally. That is true; I do not debate that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

It was predicted in the same statement that unless the Government moved quickly--
