PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I table the report of the Committee on Revitalisation of the Australian Shipping Industry. This Committee was chaired by Sir John Crawford, and the report has become known in the industry as the Crawford report. Only limited copies are presently available due to printing problems. Copies are available for reference in the Parliamentary Library and I will arrange for copies to be provided to honourable members as soon as they are printed. The shadow Minister, of course, has a copy.

SPEECH.PARA: For some time I have been concerned that Australia's involvement in overseas shipping has been dismal compared to the comparative efficiency and competitiveness of our export industries. Australia is an island continent almost totally dependent on shipping to move our exports and imports, yet in 1979-80 Australian flag vessels lifted a total of only 7 per cent of cargoes carried in all Australia's overseas liner trades, 9.4 per cent of import cargoes and 4.3 per cent of exports. In the bulk trades Australian flag vessels lifted 3 .24 per cent of exports and 1.84 per cent of imports. The coastal shipping trades are also not in favour because of claimed high costs and unreliability and have been overshadowed by road and rail transport.

I formed the view that Australia ought to secure a more substantial place in our overseas shipping and that there should be a clear choice between shipping and over-land transport in our domestic trades. Following discussions with the maritime industry, I announced, in an address to the Australian Chamber of Shipping on 28 May 1980, initiatives to revitalise the Australian shipping industry. At that time I stated that both the maritime unions and the shipowners had agreed to enter into negotiations to find mutually satisfactory solutions to the problems that were apparent at that time in the industry. Both the shipowners and the maritime unions had agreed to set up separate shipowner and union committees to examine the issues involved. It was also agreed by the unions and shipowners to establish a joint committee under an independent chairman to facilitate discussions between the parties.

Subsequently, on 14 June 1980 I was pleased to announce the appointment of Sir John Crawford as the independent chairman of the joint committee. The chairman's role, through the joint committee, was to assist in the evolution of practical proposals for the benefit of the shipping industry as a whole, having regard to the problems identified by the shipowners and union groups. I stated at the time that the committees would identify the problems facing the industry and then propose solutions, aimed at providing potential for some growth in the Australian shipping industry. By fostering agreement between the shipowners and the maritime unions, through the joint committee chaired by Sir John, I hope to achieve the development of an efficient Australian shipping industry which will be able to compete commercially. By 'commercially' I mean an industry that does not need to rely on measures such as cargo reservation for Australian ships and that does not impose additional costs to the exporter or an additional price to the consumer for our imports.

The task that Sir John undertook has now been completed, and I should like to express my appreciation to Sir John, and also to the shipowners and union officials who have worked so hard together to produce the report. The report provides an answer to the question 'why have an Australian shipping industry if other countries offer subsidised services to carry our goods' by pointing to the advantages to Australia of a commercially viable fleet. In brief these are: A small but real balance of payment gain; a growth in employment and a source of skilled personnel not merely for ships but for the off-shore exploration and development industry as well as for the operation of ports; the opportunity to improve the efficiency of coastal shipping by integrating coastal and overseas operations; the operation of Australian ships provides exporters with reliable information on freight costs which can be a significant marketing tool; and access to adequate shipping services in times of emergency. The report also has an important attachment, which should be noted by all exporters, dealing with the vexed question of c.i.f. and f.o.b. sales. The report suggest that exporters be encouraged to sell c.i.f. where commercially feasible.

The report contains a number of recommendations, which together provide a package, that Sir John considers has the potential to improve efficiency and enable orderly development and growth of Australia's shipping industry. I seek leave to incorporate the recommendations of Sir John Crawford in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

PROCTEXT.PARA: Summary of Recommendations
The recommendations are to be read as a total package. Serious shortfalls in any group would jeopardise revitalisation.
(1) Definition of an Australian Ship:
It is recommended that ships claiming the benefits of revitalisation should:
(a) fly the Australian flag;
(b) be manned by Australian crews;
(c) be registered under the appropriate Australian Act;
(d) be liable to tax on their operations;
(e) comply with relevant F.I.R.B. guidelines in relation to the shipowning company.
(Section II refers)
(2) Financial Incentives:
The Government should make the following changes to legislation as it affects Australian ships as defined above:

(a) for ships added to the fleet allow depreciation of over five years at 20% per annum with depreciation to commence in the year prior to commissioning provided the equivalent sum has been spent on the ship;
(b) abolish the 2% import duty on Australian ships;
(c) extend the investment allowance to all Australian ships regardless of the geographical pattern of operation.

(3) My recommendation here should not preclude consideration of the wider benefits requested by the Jenner Committee. In particular the depreciation allowance should not be fixed indefinitely but should be reviewed from time to time particularly if amendments are made to the investment allowance.
(Section II refers)
(4) Existing ships less than five years old should be eligible for financial benefits if the manning level is reviewed and agreed.
(Section II refers)
(5) Manpower Policy:
The industry (comprising shipowners, unions and Government) should develop a manpower policy the significant factors of which are:
(a) only ships manned in accordance with the decision of a manning committee be eligible for financial assistance;
(b) the safety manning initiative of the Department of Transport be abandoned;
(c) the manning committee be modified to provide a single committee to set the total manning of each vessel:
an officer of the Department of Transport to continue to chair the committee
a series of sub-committees be used if necessary to set numbers required in each category;
(d) the Launceston College be used as the core of a training program for officers and ratings with further Government financial support as necessary;
(e) the industry agree and implement an effective dispute settling procedure.
(Section IV refers)
(6) Access to Cargo:
The Government should commit itself to support an efficient Australian shipping industry and should:
(a) encourage exporters to sell c.i.f. where commercially feasible;
(b) not legislate for a fixed Australian share of our cargoes but

(c) make known its wish to increase the Australian flag share of our shipping and arrange Government to Government discussions on behalf of efficient Australian shipowners if entry cannot be arranged on a commercial basis.
(Section V refers)
(7) In addition there are a number of subjects where specific recommendations would be inappropriate but where continued dialogue between industry and Government is required:

(a) If Australian shipowners are to use the favourable shipbuilding credit available from foreign yards there is scope for owners, local financial institutions and Government to provide a solution to any foreign exchange risk problems which might arise.
(Section IV refers)
(b) A mechanism is needed to overcome industry problems with Department of Transport interpretations of international conventions as they arise.
(Section IV refers)
(c) Close and continuous liaison is needed between Government, exporters and shipowners over the commercial use of Australian ships in overseas trades.
(Section V refers)
(d) Further examination is needed of the problems of coastal liner shipping.
(Section VI refers)

(e) The Department of Transport should promote, on a continuing basis, greater interaction among the related groups within the Australian shipping industry on both technical and economic policy issues.
(Sectiom VI refers)

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr HUNT

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The recommendations of the report deal with the need to define an Australian ship, something made easier by the recent introduction by the Government of the Australian Register of Ships. The report recommends financial incentives for shipping through accelerated depreciation and an extension of the investment allowance to Australian ships operating overseas, these concessions only being made available to ships with an acceptable manning level. A further recommendation is the development by the industry, comprising shipowners, unions and government, of a manpower policy covering manning, training and a disputes settlement procedure.

INTERJECT.PARA: Following consideration of Sir John's report, the Government has agreed that I should hold discussions with shipowners, potential shipowners and the maritime unions to explore a package, generally along the lines of the recommendations of the report. Following these discussions I will then report the outcome to the Government. In the first instance, it is expected that this growth will occur primarily in the export of bulk commodities. Opportunities may also be available in other areas, and it is hoped that the benefits would flow into our coastal trades.

Honourable members will be aware of my recent announcement concerning the high costs to the nation of industrial disputes in sea transport. When measured in terms of days of disputes, almost half are attributable to the stevedoring industry but over one-third are attributable to ships' crews. Of those involving seagoing personnel, a substantial proportion were issues which find their basic motivation in job protection. I refer, of course, to disputes such as those designed to achieve higher manning levels or those involving bans on the so- called flag of convenience shipping. If there were opportunities for growth in maritime employment, much of the present pressures leading to such disputes would be removed. I believe the Crawford report provides this opportunity.

Revitalisation should enable us to enter a new era in maritime industrial relations through the prospect of growth in the industry and elimination of the disputes as to manning levels for vessels. I am confident that the challenge that Sir John has put forward will be met by both the shipowners and the maritime unions, and that we can look forward to a revitalisation of Australian shipping, where an efficient, reliable service can be offered on a commercially competitive basis. If this can be achieved it will be of considerable benefit to many Australians and the Australian nation. It is fitting indeed that the proposals which give the prospect of revitalising the shipping industry should have been brought forward by Sir John Crawford, who was recently recognised as Australian of the Year. I present the following paper:
Revitalisation of Australian Shipping-Ministerial statement, 18 February 1982.
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the statement by the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) on the reports of the Committee on Revitalisation of Australian Shipping. From time to time people ask me and, Mr Deputy Speaker, they probably ask you: 'Are there not any occasions on which the Opposition and the Government concur?' I reply: 'There are many, but those occasions are not newsworthy; it is the friction that is newsworthy'. But today is an occasion when there is substantial agreement on an issue that we see as vital to Australia's trade and employment opportunities. Although the Minister has not detailed the Government's attitude to the specific recommendations in the report it does appear that the Government has adopted the general thrust of the recommendations. The Government has, in effect, adopted Labor's long- standing policy for the expansion of Australia's maritime industry as, similarly , it adopted our policy in respect of an independent air-fares committee, and we commend the Government for that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition, maritime unions and shipping companies have repeatedly made the point that Australia, as a major trading nation is one of the least significant maritime nations with only about 3 per cent of its international trade being transported in Australian flag vessels. The Government, albeit belatedly, has recognised the substantial benefits to be gained from greater Australian participation in the sea carriage of its exports and imports. This Minister, to an extent like his National Country Party predecessor, has continued the negative union bashing policy, but to a lesser degree. However this Minister, to his credit, has realised that there is a role for an expanded Australian shipping fleet and that job insecurity has been a core problem in the disputes that have occurred in the shipping industry. The recommendations for provisions of accelerated depreciation allowances and the development of improved consultation disputes procedures and manning arrangements are a positive approach to the needs and problems of an industry whose effective performance is crucial to Australia's economy. However, from the Minister's statement today we should not raise false or overoptimistic expectations as to the future of the shipping industry.

In effect all that has been decided is that the Minister has been authorised to put the recommendations of the review to shipowners, potential shipowners and maritime unions as a package for agreement, with the emphasis being on 'as a package'. If agreement is reached on a package of conditions, then the Government will consider the terms of the agreement. The real test then for the Minister will be in taking that package back to the Cabinet and getting the support of Cabinet for the implementation of the terms of the package. I am confident at this stage, looking at the recommendations overall and in principle , that if the Minister brings back to the Cabinet a package that is substantially the same as that now before us he again will have the support of the Opposition for his endeavours.

Public understanding of the vexed question of crew levels of Australian ships has been confused by the distortion and misrepresentation engaged in over the years by supporters of this Government and its predecessors. Sir John Crawford confirms in the report that substantial progress has already been made in the reduction of crew levels. This problem has always been related to job insecurity . When men in the industry saw the number of jobs diminishing and the crew levels on ships declining, they worried about their future and they took action to try to preserve their future. But when they can see an industry with a hope, with room for expansion and with a level of certainty about it, then their attitudes like those of all other human beings can be quite different and they can look forward with confidence and security to their future. All parties accept at present that there is further scope for improvement in manning scales. In an expanding shipping industry with appropriate consultative procedures I have no doubt that further progress can be made. Fundamental to improvement in the shipping industry is the need for greater efficiency in the operation of the massive public and private investment in port facilities. Sir John has referred to this particularly in respect of coastal container shipping. This Government has been preoccupied, as I said earlier, with union bashing on the waterfront, but not this Minister so much in this area.

But what of other major causes of rising port costs that add to export and import prices and reduce Australia's overseas competitiveness, notably inefficient port organisation from the national perspective? Many ports lack competition amongst container terminal operators and amongst stevedoring operaors, leading to monopolised gains to shipping and terminal companies. This has led to port organisations supporting suppliers not users of shipping terminal services. Users are exporters, importers and all Australians. The present lack of Federal input in major port investments and planning leads to major customers of individual port authorities, such as shipping companies and terminal companies, exerting strong influence over port authorities and gaining concessions which do not benefit exporters or importers. Thus, suppliers of the services to a port benefit with the users of those services or the customers being a secondary consideration. In addition, competition between States to attract investment and trade has led to States offering to supply large companies with port infrastructure leading to overcapacity of port container facilities from a national perspective and in effect a waste of resources. Often solutions to port problems tend to focus on greater investment in facilities rather than a better utilisation and co-ordination and organisation of the infrastructure that is available in each of those ports. This again leads to a waste of scarce resources.

Let me for a few minutes turn to the problems of a specific port, the port of Newcastle, which has been coming into the national arena over recent weeks. In his usual style the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in recent weeks has sought to score cheap political points from the delays to shipping at Newcastle rather than to recognise and to face up to the issues and complex difficulties involved in seeking a viable solution to these difficulties and delays. Let me say that the nature of the global shipping industry is such that in the foreseeable future there will be a minimum queue of about 15 vessels off Newcastle. That is not something new. Honourable members may recall the disaster in 1974 when the Sygna went aground at Stockton beach in the electorate of Lyne at a time when there was a fleet waiting off Newcastle. That occurred at least eight years back. That is the nature of the industry. It is because of the positioning of the vessels which operate on global routes, from the timing as to when they reach port or are off port, and the simple fact that those vessels go on to the coal loaders at Newcastle in the order of their arrival off the port. So there is an incentive--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are defending the 40-odd ships off the coast.

—No. I am trying to approach this, not in the honourable member's manner, but in a constructive way in order to offer a solution to the problems so I would be grateful if the honourable member were to treat this subject in that manner. I will help the situation. Because the vessels go on to the coal loader in the order in which they arrive at the port there is an incentive to arrive early off the port. In April or May last year, during the 2 1/2-month United States coal mine strike, which my friend the honourable member for Lyne ( Mr Cowan) did not want to mention, vessels were diverted from the United States west coast-the coal trade-to the port of Newcastle and Port Kembla in the expectancy that they might pick up a spot cargo because cargoes were not available in the United States due to the coal strike. Other tramp vessels will arrive off those ports and get in the queue, again in the expectation of picking up cargo. So one should not think when one sees an armada off the coast that all those vessels have a cargo awaiting a turn. A number of factors are involved. The worst port of all is Hampton Roads in that home of free enterprise, the United States. It is off the east coast. There, 100 vessels are not uncommon. No coal port in the United States has a depth greater than the port of Newcastle. The deepest coal port in the United States is 45 feet. So let us get the whole matter into perspective and then see what we can do about it. What is important is that the transport of shipping of coal be so organised that the number of waiting vessels is minimised, and disruptions that would impede the smooth flow of coal through a port are avoided. The reasons for the recent increase in the number of ships waiting off Newcastle are several, I acknowledge, including the multiplicity of unions and a lack of national interest in improving this situation. The Federal Government has declined to play any effective role in the despoilage of the local seaside environment caused by the discharge of waste and oil from the waiting off-shore fleet. There are other local problems associated with this problem. The Minister and the Prime Minister have turned their backs on it. But in the circumstances and because as a nation we have to set about doing something to improving the flow of coal through our ports, to protect our export trades, to protect our industries and at the same time minimise delays, I advise the Government that later today I will be writing to the Premier of New South Wales, in the absence of initiative from this Federal Government and from the Prime Minister, requesting the New South Wales Government to initiate the establishment of a Newcastle port co-ordinating committee comprising representatives of the Federal and State Governments, local government, coal producers, shippers, exporters, coal loading interests, shipping companies, the port authorities, the relevant trade unions and the local fishing industry with the following aims:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. The efficient movement of coal through the port of Newcastle;
2. The minimisation of delays to ship movements and loading;
3. The avoidance of interference with the operation of the local fishing industry.

4. The prevention of pollution of coastal waters in the coastal environment by the dumping or discharge of inorganic and organic refuse, oily substances, sewage and packaging materials from vessels awaiting entry to the port;
5. The streamlining of quarantine procedures so as to enable:
(a) maximisation of local opportunities for on-ship and shoreside ship repair services;
(b) crews of waiting vessels to have greater access to port recreational facilities.

That last matter is there because there is a problem of morale and state of mind of the crews of those waiting vessels. I am confident that given support now from this Government and from the State Government that such a co-ordinating committee could make positive contributions to the solutions of the port's problems and of the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good idea.

—I thank the honourable member for Lilley. I have indicated to the House and to the Minister our general support for the recommendations of the review. We have attributed to him credit for the role and initiative he has taken in this matter, unlike his predecessor sitting behind him. On behalf of the Opposition I commend the members of the Committee-Sir John Crawford, seagoing unions and the shipowners-for their thorough work and enlightened recommendations on this very important subject. The shipping industry, unions and owners, have demonstrated that given the opportunity they can apply a mature and responsible approach to the industry's problems and come forward with positive solutions.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, it is with sadness that I note the death of Mr Len Schurr, convenor of the unions' committee until his untimely passing away during the committee's deliberations. He was a fine unionist and will be sadly missed. I am sure I speak on behalf of all honourable members of this Parliament in paying tribute to his valuable contribution to Australia and the trade union movement. Our sympathy goes to his family.
Debate (on motion by Mr Shipton) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered, for this session, standing order 101 be amended to read: '101. The House shall proceed each day with its ordinary business in the following routine: 1. Giving notices. 2. Questions without notice. 3. Presentation of papers. 4. Ministerial statements, by leave. 5. Matter of public importance. 6. Presentation of petitions. 7. Notices and orders of the day: Provided that on those alternate sitting Thursdays when ''Grievance debate'' is first order of the day, government business, under standing order 106 or when general business has precedence on the Notice Paper under standing order 104, '' Grievance debate'' or general business, as the case may be, shall precede ''5. Matter of public importance.''.'.

Honourable members will recall that on 15 November 1979 the House of Representatives Standing Orders Committee presented a report to this Parliament which included, amongst its recommendations, the changed routine of business specifically with respect to petitions. I do not want to go into a great deal of detail in summarising the reasons for the change, but it is worth commenting on some part of the Standing Orders Committee report. On page 1 it states:

The particulars of petitions lodged for presentation to the House are announced to the House by the Clerk in a long announcement which cites the Member lodging the petition, the identity of the petitioners and the subject matter of the petition. This results in a burdensome narrative which has little significance for Members gathering in the Chamber at the start of the day's proceedings.
In summary, the time taken by the Clerk's announcement is increasing at the expense of prime Parliamentary time.

Nothing in this, or in the change proposed, in any way lessens the significance of petitions. I know that many people in the Australian community regard the petition as a valid way by which they can address matters of concern to themselves, or groups of which they are members either to those responsible, or to this Parliament. It is also worth remembering that in our present procedures those petitions that fall within a Minister's bailiwick are in fact forwarded on to him. It is not just a matter of a petition being presented in the Parliament and being read here; it is a matter of that Minister having the capacity to respond if he sees fit. In that respect, I draw honourable member's attentin to Standing Order 132 which requires that a copy of every petition be sent by the Clerk to the appropriate Minister.

It is worth noting that in 1974 the House of Commons in the United Kingdom decided that it would alter the time for the presentation of petitions until immediately before the half-hour adjournment debate. Though such a late position in the program in the House of Representatives sitting is not suggested, it does seem to the Government that a suitable position would be after our dealing with matters of public importance. It is for that reason, and in accordance with the recommendations of the Standing Orders Committee, that I now propose this change in my name to the sessional order. I point out to honourable members that it has been introduced as a sessional order so that if the practice proves unsatisfactory modifications can be made to it. It will be the intention of the Government, subject to the sessional order proving to meet the convenience of the members of this House and enabling a satisfactory consideration of petitions , for an appropriate amendment be made to the Standing Orders in due course. I comend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition agrees with the motion. We think it is a sensible one. We note that petitions will still be important, that only the order in which they are introduced into the House will change. It is noticeable, particularly when we come back after a parliamentary recess, that petitions have accumulated and we are sitting listening to them for a period of up to half an hour or more. From the point of view of public interest and matters of interest to the nation it would be more appropriate if we got on with the business of the Parliament. According to the Notice Paper, the petitions would be read at a slightly later time of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that Ministers be made aware of matters in the petitions. That is to be commended. It is essential in democracy that we just do not have the whole of this place to ourselves. We want to hear the claims of people and petitions are one way of doing this. I know that people listen with interest to them being read, particularly when the proceedings are being broadcast, because they feel that the petitions are making some point in respect of what they are petitioning about. No matter which side we come from, all of us have a duty to present petitions. This certainly helps to form public opinion on matters of importance. I emphasise the fact that in no way are we degrading the strength of the petition by removing it from the first position to what now appears to be No . 6 in the order of business of the day. Accordingly, we have no objection to the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CANNED FRUITS MARKETING LEGISLATION REPEAL AND AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Nixon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes to amend and repeal existing legislation to allow for the termination of the operations of the Australian Canned Fruit Sales Promotion Committee and for the residual assets and liabilities of the Committee to vest with the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation. The Sales Promotion Committee was established in 1959 with the single function of promoting the sale of Australian canned deciduous fruit. As a matter of policy, the Committee has always restricted its promotional activities to the domestic market. The Committee's activities are funded from the proceeds of a charge on grower deliveries of fruit to canners collected under the Canning-Fruit Charge Act 1959.

Following the announcement of the decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions on 31 April 1981, I canvassed with grower and canner interests the desirability of rationalising the operations of the Committee within the existing broad marketing and general functions of the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation. This has been accepted, and the domestic promotion programs of the Committee were taken over by the Corporation as from 1 January 1982. I commend this Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Dr Blewett) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes increases to the rates of levy imposed on canned deciduous fruit production to finance the administrative operations of the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation. As from 1 January 1982, the operative rate of levy increases from the equivalent of 11c a basic carton-24 x 825 gram cans-to 27c a basic carton. Provision is also being made for future alteration of levy rates by regulation up to a maximum of 30c a basic carton. The new maximum and operative rates for various container sizes are set out in the Schedules to this Bill.

The increased levy rates have been recommended by the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation following its decision in November 1981 to reduce canned fruit production in the 1982 season to approximately one-half the level achieved last year. This decision was made necessary following the drastic downturn in export market outlets last year and the build up of unsold stocks to near record high levels. The Corporation's marketing plans for 1982 have been developed in close consultation with grower and canner interests and the reduction in production is seen by the bulk of the industry as the best response to the current oversupply problem. Significant marketing and promotional problems will continue to face the industry this year and the increased levy rates proposed by this Bill are essential if the Corporation is to have the resources necessary to deal effectively with these problems.

The Government is also giving urgent attention to the problems facing the industry. It agreed late last year to an urgent Industries Assistance Commission reference. The Commission is scheduled to report on the industry's short term assistance needs by 31 March. I have assured industry interests that the IAC report will be accorded urgent consideration by the Government. I commend the Bill to honourable members.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

The purpose of this Bill is to introduce, as from 1 July 1982, charges to recoup a proportion of the cost borne by the Commonwealth for inspecting dairy products for export. This is part of the Government's program to recover costs of providing export inspection for certain agricultural and fishery products. Export inspection is designed to ensure that products meet minimum standards of quality, hygiene and presentation when exported. The Government introduced charges for inspecting meat, grain and wool in 1979 and fish and dried fruits in 1981. These charges are aimed at recovering approximately 50 per cent of the inspection costs of the Commonwealth. The Government proposes that fees aimed at a similar level of recovery should be imposed for similar services provided by my Department for other products.

I turn to specifics in this Bill. Honourable members will see that it provides for the recovery of dairy product export inspection costs to be achieved through charges on dairy products inspected for export. The Bill provides that the person who furnishes an export notice for inspection purposes is liable to pay the charge. Exemptions may be provided in the regulations. A maximum rate of charge of $5 a tonne is specified. The actual rates of charge will be specified in regulations. It is proposed that the following rates for 1982-83 be recommended to the Governor-General for promulgation by regulation: Butter packed in bulk or pat form, $2.50 a tonne; butter packed in other forms and butter fat products, $1 a tonne; cheese packed in bulk, $2.50 a tonne; cheese packed in other forms, $1 a tonne; concentrated, condensed and dried milk, $0.50 a tonne; and milk and other milk products, $1 a tonne. On current estimates of export production for 1982-83, charges at these rates will yield approximately $ 307,000 in a full year. I commend the Bill to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to obtain parliamentary approval for Australia to take up increases in its capital subscriptions to two international financial institutions-the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Finance Corporation. Honourable members will be aware that the main function of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which was established in 1947, is to provide loans on semi-commercial terms to its less developed member countries. To the end of June 1981, the Bank had lent about $US68.2 billion to its member countries for projects covering all the major sectors of economic development with emphasis on the development of infrastructure facilities in the transport and communications, industry and energy sectors, as well as projects for agriculture, education and water supply.

Following an examination of the adequacy of the capital base of the Bank for its operations in the 1980s, the Governors of the IBRD approved in January 1980 an increase in the authorised capital stock of the IBRD of approximately $US40 billion. This represents an effective doubling of the Bank's capital base and should allow it to continue to increase its operations in real terms. The increase was covered by two resolutions, one approving a general capital increase and the other an additional capital increase. Under the latter resolution each member country is entitled to a fixed number of shares. It was passed to offset an unintended reduction in the aggregate voting power of developing countries, which would otherwise result from the general capital increase. Australia voted in favour of the resolutions authorising these capital increases. The text of the resolutions, including the number of shares to which each member is entitled to subscribe, is set out in the explanatory memorandum to this legislation. Members, including Australia, are entitled, but not obligated, to subscribe to this authorised increase. Australia is entitled to subscribe to 6,037 shares under the general capital increase and to 250 shares under the additional capital increase, a total of 6,287 shares, valued at $US758 .43m.

Under the general capital increase, 92.5 per cent of the subscription is to remain on call with the other 7.5 per cent-$US54.62m-to be paid in. Of the paid in portion, 10 per cent-$US5.46m-has to be in the form of gold or United States dollars and the balance of $US49.16m in Australian dollars. The latter amount-$ A44.95m at the current exchange rate-will be paid in the form of a promissory note. Subject to agreement with the Bank, this will be encashed in approximately equal instalments over four financial years commencing 1982-83. Under the additional capital increase, the full subscription price of the 250 shares remains on call. The IBRD is an effective and efficient institution in the provision of development assistance to developing countries, and it plays an important role in the South East Asian region. This has been recognised by Australian governments over the years since the Bank's establishment. I believe it to be in Australia's interest to continue this policy of support by taking up , in full, the increase in our capital subscription to which we are entitled under the two resolutions.

The International Finance Corporation, which was established in 1956 as an affiliate of the World Bank, is an international development institution established to promote the growth of productive private investment and to assist enterprises which will contribute to the economic development of its developing member countries. In addition to the direct financial assistance it provides, which may take the form of loan or equity investment, it also arranges for other investment finance, mainly from the private sector, to be made available. Up to the end of June 1981, the Corporation had invested about $US4.1 billion in nearly 600 ventures. The syndications it has arranged are an important measure of its ability to attract private financing for the projects in which it is involved.

In view of the need to ensure that the IFC had adequate resources to continue to expand its operations, the Governors of the Corporation approved a resolution in September 1977 authorising an increase in the IFC capital from $US110m to $ US650m. Australia voted in favour of the resolution. As in the case of the IBRD capital increase, member countries are entitled, but not obligated, to subscribe to additional shares. Australia is entitled under the resolution, the text of which is set out in the explanatory memorandum, to subscribe an additional 9,976 shares at a cost of $US9.976m, all of which would be paid in. Under the terms of that resolution all payments associated with additional subscription must be made by 1 August 1982.

The IFC has proved itself to be a very effective catalyst for attracting private capital for investment in enterprises in developing countries. As honourable members will be fully aware, this Government has continually emphasised the important role that the private sector can play in economic growth and development both in Australia and in developing countries. It is totally appropriate therefore for Australia to register its support for the Corporation and its activities by taking up its full share entitlement. I commend the Bill to honourable members.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981 to provide for:
(a) the payment in 1981-82 of additional tax sharing grants and special allocations totalling $69m to New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland; and

(b) the payment in 1981-82 of a fixed tax sharing grant of $315.1m to the Northern Territory in lieu of the amount which would be payable under the formula prescribed by section 8 of the principal Act.

At the Premiers Conference on 20 June 1981, at which the Commonwealth Grants Commission report on State tax sharing entitlements for 1981 was considered, it was decided that there would be no change in the relativities contained in the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981 in respect of the year 1981-82, and that the Commission should be asked to produce a further report on its assessment of States' relativities in the light of submissions to be put to it by States and by the Commonwealth. The Commission is expected to report by 31 May 1982.

In recognition of the likelihood that, following the further review, the State relativities would be adjusted in favour of the three most populous States, the Commonwealth agreed at the June 1981 Premiers Conference, to provide additional grants to New South Wales, $24.5m; Victoria, $15.0m; and Queensland, $20.5m in the current financial year. These additional grants are to be considered as being a part of whatever total contribution the Commonwealth may choose to make towards assisting States to adjust to whatever new relativities are adopted after consideration of the further report of the Grants Commission.

In this context, the Commonwealth made it clear that it has no intention of funding the total cost of the adjustments to whatever new relativities are decided and that the additional grants for 1981-82 are without prejudice to any future decisions about the degree of change in relativities or the pace at which any such change should be implemented. The additional grants for 1981-82 are on the basis that there will be no application by any State for special grants in respect of 1981-82.

As a result of an agreement between the Commonwealth and Queensland at the 20 June 1981 Premiers Conference the Bill also makes provision for that State to receive a supplement of $9m to its tax sharing grant payable in 1981-82. This special addition is a once-and-for-all payment to compensate that State for the reduction in its basic tax sharing grant resulting from the adoption of a new basis of estimating States' populations in the tax sharing calculation. The impact of this change-to an estimated resident population basis-on estimates of the States' tax sharing grants in 1981-82 was to produce a significant reduction in Queensland's grant as compared with estimates using the population estimates, prepared on the previous 1976 basis.

This Bill also gives effect to an agreement with the Northern Territory, arrived at subsequent to the June 1981 Premiers Conference, to pay the Territory in 1981-82 a fixed tax sharing grant of $315.1m rather than the lesser amount that would result from the formula set down in section 8 of the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981. This amount takes into account both the population increase in the Territory and the above mentioned change in the basis for estimating State and Territory populations to be implemented in March 1982. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the following table which contains the latest, that is Budget estimates of the tax sharing grants that would be payable to each State and the Northern Territory in 1981-82, including the amounts contained in this amendment Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (COAL EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Street, for Mr Moore, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Act 1975 to enact the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Proposals which I tabled in this House on 18 August 1981. The changes to the coal export duty, as proposed by this Bill, were foreshadowed by my colleague the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in the Budget Speech on that day. These changes impose, with effect from 8 p.m. on 18 August 1981, an export duty of $1 per tonne on black coal previously exempt from export duty.

The Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Act imposes a duty on exports of coking coal, at rates of either $3.50 per tonne or $1 per tonne depending on the quality of the coal and certain other features of the mining operation. Lower valued coals, principally steaming coal, had been exempted from this duty. Because of changes in the world market for energy resources and the consequential strengthening of export demand for steaming coal the Government decided that there was no longer any reason to differentiate between coking coal and steaming coal in the application of the export duty. I commend the Bill to honourable members.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS (PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 October 1981, on motion by Mr Street:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill we are about to debate is a Bill to amend the International Organizations (Privileges and Immunities) Act of 1963. The purpose of the Bill is to amend the parent Act to provide a contingency which was not foreseen when that Act was passed. It relates specifically to provisions which must be made for organisations such as the European Economic Community. The particular problem which has necessitated legislation at this time arises out of the establishment in Hobart of a secretariat to service the countries belonging to the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources. Under this Convention, negotiations on which were completed last year, the European Economic Community will now be entitled to participate along with the member states of the Antarctic Treaty. They will be participating in meetings relating to Antarctic marine living resources. It will therefore be necessary for them to send delegations and diplomatic representatives to meetings. As the host state, Australia has the obligation to extend to those delegations the same privileges which diplomatic envoys enjoy under the Vienna Convention. Similarly, the privileges and immunities enjoyed by the headquarters' organisation which services the Convention will also have to reflect this.

SPEECH.PARA: When the parent Act was passed in 1963 this was not foreseen. The Treaty of Rome, which established the European Economic Community, had come into operation , but we did not foresee in 1963 the establishment of what are called EEC missions in countries such as Australia or the sending of envoys to negotiate on behalf of the EEC in meetings.

The second amendment, which is set out in clause 6, will enable Australia to implement her taxation obligation under agreements establishing the Common Fund and the Asian Development Bank. This clause will exempt from taxation on income experts participating in the work of prescribed organisations. The Opposition agrees with the amendment, but would like to make some immediate observations as to what Australia's position is in respect of its international obligations and responsibilities. We note that this Bill will in that regard, particularly as a number of matters arise in relation to the EEC, for example, but we need a little detail as to what the Minister has defined as 'prescribed organisations'. We appreciate at some time information as to what he has in mind, other than perhaps the Asian Development Bank.

We also appluad the fact that a secretariat is to be established to service the countries that are parties to the Antarctic Convention. But on that note, let us emphasise the fact that what we are all about is the conservation of Antarctic marine living resources. We submit that we ought to be doing a little more than just ensuring that international public servants have a tax exempt status, because there are a number of essential matters which, when we come to the Antarctic, have a very high profile.

This particular area of the world, of which we claim a substantial part- admittedly, our claim is not recognised-has enormous potential and wealth. Other countries which have perhaps, more capacity than we do, are exploiting that wealth. Australians would be anxious that this Government-all Australian governments-should continue to take a very keen interest in the Antarctic, both for its preservation and effectively to indicate to the world that we have a stake there.

Let me mention some of the resources of the region. Nearly two-thirds of the world's fresh water is to be found in the polar ice cap. The largest coal field in the world runs along the Transantarctic Mountains, which are within the Australian sector. We seem to be in the position of perhaps jeopardising our own sovereignty, because I am told that one of the things that is likely to happen because of what are called fiscal stringencies, or the razor gang approach to this issue, is that we could well close one of our bases there-probably Casey, leaving only Mawson and Davis-simply because we do not have any funds. That is an indictment of any approach taken to safeguard Australia's interest in the Antarctic.

Let me make the point that there are four Soviet bases in our sector. If Casey were to close, half of our sector would be completely unoccupied by us, although the Soviet Union would have bases on it. I am not getting paranoid about the Soviet Union, as such, but it runs counter to any question of sovereignty if in our own territory we cannot service or own bases, and close them, yet other nations are establishing bases there.

It is worthy of note that last year 40 Soviet ships harvested some 2000,000 tons of krill-that small protein of marine life which the nations of the world are anxious to exploit. One wonders what is happening to us, it being recognised that krill contains 25 per cent of the world's protein requirements, we have no capacity at all to go there and harvest it. The Japanese also are there and are doing very well. That is to be applauded also. But what about our capacity to send ships there and do something from the point of view of Australia? India is about to set up a base there. That is an indication of the recognition by other countries of the value of the Antarctic.

The question is: What about Australia's plans? What about our having a ship of our own that can go to the Antarctic? At present we hire such a vessel. These vessels are heavily in demand by countries which are taking an increasing interest in the Antarctic. Are we to be left out? The ship that we have seems to be getting old and it will obviously be coming to the end of its life. We shall be left without any facility in that regard. We are becoming very dependent on United States flights for assistance. Again, the United States has been--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. With due respect to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, to refer to United States flights to the Antarctic and matters of a similar kind, as he has just been doing, is to draw a pretty long bow from the point of view of associating those remarks with this very specific piece of legislation. I suggest that the sort of comment that he is making might be very relevant in the context of a debate on Antarctica.
—I am not trying to delay the House. What I have said obviously hurts the Minister-not in any physical sense of course.
—It is not hurting me at all.

—Let us look at the matter: The whole concept of the Antarctic secretariat is preservation. Surely in that context, as Australia is claiming territorial rights, which, as I have said, are not recognised, I may make this point: What input could we have to these meetings if we could not even find out what was happening at our own base? How silly we shall look in Hobart at the secretariat if we are not able to participate in the discussions. That is the point I am making. Do not tell me, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the Minister will object to my pinpointing issues which every Australian will be anxious that we might promote at these meetings.
—I do not uphold the point of order, but I invite the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to consider the relationship of his remarks to the legislation.

—I think that that is right. The Minister is a worthy opponent of mine. He has objected to my mentioning the United States. I am only saying that it is apparently in the same position as Australia and is not prepared to devote the necessary resources either.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I may conclude, which will delight the Minister, on this note. The budget for Antarctica is only $18m, of which only 10 per cent goes into research . If we could only get a bit more money devoted to that, we could build up the scientific research which would give us so much greater input into the areas that we are about.
The Opposition has no objection to the Bill but we have every objection to Australia being just a country that stands on the sidelines and listens to everybody else debate our territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) raised a point on which he sought clarification, and I am happy to give it to him. It relates to that clause of the Bill which concerns the taxation obligation under two specific agreements, one being the Common Fund and the other being the agreement establishing the Asian Development Bank. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition asked whether there was any further intention on the part of the Government in this respect. I merely make the point that at present we are not a party to any other agreement under which a similar concession could be made, but it is conceibable that such a situation could arise in the future, and this legislation is designed to deal with it. If any further agreements are entered into, they would have to be prescribed by regulation which, of course, would have to be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and come before Parliament in the usual way.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Street) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 27 October 1981, on motion by Mr N.A. Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr N.A. BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: — May I, with the indulgence of the House, suggest that there be a general debate covering this Bill and the Domicile (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1981, as they are related. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—If there is no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the Domicile Bill and the Domicile (Consequential Amendments) Bill. The Bills are based on a model domicile Bill which was agreed to by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General , which consists of the Federal Attorney-General, the six State Attorneys- General and the Attorney-General for the Northern Territory. On 27 October last year the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown), who was at that time Acting Attorney-General, introduced the Bill into this House. He informed the House that similar legislation had been passed by the Northern Territory and all States except Western Australia, where at that stage the Bill had been introduced. I am advised that it has since been passed in that State.

SPEECH.PARA: The Domicile Bill introduces four reforms into the law of domicile. These reforms are not exactly new. They were first recommended by the British private introductional law committee report which was published in 1954. A Bill to give effect to these proposals was first introduced into the British Parliament in 1958. Objections to the legislation by foreign corporations-which the Treasurer (Mr Howard) never likes us to mention-and disputes between the House of Lords and the House of Commons resulted in the legislation to implement the reforms not being introduced and passed until 1973. One of the reforms is to abolish the common law rule whereby a woman who is married has at all times the domicile of her husband. This was perhaps the worst rule of the common law position on domicile. It treated women as secondary to their husbands until divorced. However, the form of amendment is a little difficult to understand.

The Bill simply states that the common law rule is abolished. It does not instruct the courts on how to ascertain the domicile of a married woman. It uses the expression 'at all times', that is, that a woman at all times used to have the same domicile as her husband. The question now is: At what time does she not ? Does there need to be a legal separation as distinct from a de facto separation before the woman can acquire her own domicile? In a country which is a federation such as Australia, this can be particularly important as one acquires a State domicile, rather than simply a country of domicile. From the Minister's second reading speech it would appear that what is intended is that a de facto separation, without any judicial proceedings, is sufficient. However, the courts may interpret it differently.

Much of the importance of the law of domicile has gone with the passing of the two Federal pieces of legislation governing family law. I refer to the Matrimonial Causes Act of 1959, which introduced the concept of Australian domicile, and the Family Law Act of 1975 which allowed 12 months' residence in Australia to be a sufficient basis for jurisdiction. However, there are matters, particularly under State law, which continue to be governed by the law of domicile. These are important matters relating to laws governing ex-nuptial children, adoption and certain matters relating to wills. While domicile is a principle of the British system of private international law, it is not the universal test for determining the status of a person. European countries, as well as Japan and Mexico, adopt nationality rather than domicile as the test for determining personal law. In 1968 it was estimated that about 1,450m people were subject to the law of domicile, about 1,600m were subject to the law of nationality and about 350m were citizens of countries which applied the principle of nationality to their subjects and that of domicile to foreigners.

One of the problems with the law of nationality is that it is inappropriate for federations such as the United States of America, Canada and Australia. For example, every State in Australia has legislation governing wills. The legislation varies from State to State. To adopt the test of nationality would make it impossible to determine which system of State law governed a particular will. Nevertheless, domicile has its problems. Firstly, it is riddled with technical rules which mean that the domicile of a person may be far removed from where that person lives. I cite as an example a person who may have left Italy at the age of eight, moved to New Zealand, then, say, at the age of 15 moved to Sydney and at the age of 18 then went to Victoria with the intention of residing permanently in any one of the three places but not having made any decision. He would be amazed to find that his domicile was still in Italy. This would be because he had no intention of residing in any one place and therefore his country of origin had been revived. For example, even if a person intended to live indefinitely in Australia but retained a lingering desire to die in Italy, his domicile might be determined to be in Italy, irrespective of the fact that he might be an Australian citizen.

Domicile was defined by Lord Cranworth in the case of Whicker v. Hume in 1858 as 'home, the permanent home, and if you do not understand your permanent home, I am afraid that no illustrations drawn from foreign writers will very much help you to it'. Unfortunately Lord Cranworth's definition does not help much either. Long term residence in a particular place may not be enough to establish domicile. The test is both of residence and intention. It is the way the courts determine intention that makes domicile such a difficult concept. This Bill will abolish some of the more ludicrous rules of the common law. Clause 7 abolishes the rule known as the 'revival of the domicile of origin'. This meant that a person who acquired a domicile different from that where he was born and then left that place without any intention to live indefinitely in another place was deemed by the law to have the domicile of the place where he was born.

Clause 10 of the Bill makes it clear that the necessary intention for a person is to make his or her home indefinitely, rather than permanently or perpetually, in a country. In Clause 4 country is defined as any State, province or other territory that is one of two or more territories that together form a country. Clause 11 defines that situation in which a person intends to live permanently, for example in Canada, but resides in Ontario until he is able to find a residence in Quebec. At that time that person is considered to have a domicile in Ontario because it is with Ontario that at that time he has the closest connection. That is an example of the situation.

The other reforms made by the Bill relate to children and the age of majority. Clause 8 specifies that a person can have an independent domicile at the age of 18 or on being married. Clause 9 of the Bill relates to the domicile of some children. As the Minister said in his second reading speech, at common law a child born of a married union acquired the domicile of his father while an ex- nuptial child acquired the domicile of his or her mother. The Bill provides that the child has the domicile of the parent with whom the child has his principal home. It makes the same provision for adopted children, with the added proviso that, if the child has only one adoptive parent, the child has the same domicile as that parent. If that parent dies, the child retains, until he or she can acquire a domicile of choice, the domicile of the deceased parent. Where an adoption is rescinded the domicile of the child becomes that of the natural parent or parents. In other words, it is assumed that the adoption never took place.

The Opposition supports this Bill. It is perhaps worth noting in passing that, just as special provisions need to be made for federations in relations to the law of domicile, so the pace of law reform in a federation is very slow. These reforms have come 30 years after they were first mooted in Britain. The passage of the Bill through this place has not been hasty. It has already passed through the Senate and we can see no reason to delay it further.

The other Bill which we are debating is the Domicile (Consequential Amendments) Bill. This Bill simply repeals sub-section 5 (4) of the Marriage Act of 1961 and sub-section 4 (3) of the Family Law Act of 1975. These two sub-sections relate to the domicile of married women, abandonment of a domicile of choice and the capacity of people over 18 years of age to have an independent domicile for the purposes of the Act. These matters are now covered in the Domicile Bill and therefore, the two sub-sections are no longer relevant. While, technically, matters relating to the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act are subject to a free vote, the Opposition has no objections to the amendments as they are consequential on the passing of the Domicile Bill, which we support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harris Mr G.McD.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Domicile Bill and the Domicile ( Consequential Amendments) Bill is to replace certain of the common law rules of domicile with statutory provisions which have been agreed upon by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, and to make consequential changes to the Marriage Act and the Family Law Act. Four important changes are made in this legislation. These changes relate to the abolition of the rule of dependent domicile of married women, the abolition of the rule of revival of domicile of orgin, the age of capacity to have an independent domicile, which is fixed at 18 years, and new rules for determining the domicile of certain children.

SPEECH.PARA: Domicile is not a concept generally understood. Lawyers aside, people usually are aware of it only when it appears to complicate some piece of litigation in which they are engaged. It can, nonetheless, have significant consequences for an individual's status. A person's domicile is a place the law regards as his permanent home. A number of matters affecting personal capacity, such as capacity to marry and to make a will, are determined accordingly to the law of the place in which a person is said to be domiciled. The question where a person is domiciled is now determined according to a number of complex common law rules . At birth a person acquires his father's domicile, if his parents are married, or his mother's domicile if his parents are not married.

Other rules relate to changes of domicile, for example, where a person moves from one jurisdiction to another. The common law rules do not take account of modern social attitudes relating to the rights of parties to a marriage or the custody of children, nor do they reflect the increasing mobility of individuals. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) has indicated, in a nation such as Australia which is a federation those complications can arise even if a person does not move outside the nation. The first change to which I wish to refer is that which abolishes the common law rule that a married woman has the same domicile as her husband. At present a woman acquires, upon marriage , the domicile of her husband and thereupon has no capacity to have an independent domicile. A wife continues to have the domicile of her husband throughtout the duration of a marriage, even if the spouses permanently separate and the husband acquires a domicile in a foreign country with which the wife has no connection. It is clearly no longer appropriate that a wife's domicile should automatically be the same as that of her husband. The common law rule is abolished by this Bill and a married woman will have an independent capacity to acquire a domicile of her own.

The second change is to abolish a common law rule known as the revival of the domicile of origin. This rule is complex and inconvenient and can have unexpected results for the individual whose status has become important in litigation. the Deputy Leader of the Opposition gave a number of examples of that just now. At the same time a new provision is introduced in clause 10 that states that the intention a person must have in order to acquire a domicile of choice in a country is the intention to make his or her home indefinitely in that country. There have, until now, been problems at common law in establishing the acquisition of domicile of choice. One hopes that this provision will make this easier. In particular, problems can arise in a country such as Australia which comprises a number of States and Territories. A person may come to Australia with the intention to settle permanently but because he moves between States he may be domiciled in Australia for the purposes of Commonwealth law but not have sufficient connection with any particular State to acquire a domicile of choice in any State for the purposes of State law. Clause 11 of the Bill deals with this situation by providing that a person who is domiciled in a union but is not domiciled in any particular part of that union is to be domiciled in that part of the union with which he has for the time being the closest connection.

The third change made by the Bill relates to the age at which a person is capable of having an independent domicile. Clause 8 provides that a person is capable of having an independent domicile if he has attained the age of 18 years or he is or has at any time been married. This change recognises the contemporary view of the age of majority which is already incorporated in other legislation. The Bill includes a number of changes related to children. Under common law, a child born in wedlock acquires the domicile of his father; an illegitimate child acquires the domicile of his mother. In a situation where the parents have separated it would be quite possible under common law to find the child living with the parent other than the parent whose domicile he has acquired. This Bill makes the sensible provision that in such circumstances the child has the domicile of the parent with whom he has his principal home. I am aware of some custody orders which have been made in recent years which give children equal time in both parents' homes alternately. I hope I never have to be a participant in a case which decides the domicile of the child. The Bill also makes provision for the case of adopted children.

The enactment by the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory of the model domicile legislation will rationalise and modernise the rules of domicile. The Attorneys-General are to be commended for acting together to reform a complex area of law. I support the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr N.A. Brown) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 27 October 1981, on motion by Mr N.A. Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion of Mr N.A. Brown) read a third time.
