That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Bill. I think it is appropriate that it be debated at this time because the dried fruit industry along the Murray Valley is presently picking one of its best ever crops. Many thousands of pickers are involved in the production of this harvest and it is expected that the yield will be well above any previous production figures. I am told that the currant crop will yield some 7,200 dried tonnes. Last year this crop yielded only 4,000 tonnes. The sultana crop is likely to reach some 75,000 dried tonnes, being the equivalent of about 300,000 tonnes of fresh grapes. The entire crop being produced this year throughout the Sunraysia and mid-Murray areas of my electorate and on the other side of the river in New South Wales is estimated to yield $90m, and 50,000 tonnes of dried fruit are expected to be exported.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that this large crop is presently being picked, I believe it is important and significant that this legislation is now before the Federal Parliament. The Bill that we are debating seeks to provide an underwriting arrangement to support, if necessary, returns to the producers of dried sultana grapes in the 1982 to 1986 seasons. The arrangement before us at the present time in acceptable to the dried fruits industry. It is in fact at the industry's request . I emphasise that the legislation applies only to dried sultanas, which presently accounts for some 85 per cent of the dried fruit production. The House would be aware that previous stabilisation schemes for dried fruits have been in existence for most seasons since 1964. The latest arrangements, which applied to sultanas in the 1978 to 1980 seasons, was terminated at the industry's request in 1980 when it became evident that very favourable export prices in those seasons had made government support unnecessary. We are also aware that export prices for dried vine fruits are volatile. Any major crop failure, such as the one we saw in the United States of America in 1979 which triggered off large rises in world prices, can occur at any time. On the other hand, abundant supplies can rapidly develop, leading to keen price competition.

World production in 1980-81 was relatively high and prospects for further big crops for the second year in several major producing countries during the current Northern Hemisphere autumn have already brought about reductions in world prices. In Australia our home market absorbs one-third of our production of dried sultanas. However, the dried fruit industry and the Government are concerned that the income position of Australian producers is vulnerable, particularly if an abrupt worsening of conditions on world markets occurs. I shall return to this problem shortly, particularly in respect of volatile production and trading conditions in other countries. The Government has therefore decided in this legislation to implement an underwriting arrangement to provide a measure of security for producers against sudden large falls in world prices. The scheme that we are legislating for will provide security for producers but, I emphasise, it will not insulate them from market price signals which might be indicating that fundamental changes should be made to the structure of production and trade.

As the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) indicates, the underwriting arrangement is based on the Government guaranteeing minimum returns per tonne for production in the 1982, 1983 and 1984 seasons which will be equal to 90 per cent of the average of net returns per tonne to packers in the preceding two seasons and the estimated net return for the current season. In the 1985 and 1986 seasons the guaranteed minimum return will be 95 per cent of the three-year average net return. If the net return for a season is less than the guaranteed level or underwriting payment equal to the difference would be made in respect of the total production in that season. The provision for the guaranteed minimum return to be set at 90 per cent in the first three seasons reflects the satisfactory export prices which the industry has enjoyed in recent seasons. If one travels through the grape growing areas of the Murray Valley one will see that these higher prices have been reflected in the obvious improvement that has taken place in recent years in personal lifestyles, and this is something that I think has been warranted for many years . As I have said, the determination of the three-year average return requires an estimate to be made of the average return requires an estimate to be made of the average return for the current season. This will be determined by the Minister after consideration of advice and information provided by the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. The administration of the underwriting scheme is to be vested in the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation.

I return to the very real concern that the dried fruit industry has about, particularly, the influences of the European Economic Community in the world trading scene. We are all aware that, prior to the Common Agricultural Policy, Australia secured and held European markets-mainly but not solely in Great Britain-for its farm products on the basis of price and quality considerations. However, the progressive exclusion of Australian farm products from the Community as a direct consequence of the policy of Community preference is only one aspect of Australia's concern. Perhaps I could give some examples of the rundown in trade that has occurred between Australia and the EEC over the last few years. In 1958-59 Australia exported 71 per cent of its beef and veal to the EEC. In 1979-80 it exported only 2 per cent. In 1958-59 Australia exported 69 per cent of its dairy and egg products to the EEC. Now it exports none. Australia exported 48 per cent of its sugar to the EEC in 1958-59 but now it exports none. In 1958-59 it exported 48 per cent of its wheat to the EEC but now it exports none.

The effect of the loss of these markets on Australia is very real. Industries for which no alternative markets can be developed have had to scale down production. This inevitably has led to a reduction in the numbers engaged in affected industries with consequent adverse effects on towns and regions. In the past decade the number of dairy farms in Australia has declined by 54 per cent. Peach and pear production has declined by one-third, apple production by over 20 per cent and the number of beef producers by 30 per cent. If this adjustment to change had been substantially shared by both the Community and third countries and real restraint had been exercised on the part of the Community in terms of support prices, self-sufficiency ratios, import levies and export restitutions and exports, a degree of fairness and equity might have been achieved and the needs of world trade advanced. That this has not happened is a matter of great concern to Australia. Indeed, the situation worsens each year and the gulf between the Community and Third World countries deepens. In short, the continual rise in Common Agricultural Policy support prices has called forth ever increasing production across the whole range of temperate zone commodities. Since its inception in 1962, the CAP has acted to displace Australian farm products first from continental Europe, then from the United Kingdom and now, with further enlargement, from the few remaining markets. As well it has begun to invade third markets.

Against this background of the loss of traditional markets described above, of even greater concern and complaint is the emergence of the Community as an agricultural exporter of major proportions on the basis of subsidised export disposal. This is the result of excessively high producer supports, unrestrained production, high domestic food prices and extensive intervention in foreign trade. As a consequence of European integration Australia has been forced to develop entirely new agricultural markets in the Middle East and in East and South East Asia. These markets are now also threatened by subsidised exports from the Community. The CAP has been massively successful in generating production but highly unsuccessful in achieving expanded levels of consumption of such production in the Community. As a result, massive surpluses have been disposed of on world markets. Nowhere has this been of more importance or significance than the effect of the EEC in relation to the dried fruit industry. It is in this area that the dried fruit industry is extremely concerned.

Today the EEC is the largest export market for Australian sultana production with some 30 per cent being exported to it. The EEC is also the largest world importer of sultanas, taking 55 per cent of total world imports. Exports to the EEC have traditionally accounted for about 46 per cent of total exports of the Australian crop. These, of course, have gone mostly to the United Kingdom and more recently to the Federal Republic of Germany. Exports of sultanas to the EEC in 1979 totalled some 10,000 tonnes at a value of about $A11m. In 1980 they totalled some 32,000 tonnes with value of $A40m. On the basis of the very low self-sufficiency in the Community, dried vine fruits was one of the few commodities in respect of which Australia's traditional United Kingdom-Europe trade remained relatively unaffected by the CAP regime. However, the entry of Greece into the EEC in 1981 has changed this outlook substantially. Greece has traditionally been a major world producer and supplier to the EEC of dried vine fruit. However, following the accession by Greece to the EEC, an EEC system of production aids for dried vine fruit was implemented in August 1981. This was designed to permit growers to compete with Third World suppliers to the EEC but it also effectively guarantees high returns to their growers. In essence the regime consists of a subsidy to producers-a subsidy for storage, compensation for losses incurred in storage and subsidised sales by tender for storage agencies where the market situation so requires. The processing subsidy is calculated as the difference between total processor costs and the frontier price of Third country imports. Current low prices on world markets and for imports into the EEC are presently inhibiting purchases of Greek fruit by processors with the result that most of the 1981 Greek crop has been put into storage. It is also alleged that processing at current prices would be unprofitable because of the generous minimum prices paid to growers. Attempts have been made to sell fruit by tender from storage agencies but few sales of Greek fruit have been made because of the high reserve prices set by the EEC Commission. Under the tender system that exists the difference between the tender price and the minimum price would be funded from that fund that backs the Common Agricultural Policy.

I am concerned and the industry is concerned about these circumstances for three main reasons. Firstly, the dried vine fruit regime is an unreasonable concession to Greece. Secondly, the regime may be the forerunner of more direct restrictions on imports of dried vine fruit from Third country suppliers. In this regard there has been a recent reduction in access under the annual concessionary quota for dried vine fruit and an increase in the operative tariff . Thirdly, there must also be a concern that if prices for dried vine fruit remain at depressed levels into this year's marketing season, returns to Australian producers will be significantly reduced. Whilst Greece has traditionally produced a substantial quantity of sultanas it has been claimed by Greek producers that the scope for this to increase is limited and that as a consequence increased returns to producers will not result in greater production in competition from Greek exporter in the EEC markets. However, I believe that these claims are based on some assumptions which may no be valid. Firstly, the primary restraint on increased production is assumed to be the limited land area available. This, however, does not take account of the potential in Greece to increase productivity yield within existing producing areas and also ignores the potential for additional plantings in areas currently occupied by alternative crops. It also ignores the fact that Greece may encourage increased production through the availability of subsidies which would allow the EEC to become more self-sufficient and the future import market would therefore decline. This, of course, would lead in time to increased competition in other Third World markets .

The Australian Government is making repeated representations to the EEC Commission both in Canberra and Brussels and it was making these representations three years before the new regime was finalised. These representations have been maintained since that time. the Australian Government has urged restraint in setting the levels of dried vine fruit production aids because it foresaw the likelihood that these subsidies would depress prices in the EEC and new production would be encouraged in Greece. The Commission, however, has discounted our concerns and maintained that the support measures for dried vine fruit were unlikely to harm Australian exporters.

Since August 1981 at every indication that Australia's fears of the effects of the dried vine fruit subsidies were justified the Government at both ministerial and official level has made representations to the EEC. Throughout this period I am aware that the Department of Trade and Resources through the Department of Primary Industry has consulted the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation with a view to ensuring that the Australian industry is fully consulted on all developments including the various actions taken with the EEC. To date, however, our representations have not resulted in any modification of the dried vine fruit subsidies. The Government, in closer consultation with the Australian industry, is now examining its options including possible action under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The United States of America, another major exporter of dried vine fruit to the EEC, has also failed to secure assurances from the Commission officials that the effect of the dried vine fruit subsidies will be moderated and has recently taken a decision also to seek consultation with the EEC under GATT. The Australian Government is presently liaising with the United States on these consultations. The object is to achieve order in the trading situation and to maintain full access for Australian fruit to the EEC market.

I support this Bill. I believe it does show that our Government is prepared to make arrangements to provide stability for the future of the dried fruit industry extending over the 1982 season into the 1986 season. I hope that in that time some moderation of the Common Agricultural Policy will take place allowing the Australian dried fruit industry to have the same access to the European market that it has had in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) has given the House a very thorough outline of the mechanics of the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Bill. Of course we are all aware that his electorate is the one that produces more dried vine fruit than any other in Australia. His comments ranged very widely over the Common Agricultural Policy of the European Economic Community and any commodity that is so possibly affected by that Policy also needs to be discussed at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not oppose this Bill and we indicated this when we did not oppose the Dried Vine Fruit Stabilization Legislation Repeal Bill 1981 which was debated nearly a year ago on 5 March. At that time the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) said that an underwriting scheme would be introduced. But even over a year ago the Minister and his officials were in discussion with the Australian Dried Fruits Association as to the level of the underwriting and whilst the industry has suffered no disadvantage from the delay, the lapse of time is typical of procrastination by this Government and the Minister when it comes to rural issues generally and the welfare of Australia's primary industries. Quite apart from the fact there has been economic bungling on the part of the Government such as the level of interest rates which have a particular impact on our primary industries and quite apart from the fact that the Government has allowed to persist an overvalued currency disadvantaging rural exporters, the Government will take no positive action to help specific industries. The industry in most trouble at present is the beef industry and the Government will do nothing about it.

The negotiations with the Association took so long because the Government was insisting that domestic prices be related to export prices. Given the fluctuation in price on world markets, the industry's case was understandable and supportable. While the Minister's second reading speech does not acknowledge the success of the industry, in putting its case, he at least alludes to it when he said that prices in the domestic market should be maintained but that rises in price will be moderate. While the industry now accepts the provisions of the Bill, it still has some reservations about the level of underwriting, particularly at a time when inflation caused by the Fraser-Howard Government's policies is still rampant. The 90 per cent level of underwriting, related to the average net returns per tonne to packers in the preceding two seasons and the estimated net return for the current season, when taken into account with the level of inflation could give a real price per tonne for sultanas-working from two years back-of only between $850 and $900 a tonne. This is an unprofitable level-a level at which most growers would go broke. Previously the Association has administered stabilisation and equalisation arrangements and all negotiations with the industry have sensibly been between the Government and the Association. The Australian Dried Fruits Corporation now has the powers of administering the equalisation arrangement and while it was essential for the Association-that is the growers-to have been fully involved in the negotiations we are now talking about, I find it hard to understand why the Corporation was not also involved in the negotiations too, particularly when the Corporation will administer the new underwriting arrangement from now on.

Prior to Greece's accession to the EEC the organisation of the international market between the northern and southern hemisphere producing countries had been by informal agreements. Australia has often taken the initiative in trying to get some sort of order into the trade. Supply and demand have always been taken into account. In the past two years prices have been firm but there was a slight shortfall in production. This situation has now changed and the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) has referred to this. The northern hemisphere has had excellent crops and Greece's usual crop of some 65,000 tonnes of sultanas is up to 100,000 tonnes. So export prices are going down and the Greek crop is now in the hands of the Brussels Commissioners.

Australia's primary producers rightfully are concerned by EEC policies in a range of agricultural and pastoral products. While the EEC follows policies that the National Country Party would like to see applied here for our domestic industries, it has no choice but to protest strongly at the effects of the decisions on more efficient exporting industries and exporting countries such as Australia. The Opposition joins with the Government in making as strong a case as possible that EEC policies, which result in surpluses that have to be dumped and take third markets off us and result in generally inefficient agriculture in the EEC, are not in the long term interests of the people in the EEC who have to pay the taxes to support this unprofitable production when it is often producing products that could be more cheaply bought on the free international markets.

The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and I were in London some two weeks ago and we again made Australia's case known in the strongest terms possible to the British Government. For the reasons I have already stated, export prices bear little relation to the cost of production. Quite apart from the slight over -supply situation at present, one of the key factors determining the price from now on will be the price set by the Brussels Commissioners for the Greek crop. Since 1978 prices for the Australian crop have ranged from between $A1,090 to $ A1,650 per tonne. The $A1,650 Australian price gave Australian growers returns in excess of $A1,000 per tonne for the first time. This represented a doubling of the price of some five years before. The 1981 crop was sold, or is being sold , for prices below this and the current price on offer is about $A1,375 per tonne, which equals about $US1,600 a tonne c.i.f. cost, insurance and freight. I give these figures to show that if, as is rumoured, the EEC sets a price equivalent to $A1,250, c.i.f., there will be a downward pressure on Australian prices for the coming season's crop which is now estimated to be something like 65,000 tonnes of sultanas, most of which is predicted to be high quality three, four and five crown. It is estimated that the price which will trigger the underwriting mechanism is about $A1,000 a tonne. I think we can believe that this level will not be reached. Australia and South Africa in setting southern hemisphere prices next month should not go below $US1,550 as world stocks are not all that high and the previous informal arrangements need to be persisted with so that Greece's accession to the EEC does not distort the world price for sultanas to an unrealistic degree. To back up that statement, I advise the House of a telex from the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation. This was repeated by Mr Sutterby, President of the Federal Council of Australian Dried Fruits Association, to the recent Bureau of Agricultural Economics Outlook Conference. A telex was sent to Greece, Turkey, Iran, Afghanistan, South Africa and the United States of America for information. It states:

The Australian Dried Fruits Corporation is extremely concerned at the very low prices particularly those emanating from Turkish exporters now being offered in world markets for 1981 season's sultanas. We are well aware of the very favourable benefits received recently from the European Commission by the dried fruits industry in Greece particularly the sultana and currant growers and while we may continue to express our disapproval at those developments our immediate problem is to stop the run on export prices.

We maintain that there are no justifiable reasons for the present low prices- world stocks are not large and as you know world export trade in sultanas/ raisins is around 350,000 annually. We must maintain that business.

World markets will not react in a positive manner when prices are low and falling and this approach to your organisation is being made in the sincere hope the present attitude of selling at prices not in accordance with the proper market indicators will be reversed.
We all owe it to our producers and respective countries to obtain the best possible returns and so limit as far as we possibly can the call on our governments for financial assistance.

During the four years from 1977 to 1980 dried fruit producers throughout the world had no need for any recourse to governments for assistance. We in Australia fail to understand why sultana producing countries should subsidise the dried fruit trades in importing countries. If there is any thought that the present low prices will be passed on for the benefit of the consumer we should think again.
Over the past 12 months sultana prices in world export trade have fallen by 30 to 40 per cent.

We fear that what may happen will be a repetition of the early 1960s when prices dropped from 150 pounds sterling to 78 pounds sterling. It was only then that sultana producing countries through the intervention of their governments stopped the run on prices and decided that Australia, Greece and Turkey should talk together.
We do not need government intervention now or any other time on a matter well within the capabilities of the dried fruit industries in Australia, Greece, Turkey and others to correct.

I quote this telex because it sets out very clearly the Dried Fruits Corporation 's case, the case of the Australian growers and the need, as I have emphasised, for informal arrangements to prevail in the sultana market. I am sure all Government members and all Opposition members are very much aware that if Brussels sets a price so high that surplus production is encouraged, this would be worse in the long term than if too low a price were set in the first place.

The measure before the House only cushions Australian producers from an abrupt worsening of market conditions. While we are in a position of some uncertainty at present both in price and by way of diversion, one would hope that if conditions do change for the worse and if the underwriting is shown to be inadequate, the Government will respond with alacrity to allow the industry to survive in the short term or to adjust in the long term. Underwriting is a more economically rational way of dealing with government support for primary industries. This measure is now common to other industries, such as the wheat industry and dairying. The Opposition supports the Bill but, once again, wishes to emphasise that the Government needs to be more sensitive to the industry's needs at this time and for the rest of this season than it is to the plight of some of Australia's other primary industries. We support the measures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a contribution to this important debate on the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Bill. There is no doubt whatsoever that the dried vine fruits industry is a significant industry in the context of Australian primary production. It is widespread throughout the Murray Valley area. It is an industry on which thousands of families depend. It is an industry which, unlike a lot of other industries in this country, is highly decentralised . Not only are a lot of people directly involved in growing the product and what have you but also a lot of people are employed in and otherwise involved in processing and packing-the general secondary phase of the industry. This legislation is important to that industry. Obviously we on the Government side of the House support it. However, the Australian Labor Party seems to lack interest in this matter and is not playing much of a part in debate on it.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bill is to provide underwriting, to provide support, if it becomes necessary, for the returns of producers in the dried sultana grapes industry in the seasons from 1982 to 1986. Such an arrangement was requested by the industry and is acceptable to it. It will apply only to sultanas, which account for about 85 per cent of the production of dried vine fruits. One of the difficulties the industry is facing is that threats are being made by the European Economics Community, largely as a result of the accession of Greece to the European Economic Community and the fact that Greece now takes its place in the arrangements known as the Common Agricultural Policy. I think it is fairly well known in this chamber and in this country generally that Europe has traditionally been a large buyer of Australian sultanas. We as a nation have exported quite significant tonnages of sultanas to the European Economic Community in recent years. For instance, in 1980 we exported 32,000 tonnes of sultanas. Since 1975, the tonnage has varied between about 11,000 and 32,000 tonnes.

The dried vine fruits industry, particularly that part involving sultanas, is one of the industries which survived the arrangements made on the formation of the European Economic Community and the introduction of the Common Agricultural Policy. That was largely because there was not in the European Economic Community a country with a significant industry of that nature; therefore there was no competition for the Australian product. Traditionally about 30 per cent of our sultana production has been exported to Europe. However, the entry of Greece into the Common Market last year changed quite significantly the situation in relation to dried vine fruits. Greece is a dried vine fruits producer and was a supplier of dried vine fruits to the Common Market before its entry. However, now that it is a member of the Common Market and has been able to seek arrangements to protect its producers under the Common Agricultural Policy, it is quite likely that support which has been or may be granted to Greek producers and processors will disrupt the Australian producers' market in the European Economic Community.

I shall talk a little of the background of the Common Agricultural Policy because I think it is important that this House and Australians generally understand to a far greater extent than perhaps they do the basis of the Common Agricultural Policy and why it has the effect it has on Australia. It was introduced in 1962 and developed out of the original Treaty of Rome. Article 39 of the Treaty of Rome defines the five fundamental objectives assigned to the Common Agricultural Policy as follows:

to increase productivity by promoting technical progress and by assuring the rational development of agricultural production and the optimum utilisation of the factors of production, in particular labour;
to ensure a fair standard of living for the agricultural community;
to stabilise markets;
to assure the availability of supplies; and
to ensure that supplies reach consumers at reasonable prices.

To meet the above objectives various markets for farm produce have been progressively organised, based on three fundamental principles, namely, the single market, community preference and joint financial responsibility. Single market implies total trade liberalisation between the member countries, therefore the removal of customs duties and non-tariff barriers between the member countries. Community preference is the indispensable corollary of the single market. Protection for the European market against low priced imports is provided by Customs duty at Community frontiers.

Levies dissuade the outflow of Community products to higher priced markets outside the EEC insofar as it is necessary to guarantee supplies to European consumers. That is a fairly important rider 'insofar as it is necessary to guarantee supplies to European consumers'. As the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) who is sitting at the table, his colleague, the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony), and particularly those of us who are members of the National Country Party are well aware, the reality is it is with those commodities in which there are surpluses which are sought to be exported that so much difficulty and disruption has been caused to Australian trade. Joint financial responsibility arises logically from the two preceding principles and is embodied in the European Agricultural Guidance and Guarantee Fund, which is an integral part of the Community budget.

The European Economic Community has a limited source of revenue. Largely it comes from Customs revenue. My latest figures indicate that of the order of 75 per cent of the EEC budget is spent on the Common Agricultural Policy, not only on paying subsidies to the producers of various agricultural commodities within Europe but also in providing export subsidies to enable produce to be sold outside the Common Market boundaries. That I would think is a unique situation. I am sure that if we could arrange such a situation for the farming community in Australia everyone in that community would regard it as an outstanding achievement. It creates a double whammy effect. Not only is assistance given to the producer to produce a commodity, but also if that commodity, having been produced with assistance from government, in effect, cannot be sold because its price is too high, a further subsidy is applied to help it to be off-loaded onto third markets, That obviously is of great concern to Australia, particularly the agricultural producers and exporters.

My leader, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources, is on record as having not only in this chamber but also around Australia and in Europe, argued vigorously against the sorts of policies the Europeans have adopted and as having defended strongly the rights of the Australian primary producers-be he a dried vine fruits man, a sugar producer, a wheat producer or a beef producer-to sell that produce in a fair and competitive way in world markets and not to have his situation disrupted by the totally unethical methods adopted by the European Economic Community under the Common Agricultural Policy. That policy creates enormous difficulties not only for Australia but also for other Third World nations, other developing and developed nations which export agricultural produce.

It is obviously a matter of record that Australia's protestations have been vigorous and lengthy, and it seems that it will be only as a result of pressure from within the Community itself that we will be able to get some semblance of sanity into the Common Market. I was in a party that visited Brussels a couple of years ago and we held discussions with officers of the Community. We spoke also to officials in France, France being a member of the Community and benefiting to some extent from the Common Agricultural Policy. It became fairly apparent at that stage that the costs of supporting the Common Agricultural Policy may ultimately sink that policy. They tended to take the view at that time that they would seek to maintain, in the industries in which they were operating, those producers involved at that time and they would allow any growth in the European market to be taken up by imports; they would not seek to encourage further any highly subsidised high cost European production of agricultural commodities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to raise a point of order. I do not want to disagree with what the honourable member is saying but I wonder whether you would draw his attention to the fact that we are talking about underwriting sultana production.
—Speaking to the point of order raised by the honourable member for Werriwa, I draw your attention to his speech on this Bill before you make a judgment.

—I have been listening very carefully to the debate and I must say that, on the basis of what is a fairly obvious precedent, I cannot uphold the point of order taken by the honourable member for Werriwa.

—I take on board the point that the honourable member for Werriwa sought to make. In fact he beat me by only a matter of seconds; I was about to come to the relevance of what I had been saying. Having formed a relatively favourable viewpoint after speaking with officers of the European Economic Community, I was suggesting to the House that the trends might be as I had indicated; that is, if we are confronted with a situation such as we have in the area of dried vine fruits I am concerned that substantial subsidies will be provided to enable the Greek producers to compete within the European Market and then--
—Now I see what you are getting at.

—I thank the honourable member for Werriwa because I am quite sincere about my concerns in this matter. Perhaps I was a little long-winded in the way in which I was making my point. If that was the case, I apologise to the honourable member. Obviously he was paying attention and for that I am grateful. If we were to get into a situation-it seems we may-in which the Common Agricultural Policy was being used on yet another occasion in yet another industry to provide support for a domestic European primary industry to the detriment of what is obviously an efficient industry in Australia, that would concern me greatly. The Government is obviously concerned about the industry in Australia and the industry has its own reasons to look to its future. It is for that reason that the Government and the Minister for Primary Industry have introduced the legislation we are debating this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: Most honourable members are aware that a stabilisation scheme has existed in most seasons for almost a couple of decades. In recent years we have not needed export support and for that reason it has not really been operative. But the fact is that it is a volatile market and if world situations develop as a result of seasonal conditions in other countries prices can fluctuate quite dramatically. World production in the 1980-81 season was relatively high and that could lead to reductions in world prices. We have to understand that whilst the Australian domestic market consumes a significant part of our production-I think around one third-we do rely very heavily on the export market. It is for that reason that the price of the product on the export market becomes of great significance to the producers. It is not so much a Cinderella industry but it is not one of the big primary production industries. When we talk about agriculture in Australia we tend to think in terms of wool, wheat and meat. It is often the case that we are not as cognisant as we might be of the smaller industries which do contribute quite substantially to Australia's export figures. As I indicated at the outset, these industries are of great importance to not only a large number of producers but also the people who are employed in the further stages of the industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is decentralisation in action.

—As the honourable member for Mallee so rightly says-he is a member who probably represents more dried vine fruit producers than anyone else in this chamber-it is an industry which is highly decentralised. That point cannot be made too strongly. The exports of sultanas to the EEC alone in 1980 earned $40m for this country. That is a significant amount of money not only for the overall Australian trade figures but also for the people involved in the industry who rely on it for their own well being and to support their families. That needs to be brought home and it cannot be brought home strongly enough.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the Government for taking action to guarantee minimum returns per tonne from production in the 1982, 1983 and 1984 seasons of equal to 90 per cent of the average of net returns per tonne to packers in the preceding two seasons and the estimated net return for the current season. A similar arrangement has worked very well in the wheat industry in the years since that formula was introduced. I am sure that the same experience will apply in the dried vine fruits industry, particularly for the sultana growers. In the 1985 and 1986 seasons the guaranteed minimum return will rise to 95 per cent of the three-year average net return. So the Government has not been slow in coming forward to meet the needs of this important industry. This measure will be well received by the growers, packers, processors and exporters in the industry. I just make a plea, particularly as the European Economic Community is on the verge of setting up a mission in this country, that its representatives take back to Europe the message that I and other speakers in this debate have made about the problems that Europe creates for our-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sainsbury Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Deputy Speaker, the last thing I want to do is to stop the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) from speaking but I respect your ruling on the Standing Orders. I am speaking in the debate on the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Bill not because in my country electorate we grow any dried vine fruits but because any Bill that has to do with government intervention or stabilisation affects my farmers in one way or another. I want to take the opportunity to raise one or two points about the effects of subsidies in rural industry and some of the good reasons why they are very necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, there are many people-especially those who live in city areas-who are connected with secondary and tertiary industries who see the Australian farmer as being heavily subsidised. Even in country towns in a country electorate one finds fairly constant criticism of farmers because it is perceived that at every Budget they receive handouts, that is, handouts through either subsidies, stabilisation schemes, underwriting schemes or new concessions that a government such as ours, which is very concerned about country people, tends to introduce from time to time. We do that with a great sense of responsibility to country people. We recognise the role they have played in the development of our nation. But more than that, we recognise that in Australia we have the most efficient primary production sector of any country.

I cannot produce accurate figures because the figures would depend on one's system of calculation, but it is said that Australian farmers, per head, produce enough to feed about 70 to 80 people. It is said that another great and supposedly efficient primary production country, the United States of America, produces per farming head enough food to feed about 30 people. Without going into other relative rates of production in countries such as India, Libya or any other country such as those by comparing ourselves with the USA it is possible to demonstrate just how efficient we are. We, therefore, have an industry that always will be able to stand on its feet. One of the reasons it will be able to stand on its feet is that it has always been forced to in the past.

Australia has been an innovative primary production country. It is a country where our own consultants and experts are always giving valued advice to emerging countries, especially with respect to dry land farming, irrigation techniques and breeding and animal husbandry techniques. It is one of my great joys to represent many Australian farmers who are able to compete on world markets and who are able to hold their heads up high and produce reasonable returns in the face of very substantial privileges which are being given to other sectors of industry but are not available to them.

The matter of the European Economic Community has been noted and, of course, it has been a great danger to Australia. But more than that, the common agricultural policy has presented a great danger to the EEC because if any country pursues a policy of over-protection within its own country it is bound to become less efficient. In toto it is bound to compete on world markets worse than it did previously. The evidence is showing through very rapidly at the moment that the common agricultural policy is contributing a great deal to the reduction in efficiencies in Germany and in a more recent joiner of the EEC, the United Kingdom.

All of that is a matter of record. I think the greatest argument against the EEC we have on our side for the next 10 or 15 years is the argument that must emerge through the EEC's own understanding of its own mistakes. I say that they are mistakes because, quite demonstrably, they are. Those mistakes, apart from pulling down the overall efficiency of those economies, have great effect on us. In the dried vine fruits area, as the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) has just pointed out, in this coming season we are at risk of having fruit virtually dumped from one of the members of the EEC, namely Greece. I have read that following the election of the socialist Government in Greece Mr Papandreou has said that he might favour removing Greece from the EEC. Nothing would delight me more at present than to see that because without the EEC this would be one industry that would not have the same support. Be that as it may, we have to continue our discussions with and our persuasion of the EEC to reverse its policies with respect to agriculture. We have to hope that sense will prevail through the realisation that the common agricultural policy is dragging down the rest of the economy and dragging down other industries within the EEC that have always been efficient-for instance, manufacturing industry.

When it comes to our Government's handling of a stabilisation or similar scheme it has been interesting to see the evolution. When these things were not so well tested there was a tendency in Australia to go in for other sorts of schemes such as a stabilisation scheme that was used in the milk industry for many years which, in fact, proved-we were the first to recognise it-not to be in the best interests of the industry in terms of encouraging efficient production and better returns. It was a sincere attempt in the early days to provide better returns but, in fact, it did not work. We found-I am talking about the milk industry because it illustrates the evolution-that because it was a stabilisation scheme where there was a guaranteed return of a particular nature, some producers were actively selling milk products overseas at very low prices in order to have higher production and, therefore, supposedly, economies of scale. That was dragging down other, usually smaller, producers in the industry.

It was through very sensible decisions by the previous Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Sinclair, that that whole milk mechanism was changed to an underwriting system. In this underwriting system with respect to dried vine fruits there is an inbuilt mechanism to militate against people selling overseas at too low a price. Honourable members would note from the legislation that if the price in a particular season is made artificially low, given that it would be supported by the mechanism of the underwriting, nevertheless that return price from overseas that year would, through averaging, be used to drop the underwriting price for the next year. In other words, there is a built in mechanism to keep exporters honest. That is one element that ought to be commented on.

Before I perhaps comment on other justification for this type of scheme I ought to talk about the general question of stability in markets. It is a glib and often illegitimate comment that we ought to have orderly marketing at all costs. Again, in the past the Australian farming community has tended to look for so- called orderly marketing as a matter of faith, but these days there is a great deal more sophistication among our farmers. They understand that orderly marketing at all costs can often mean merely propping up the more inefficient producers at the cost of the relatively more efficient; so orderly marketing at all costs is no longer a matter of faith. Nevertheless, the farming communities, going as they do through capricious seasons, receiving what they regard as capricious overseas prices and at times, because of particular levels of production, capricious local prices, generally say to me, at least in my electorate, that whereas they are prepared to stand up and survive in the basic market place, they do look for some form of income stability.

I imagine that anyone who lives with the seasons encountered in Australia would be prepared even to sacrifice a little income over, say, a 10-year period in order to have short term stability-to iron out the troughs and the peaks. This Government has recognised that, while at the same time recognising that people ought to be subject to the basic forces of the market and ought to adjust to long term trends. In the dried vine fruits industry, the wine industry, the apple industry, the wool industry and the meat industry there has been a shaking out from time to time, and at other times, an increase in production based on long term market signals. So I can support the basic thesis that farmers are prepared to sacrifice a small amount of income in order to have some basic income stability. It is really with this motivation in mind that the Government has introducted the legislation that is before us.

Another very good reason for its presentation is the old problem of coping with dumping by other countries. In our terms, and I believe any reasonable person's terms, the policies of the European Economic Community can amount to dumping. It is all right to say that people must live with the market and that people must cope with whatever prices competitors like to offer in the market, but it is another thing to say that that ought to be a universal rule during periods of short term dumping. Also, as a matter of faith in Australia, a principle support is that if there is evidence of dumping-which, of course, means indirectly that at any time supply could be reduced or removed, thereby removing a source of world supply-it is fair enough to protect our own people against dumping, at least in the short run. Australia having, as I have just suggested, the most efficient farming sector in the world, its farmers deserve to survive till the day when their very efficiency will allow them to compete.

Another feature that I like about this legislation, as distinct from other forms of government protection-it is a form of protection for an industry-is that it is quite visible. We also have other protection devices such as bounties . In essence, an underwriting scheme, whereby the Government is prepared to put up money to support an industry, is very visible because, when the Budget is brought down, the taxpayers can see that a certain sum is coming out of their pockets to support fellow workers. It is far less insidious than our other forms of protection that are provided not by the Government but by other consumers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Such as quotas.

—Quotas are the most insidious form of protection. The Government is well aware of that. Some industries do have quotas and the Government has indicated its intention in that regard. In the case of the motor vehicle industry, in particular, it has stated, 'In about 10 years time you will just have to do without quotas.' That proposal, which was included in the government' s statement on the industry, is another step in the right direction.

SPEECH.PARA: Another attractive feature of this legislation is that it may well cost the taxpayers nothing. An underwriting scheme merely provides that under certain conditions support will be provided. Under other conditions it will not be needed. The mechanism for deciding on a price is fair. I hope that that mechanism will not be required to operate, but at least the farmer and his family, functioning in an efficient environment, will know that within reasonable limits they can obtain protection for the next four or five years.

Finally, the legislation is simple. It is not a tricky device, not one which contains many overlays of constraints and regulations with money passing from one hand to another-complications that so often are introduced by governments of all political persuasions. Public servants have a penchant for that sort of thing, for trickiness in legislation. Thank heavens this is not one of the tricky ones. It is one that the farmers will be able to understand; that the Government will be able to administer very simply. I congratulate the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) who, although certainly not a simple person, can see things very clearly and express them without funny business or fuzziness. The legislation is a great credit to him.

I repeat that the Government is gradually moving away from such tricky situations, from artificial support schemes. Rural industry is also prepared at the present time to support that sort of drive. Of course, it wants to see the Government act consistently across all industries, but even leaving that aside, the National Farmers Federation has, quite gratifyingly, supported in principle the recommendations of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. That, one might say, has nothing to do with the dried vine fruits debate, but to me it does have a fair bit to do with it. The farming environment really requires protection only because of artificial structures in other parts of our economic environment. The NFF sees subsidies for farmers, long term, as not preferable to consistency, to an open market situation subject of course, to assistance such as is here proposed in the short term against dumping and other measures such as I have mentioned. In fact, the reaction of the NFF to the Campbell report was, in a sense, surprising to me. Campbell has suggested that the Primary Industry Bank of Australia be disbanded or put in other hands. It has suggested that the Development Bank need no longer, in a deregulated environment, be relevant. All of that makes sense to me, given of course that the full Campbell package is taken up by the Government. That is something that we have still to see.

I reiterate that the dried vine fruits industry is one which, even if in the next five or six years it costs the taxpayer something, would deserve some sort of man of the match award for having been an efficient industry, one that has been able to compete in distant markets. It is one that ought to be allowed to continue to exist in a competitive environment in Australia. For many years it will bring in export income and provide employment for a large number of people in certain areas of Australia-provided always the present Government stays in office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) said that the Opposition was not taking much interest in this debate, yet for most of the time of his speech there were only two National Country Party members in this chamber. Two others wandered in after that.
—What has that got to do with the price of fruit?

—It goes to show that the claims about the great interest of the Country Party are not warranted. I will say something else on the subject of interest. So far we have had three or four speeches from Country Party members. In each case what we have been given has been a repeat of the same story. This indicates that the Government is not bringing sufficient legislation before the Parliament and we are about to run out of the program. We are dragging on a debate when we should be discussing other matters. The Opposition does not oppose the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Bill. For that reason we want to allow it to go through the Parliament in a reasonably speedy way. Instead, we have these long-winded speeches by Country Party members trying to justify overall Country Party policy rather than speaking to the Bill. I will take a similar liberty and take on some of those arguments. In his second reading speech the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) said:

SPEECH.PARA: The underwriting arrangement embodied in this Bill is similar to systems which the Government has introduced for the wheat, dairy and apple and pear industries . It is consistent with the export pricing policies which the Government has developed for those industries.

As I have said, we support this Bill and we support action of this kind to stabilise and underwrite rural industries. But let us make very clear the methods involved. They involve Government intervention. They involve the sorts of methods which the Government is not prepared to carry out in other sectors of the economy. In fact, when we advocate such forms of intervention in other sectors of the economy we are derided by the Government. The forms of intervention involved are important in stabilising our rural industries and we support them. But the fact remains that similar forms of intervention should be carried out in manufacturing industry and other industries to support them rather than, as was suggested by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hume, allowing them to go to the wall by simply removing all protection levels without intervening to support, restructure and sustain those industries. The previous speaker talked about the motor car industry and claimed that it was a great thing that all protection is to be removed in 10 years' time. If that is a great thing, let us apply the same principle to rural industry and see how the Government likes that. The thing is that there is a contradiction in Government policy between rural industries on the one hand and manufacturing and other industries on the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point that he was making was that protection in the rural industry is visible.
—Oh, I see; because it is visible that justifies it. Is that what the honourable member is trying to say?
—We cannot argue about motor vehicles because we do not know what the cost is.
—Order! The honourable member for Burke has the call. The honourable member for Hume will come to order.

—We certainly do know what the costs are and we know that the Government has refused to intervene in the motor industry in order to restructure it or to do anything except simply to run it down. We know what the consequences of this newly announced policy are in relation to the motor car industry. I want to return to the rural industry situation. We have heard a lot about the role of the European Economic Community and the common agricultural policy. I will come back to that in a moment. What we have not heard from the Government side is about the present problems of the rural industry concerning the continuous revaluation of the Australian dollar which is directly affecting our export trade in agricultural products. It is not just a matter of-
—We have been revaluing over three months.
—I would appreciate it if the honourable member would allow me to speak as I allowed him to speak earlier on.
—But I was not making outrageous statements.
—Order! The honourable member for Burke has the call. The honourable member for Hume will come to order.

—The honourable member for Hume will get the opportunity to answer those statements at a future time. The fact is that this continuous revaluation has resulted in our export trade being seriously affected. What has happened? Where have the Country Party voices been on this matter? They have kept quiet. Even though the situation calls for a reconsideration of revaluation of the Australian currency, we have not heard a single thing from the Treasurer (Mr Howard) about it. Instead, what do we have? We have the constant attempt to blame the common agricultural policy of the EEC for the failure of rural exports .
—It is those Greeks.

—The fact remains that, although there are problems relating to the EEC, that by itself is not the totality of the situation. We have heard a lot about the Greek Government, the fact that Greece has entered the EEC which is affecting the possibility of dried vines and sultanas from Australia entering the EEC market. That is true. Nevertheless, if Greece had not joined the EEC we would still be in a difficult situation with our exports to the EEC. Let us just not blame the entry of Greece into the EEC. An earlier speaker mentioned the support price as a result of Greece's entry into the EEC. He failed to appreciate the implications of the price to be set for Greek grapes by the EEC. The support price should not become the world price for sultanas because, if it is too low, it will damage world trade as a whole; if it is too high, it will encourage unprofitable production. In this situation it is very important that all the other producing countries keep the market up and not undercut each other . That is why the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) cited the telex from the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation. The other point missed by the honourable member for Hume was that of diversion. If Greece places in the European market sultanas presently being sold to Russia, it may take markets away from Australia. While the entry of Greece into the EEC may have made some change, it is not the cause of our problems in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally I want to refer honourable members to the subject of when underwriting agreements are undertaken by the Government and when they are put on and when they are taken off. In his speech, the Minister mentioned that they were taken off because we had a buoyant season in sultanas. We now find that we are forced to reintroduce an arrangement of this kind. What I want to ask the Minister is: Will we again be taking the arrangements off if the market situation improves?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a new scheme.
—Well, it is a new scheme, but I ask: Is this scheme permanent?
—It has five years. The Bill states that.
—Well, I want to know whether in fact we will be faced with Country Party schemes that are taken off and on rather than a scheme for stabilisation over a long period.
—Let me answer. It is five years in the Act. There is an Act of Parliament for five years.

—I know it is for five years but what we want to know is whether these sorts of arrangements in general will be taken off and on depending on seasons and on markets that are created. That is all I wanted to know from the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that we do not appreciate the pious remarks of the National Country Party members who say that they are the only ones who support these sorts of schemes. As I made clear at the beginning of my speech, these schemes are based on government intervention; they are based on socialistic principles. Whilst Country Party members support those sorts of principles in rural industries, they totally fail to support those principles in other industries. In my view that is hypocritical.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was intrigued to hear what I take to be, perhaps, the real voice of the Australian Labor Party in rural matters coming from the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) rather than the more rational level of understanding that came from the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) who is the Opposition spokesman on primary industry. It concerns me-I think it should concern the House-that on rural matters a clear prejudice against the rural community, as demonstrated by the honourable member for Burke, seems to come to the fore when the Labor Party is scratched. To allege, for example-
—I raise a point of order. That is not true.
—Order! Does the honourable member for Burke wish to take a point of order?

—Yes, I have been misrepresented. We said that we support this Bill and we support these kinds of policies. How can the honourable member for Macarthur say that we are biased against the rural industries?
—There is no point of order. The honourable member for Burke has not indicated a point of order.

—So that the honourable member for Burke will understand, I will restate what I said but do so more slowly and clearly for him. His attitude reflects an anti-rural attitude in that he claimed that secondary industry in Australia did not receive anything like the assistance or protection that is given to the rural sector. He made some point of this. He went on at great length about how in many areas it was unfair for the rural sector to receive assistance, even though he did say that his party favoured taking the measure contained in this piece of legislation. I am glad to see the Labor Party is supporting the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I was endeavouring to point to the comments of the honourable member for Burke which were typical anti-rural comments. He suggested that, because support to the rural sector in this kind of legislation is clear, open and evident for all to see, it is somehow more sinister and more offensive than the hidden support that is given to secondary industry, the costs of which are not as evident to the public and which I believe represent a principle which is unacceptable to large sections of the Australian community. I stress that it seems to me, as the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) said, that it is far better to support an industry openly, cleanly and honestly in the way in which an industry is being supported in this Bill than to adopt a system which has built up over previous years under governments of all political persuasions whereby there are hidden amounts of assistance and the public does not know the real cost of the protection given. I refer, for example, to many areas of manufacturing industry.

I simply counter the proposition put by the honourable member for Burke which seems to me to be typical of the pro-urban position generally taken by the Labor Party in discussing rural matters. All the honourable member for Burke has succeeded in doing is confirming the general proposition that the Labor Party tends to have a bias against the rural sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member is persistently misrepresenting what I said.
—I take a point of order. That is not a point of order.
—I demand the right to respond to the misrepresentations of the honourable member for Macarthur.
—The honourable member for Burke has not taken a point of order. I call the honourable member for Macarthur.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I point the honourable member for Burke to a few other matters that he raised in his speech and which were simply totally untrue. He said that there was a continuing revaluation of the Australian dollar which was damaging rural industries. If the honourable member for Burke directed his attention to what is really happening to the Australian dollar, he would see a tendency to devalue in recent times.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Burke also alleged that there was no legislation to be dealt with by the chamber. If he looked at the Daily Program he would see that today a matter is coming up of major significance to all sides of the House -it is certainly of major significance to this side of the House, and I would assume to the other side-the Freedom of Information Bill. If the honourable member for Burke limited his comments to matters of facts the status of his contribution to this House would certainly be increased.

Another matter which I think the honourable member for Burke failed to understand in dealing with this legislation related to his saying that the Greek situation connected with dried fruits should not disadvantage Australia. That is my understanding of what he said. I do not think the honourable member for Burke understands the way the common agricultural policy actually works. The common agricultural policy will provide serious disadvantages to the Australian dried fruit industry now that Greece is a member of the Common Market. This is not simply illustrated by analogy although we can point to many other industries where the Common Market, which had been a major importer of rural items from Australia and other primary producing countries, as a result of the imposition of the common agricultural policy has become a major exporter. The dairy industry, for instance, is a classic example. Australia and New Zealand used to have various Common Market countries as their major customers.

The Common Market as a result of the exercise of the Common Agricultural Policy is now dumping massive surpluses in our other markets because of the encouragement to surplus production. The honourable member for Burke said that if the price were set too high there would be excessive production, and that would be silly. I am afraid that that is exactly what has happened in the Common Market, that is the result of the Common Agricultural Policy. Next month in Brussels there will be serious negotiations-I hope not disastrous-to establish a price rise for agricultural support in the current year. The French agricultural Minister has stated that the price rise will be 16 per cent-a 16 per cent increase in the support prices for agriculture in the Common Market. The consequence of that kind of price rise would be absolutely disastrous in most areas of agricultural production in which Australia is an exporter.

It seems to me that we have in the case of dried fruits the situation which existed 10 years ago in the dairy industry. Now that Greece and Spain are members of the Common Market, we face the risk of exactly the same situation developing where excessively high support prices in Europe could generate enormous surpluses of production. Instead of the Common Market's being an importer, it will become a dumping exporter of the products. In butter, for example, the dairy surplus accounts for some 30 per cent of the European Economic Community's budget and about 40 per cent of total community expenditure on agricultural support. It seems to me that when that sort of thing is allowed to happen world trade ends up in a totally disruptive and disastrous situation. I hope this does not happen to the dried fruits industry. I am pointing to the dangers involved particularly if the French have their way in the negotiations which start next month. A price rise of 16.3 per cent in the support price for agricultural products for the current year, as recommended by the French agricultural Minister, will encourage such a massive increase in production across the board that it will inevitably mean the dumping disposal of huge European surpluses.

The honourable member for Burke does not seem to understand that not only are there price support schemes within the Common Agricultural Policy which generally involve the setting of a minimum price at which the intervention agencies of the member states acting on behalf of the Community purchase produce offered when market prices are weak at times of surplus, for example, but also there are minimum import prices which are designed to protect the Community markets from imports at prices below those of the Community. The import price limits would clearly disadvantage Australian exports of dried fruit and particularly sultanas with which this Bill mainly deals. They would clearly disadvantage Australian exports which may well otherwise have been able to go into Europe at lower prices and demand a larger market. In other words, the Greek producer is going to be protected against the Australian producer. Nothing that the honourable member for Burke said will diminish or detract from that point. I fail to understand why he felt that the Government was being somehow mistaken in complaining. The honourable member for Burke objected strongly to a speech from this side pointing to these dangers. I simply cannot understand why he would seek to diminish in any way the real threat that exists. I would only hope that in this industry the sorts of variations that we have had in prices will not lead to even further disruption to the industry now that the Common Market has extended its umbrella to producers such as Greece.

We are all aware of the fact that the major supplier in the world trade is, of course, the United States of America in the sense that if there is a crop failure in that country obviously prices will rise substantially, as they did, I think, in 1978. That led to very large rises in world prices. On the other hand- I take the honourable member for Burke's point that this might be, in his view, offensive socialism-it seems to me sensible and reasonable to have a price support system which allows for, as happened in the Australian dairy industry, intervention in the market of an underwritten price when there is a surplus. Dried fruits are a storeable commodity. Many people have said that intervention schemes should exist for many other commodities, such as meat. The price of storeage, frankly, makes it very difficult to run any kind of effective intervention price. But it seems to me that in the case of dried fruits an underwriting system is very reasonable and sensible. I certainly support such a scheme. I welcome the fact that the Labor Party also supports it.

I point out that this kind of underwriting support system has been so successful in the dairy industry. In fact, from memory the latest year involved no actual cash payments because the price received was adequate before the intervention price was called on. I hope that there will be little need to resort to the underwriting price in this industry. Let us face it, given a fair deal in Europe there would be no need to use such a scheme. I regret to say that the experience of Australia in dealings with the Common Agricultural Policy is such that one would not look forward with confidence to getting a fair deal in Europe. It seems to me very important for this industry and many other export rural industries in Australia that the negotiations to be held next month in Brussels result in a far lower price rise than the 16 per cent being pressed by the French. The Common Market bureaucrats have suggested a 9 per cent price rise . I understand that such a rise would also lead to substantial increases in the surpluses of agricultural products from Europe which would be dumped on to Australian markets. I refer particularly to butter and meat.

As the House may remember, the Common Market used to be the biggest importer of meat after America. This year it will end up as the biggest exporter of that product. None of it will be exported at genuine prices. It will all be done at artificially dumped prices. The British Government is desperately seeking to limit the amount of the price rise in the Common Agricultural Policy this year. In fact, several members from both sides of this House had the opportunity to discuss this matter with Ministers of the British Government and senior bureaucrats during a recent official visit to Britain. There is no doubt that the British are very keen to limit the size of the price rise for the very simple reason that they will end up paying the bulk of the bill. It seems, therefore, that Britain and Australia have a similar objective in trying to limit the excesses of the Common Agricultural Policy which have done so much damage to trade and agricultural products throughout the world.

I conclude by saying that I strongly support this Bill. I totally agree with the honourable member for Eden-Monaro that this sort of legislation is the best way to deal with this kind of problem. Such an approach is open and the public is told exactly what the support is and what the cost of that support will be. Also I believe such a scheme enables the industry to know what it is doing and to have an understanding of what the future holds for it. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume). I would like to clarify two points on which I have been misrepresented. In fact, I expressed the Opposition's complete support for the Bill and for similar schemes. What I said was that this form of government intervention, of which the honourable member said he approves, in terms of stabilisation programs and restructuring programs should be carried out in other sectors of the economy. I did not say-
—The honourable member will not debate the point. He will point out where he has been misrepresented and then resume his seat.

—That was in contrast to the claim about protection. I said clearly that what we want to see is not simply continued protection of manufacturing industry but also intervention to support such industries. The second point I want to make concerns my attitude to the European Economic Community. I have never claimed that the agricultural policy of the EEC is just.
