SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up a few minutes of this debate to respond to a couple of points that have been raised and to put to rest the argument that the Australian Labor Party is a party that is interested only in the urban sector. The fact is that we support this Bill. So far in this debate we have heard everything from underwriting, which the Bill is about, to the marketing arrangements of the European Economic Community and just about every other industry in the rural sector. We must have a clear understanding of what underwriting involves. I should point out that the underwriting will not be set at a level which will do anything for farmers who are going broke. It will be set at a level that will allow the industry slowly to wind itself down. Many references have been made to the dairy industry. Honourable members should remember that the Government took a long time to get into the underwriting business in respect of that industry. In fact the dairy industry got right down to a broke position of 50c per lb for butterfat before the Government made any move in respect of underwriting. Even then it underwrote the industry only at a level at which thousands and thousands of farmers went out of business.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members have said that they are helping the industry. What they are actually doing is providing funds to allow farmers to be paid until export markets can return money. That is basically the purpose of underwriting under this Government. The Government would like many people in the cities to believe that it is a government with a heart and understanding. This has never been the situation. The Government has not provided funds in that regard to the rural sector for a long time. We of the Labor Party understand what underwriting is about. We support the principle of underwriting because some industries have to be rationalised to enable them to be returned to an economic situation.

In this debate there has been plenty of talk about the European Economic Community. The EEC is a fact of life. Every now and then we hear Country Party and Liberal Party supporters say in this place what a terrible thing the EEC is. We have to face up to the fact that the EEC does exist. We have to work within the policies of the EEC. The big thing that is affecting Australia's rural industries, the grape industry, our fruit industry and all exporting industries, is the revaluation of Australian currency. The honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) who put that case forward was ridiculed by the following speaker, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) but the honourable member for Hume was talking about the fact that over the last couple of months there has been a devaluation of 5 per cent or 6 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seven per cent.

—Seven per cent, as the honourable member for Mallee said, but not against all currencies. The honourable member was talking about major currencies such as the United States dollar. What we in the rural industry have to contend with at present is that government economic policies have created a situation in which the countries that we need to trade with have devalued against our currency by enormous amounts. There is very little point in Australian exporting industries going into those countries and expecting to get a return. One only has to look at the advantage New Zealand has at present and compare the value of New Zealand currency with the Australian currency to realise what would happen if these two countries were to compete on the same export markets.

SPEECH.PARA: Mention has been made of the dairying industry. Today the dairying industry is strictly an industry that is based on the home market. There is very little export from this industry. In fact, the export opportunities available to the dairying industry at present would be barely enough to keep us in our own product if we have a bad season. The dried fruit industry which is under discussion today will be in the same position when it loses its market in the EEC. We have to bear in mind that any exporting industry, be it in agriculture or manufacturing, depends on exporting to a country where the revaluation of its currency is such that we are totally non-competitive. We have to look to the Government to protect those industries in some way. It is all very well to talk about underwriting but there is no guarantee that underwriting will be set at a figure that will allow an efficient and economic producer to stay in business. It is all right for the Minister to set a figure after looking at and equalising the returns. That will cost the Government nothing. We know in the present economic situation how hard it is to get two bob out of this Government and we in the Labor Party cannot see the Government providing even to the rural industry any great amount of money that will be of assistance to it. These industries are in desperate trouble because of the Government's economic policies. The countries which have revalued their currency are the ones that are --

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw attention to the fact that we are discussing the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Bill. I do not think the honourable member for McMillan has mentioned it since he commenced his remarks.
—In my opinion he was sticking fairly close to the Bill.
—The honourable member is concerned that I am not discussing the Bill. I have listened throughout the debate on the Bill. The whole of the discussion has been on the EEC.
—Order! The honourable member will address the Chair and continue to discuss the Bill.

—The Chair is quite correct. None of the other speakers have been any closer to the Bill so I am quite entitled to say what I have been saying. The crux of the matter is that underwriting on its own will not be a solution to the problems of these industries that are in danger of losing their markets, these high paying markets such as the EEC. These industries will then be forced to sell on other export markets. It is not competition from the EEC that is the problem. The problem is one of valuation of money. The economic circumstances in this country prevent many export industries from competing on the export markets that are available. Those honourable members who watched the television program The History of Ireland, which was shown recently would be aware that in the last century a country was able to export food while its people died of starvation. We have the same situation in the world today. Australia is a country that can produce food at the present time but we are being asked to phase out agricultural industries simply because of the economic situation and the valuation of money.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude my remarks by saying that we in the Opposition support the Bill. The Labor Party is quite able to handle agriculture issues. In fact as one who represents an agricultural area I believe the Labor Party's policies are much more in line for the future of agriculture in this country than anything the Liberal-National Country Party Government can put forward.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr MacKellar) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 20 August 1981, on motion by Mr Viner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Freedom of Information Bill which is now before the House. In continuing my remarks today from an earlier date last year when the Bill was being discussed I trust that the House will forgive me on this occasion for going over some of those remarks which describe the aims and objectives of this legislation. This Bill represents a major initiative by the Government in its program of administrative reform. In many respects it is unique. Although a number of countries have freedom of information legislation, Australia is in fact the first country in which a Westminster style of government operates to bring forward such a measure. I understand that at present Canada, New Zealand and the United Kingdom are considering similar legislation. I think the Government of this country is to be commended for being the first to bring such a measure into the Parliament. At present in Canada I understand legislation is before the Parliament or the Government is looking at it before it is reintroduced. In New Zealand a parliamentary committee is examining similar legislation. In the United Kingdom I understand there have been several attempts by private members, from both government and opposition, but as yet there is no government information legislation before the House of Commons. I think Australia and the Fraser Government are to be congratulated and commended for bringing this legislation before the House and before the country.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go into the detail of the legislation I think it is worth reflecting on the environment in which this legislation has been introduced. We are talking about the making available of information in Government departments and authorities to members of the public in this democracy of ours. I think it is worth reflecting just for a minute or two on the democracy and freedom we enjoy in this country because I suggest that only 20 or so countries enjoy the same sort of freedom that we do. I think it is appropriate that the Government should have introduced freedom of information legislation so that individuals and citizens can have access to Government records and information. The people should be entitled to have this sort of access. But I think it is worth remembering that many countries do not have these forms of democracies and are unlikely to have them. The whole of the Soviet bloc has no democracy. Freedom of information is anathema to the Soviet bloc and to the communist bloc. In many countries which have a dictatorship, of the Right or of the Left, the basic freedoms that we take for granted do not exist. It is in the concept that I have referred to, that is, the environment of the freedom that we have in this country under the Westminster system, that the Government has introduced this Freedom of Information Bill.

There are three major aspects to the legislation. Firstly, it provides for the publication of certain government information, such as descriptive material about the functions, structures and operations of government. The second type of information for which publication is provided is the so-called hidden law-the manuals, the guidelines, the precedents and the instructions that are given in government by one government official to another-perhaps sometimes by Ministers, but mainly by the administrators. This provision for the publication of this material is designed to enable this so-called hidden law, this administrative structure of manuals and guidelines that I have referred to which flesh out acts , regulations, to be available to the public.

The second key element is that the Freedom of Information Bill provides for a right of access to documents in the possession of Commonwealth departments and statutory authorities. In this area there has to be a balance between the confidentiality of government and the right of access. This balance takes place in the legislation. I refer to Part IV which contains the exemptions.

It is worth stating that the Bill does not set out to be a code of access but a minimum standard which any Minister in the Executive branch of government can go beyond at any time. The exemptions that I have referred to in Part IV are a basis for saying: 'I am not required to give you access.' They are not a basis for saying: 'I am prevented from giving you access.' The Bill says, in effect, ' I am not required to give you access.' As I have said, and I will say it again, it is not a basis for saying that a Minister or the Executive is prevented from doing this; it is a matter of establishing in the legislation a floor level of access.

The Freedom of Information Bill is certainly not a code of secrecy. It is very much a case of legislation where the proof of the pudding will be in the eating. We have to see how it is administered. Ministers should be encouraged to make available more than what is set as the minimum standard established by the Bill, more than the floor level. I am confident that that will occur. Of course, when legislation such as this is being introduced for the first time, it is quite right and proper to establish that minimum floor level.

The third aspect of the legislation that was introduced in the Senate is that there is a right of correction in respect of personal records. Honourable members will agree that that is proper, appropriate and right. The Bill also provides for an adequate right of appeal. It has mechanisms for that and has, as I have mentioned, the right of access and the right of correction. We need to recognise that a Government, like a business or a family, needs confidentiality and secrecy on occasions. That is right and proper. On the one hand, it is a matter of an appropriate balance between openness and confidentiality and, on the other hand, the extent to which the right of access to information given by the Bill should require the commitment of resources in depths and authorities at a time when the Government is seeking to contain the size of the public sector.

One does not know what the demand for access under the legislation will be and whether there will be a rush for access. We would not want to see the number of people needed to service this legislation to equal the size of one government department. We have to see how the legislation works and what the demand is. When the Government is seeking, as a matter of an economic policy, to contain the size of the public sector, the House will agree that an open-ended commitment of resources to this legislation at present is just not on. The Government is to be congratulated in this regard for having undertaken to review , after 12 months operation, whether additional rights of access might be given to documents already in the possession of agencies at the date on which the Bill comes into operation-that is, the so-called prior documents. As I have said before and indicated in my comments today, the policy of the Government is to make as much information as possible available to the public.

It is worth reflecting on the Westminster system of government as we know it. As I said earlier, this Government and this country are the first operating under the Westminster system to have such legislation before it. There is, of course, legislation in the United States of America, but under the Westminster system, where there is a particular relationship between Executive government and the Parliament, it is a different ball game. Under our system, the Executive government of the day bears a responsibility to the Parliament and, through the Parliament to the people, for the proper discharge of the government of the country. In legislation like the Freedom of Information Bill before us today, we have to take care in adapting to our system a legal concept which has been derived from countries having systems different from ours. The present Bill we are talking about today needs to be seen also in the context of legislation that the Westminster system has produced, in the context of the systems of administrative review which have already been established under this Westminster system by this Parliament. I refer to the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court of Australia operating under the powers conferred on it by the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.

One also must remember that, under our system, Ministers are subjected to daily questions without notice in Parliament on matters within their ministerial responsibility. A mechanism is available to parliamentarians-honourable members and honourable senators-to place questions on the Notice Paper. This is not available under the American system where the Executive and the legislative branch are completely separate. Therefore, we cannot just adapt what has been implemented in the United States to the Westminster-Australian environment. Similarly, in our system honourable members have the opportunity to participate in debates-we have seen it today-and Ministers can be asked questions by members of their own Government back bench as well as by members of the Opposition. That is the Parliament at one of its best moments. That is where this system is different from the United States system. The Bill is interesting. It requires Ministers or departments seeking to withhold information to justify their decisions to deny access to information by reference to the criteria set out in the Bill. It puts a responsibility upon them to do that.

I have talked of the balance in the Bill and I have talked of the mandatory provisions in it. The Bill imposes a positive obligation on departments and authorities to make public their organisations, structures and the functions they perform. They are also obliged to make available to their clients or customers the criteria employed in the exercise of decision-making functions. I am sure honourable members will agree with that. I found one interesting provision when I was browsing through the legislation earlier as to the requests involving the use of computers. I have not done any research, but I do not think there are very many Acts of Parliament that actually acknowledge the existence of computers. It is interesting that clause 17 of this Bill, in fact, does that because often information today may not be written or on file but, in fact, may be on a computer tape. The Bill provides that where the information is not available, as it puts it, in a discrete form in documents of an agency, it can be called for and be produced as a computer printout. That will be the accepted form for the information being made available. The legislation is very modern. It recognises what is happening in the 20th century.

Under this legislation the ultimate decision must be made by the Minister or an officer directly responsible to him, especially in relation to exempt documents, defined in the Bill as, among other things: Documents affecting national security, defence, international relations and relations with States; Cabinet documents; Executive Council documents; and documents affecting the enforcement of the law and the protection of public safety. I am sure that the House will agree that one does not want the Australian Federal Police to have to make all its records available to people who require them; for instance, to criminals who may want to know what is going on. I agree with this legislation. I consider it represents a major step forward in removing unnecessary secrecy from the administrative process of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Freedom of Information Bill is, in our view, an excellent example of the Government's giving lip service to small 'l' liberal principles but in fact doing whatever it can to limit the genuine implementation of those principles. Indeed, it proves once again that this Government is conservative rather than liberal in any sense. It is in fact a closed government , jealously guarding its privileges, rather than an open government. I shall endeavour to demonstrate that point in speaking on this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I shall make some remarks about the need for freedom of information legislation and about the principles of liberalism, on which such Bills are based. The father of liberalism, John Stuart Mill, expressed the importance of information being available to the people from governments as a central feature in an open society. He pointed out in his writings on liberty that the possibility of rational discourse on government policies, on decisions by governments, is the most important feature of an open society and a society that prides itself on matters of liberty. He pointed out that the state can be oppressive and can oppress by withholding information from its citizens. That situation is indeed a situation we have encroached upon in the developments of the 20th century.

I point out that we in the modern state, in the moderm government, have masses of government information that is not available to the people. One reason why it is not available to the people is that people are bewildered by that mass of information, that mass of activity. I shall give some facts that illustrate that . In 1901, at the time of the first Australian Government, there were four million people and they had a Budget of #4m. The House of Representatives sat for 113 days and discussed a variety of matters. It could be argued that at that time a normal citizen could have some idea of what was going on in government and in government departments. Indeed, at that time the biggest government department was that of the general post office, would you believe? I ask honourable members to contrast that situation with the situation which existed in 1980-81, when there were 14 million people with a Budget of $40,000m. After allowing a factor of 18:1 for inflation, the growth of government, government departments and government spending was of the order of 71:1. We have had a massive increase in government departments. We have had a massive increase in activities. Those activities are determining the lives of citizens.

John Stuart Mill, in postulating the principles of liberal democratic government-I point out to honourable members opposite that we are talking about liberal democratic principles-insisted upon the importance of such information being accessible to the people. Given that enormous increase in available data, so to speak, how can any citizen be expected to come to grips with the totality of the situation? Of course, he cannot. That gives rise to opportunities for the Public Service, for the Government, to hide an enormous number of things from its citizens and, in fact, to claim that information citizens want to get because it affects their lives in certain ways is lost in computers or in one government department or another.

Therefore, in a very substantial way most modern governments govern what information is made available and what is not. In other words, we have a situation in which the ordinary citizen makes his decision about the effectiveness of government, about the extent to which government decisions represent his will, on the basis of information that is released in a controlled way by government. It can be claimed, in fact, that what the citizen gains is basically propaganda rather than information. We do not have to look far to find examples of that. We need only look at political advertisements and at surveys of the political knowledge of our people, undertaken by political scientists, to recognise that we face a serious situation in that people are ignorant about matters they should know more about because only certain types of information have been made available to them and have been pushed through the media channels .

To have the most liberal, the most open system of information is to strengthen a democracy. It is in fact to create a situation in which genuine participatory processes can operate. That is not happening in Australia. We know about the cynics who say that Australians are a bunch of apathetic no-hopers who take no interest in politics and in the operations of government. I do not for a moment accept that proposition. What I say is that part of the blame, a lot of the blame, lies with government and its insistence on secrecy in a large number of its dealings. That means that we have to think about opening up that system.

When this legislation was introduced in the Senate the Opposition proposed a substanial number of amendments, designed to do exactly that, to open up the system. What was to be lost by the Liberals adopting those amendments? Do they suppose that they will be in government perpetually or that if we come to government we will not have to operate under the same rules? Of course we would have to. Therefore, they should have recognised that in the long term it is in their interest to make government as open as possible and to make information as openly available as it possibly can be. But, as I said, lamentably that is not what has happened. Most of our amendments were not accepted by the Senate and we now face a situation in which we have to move those amendments again in the House of Representatives. I appeal to honourable members opposite who pride themselves in having some respect for genuine liberal principles to look at this legislation once again, to look at the amendments once again and to accept that by refusing to support those amendments all that they will be doing will be strengthening the hands of the Executive against the Parliament and against the people as a whole. They should consider supporting the Opposition and adopting those amendments.

As I mentioned, freedom of information legislation is necessary to ensure the proper functioning of a democratic system. The people should be given much greater access to the Public Service, especially to those decisions which directly affect their lives. The people must be able to query the suppositions on which government decisions are made and the manner in which those decisions are implemented. We have a Public Service which, notwithstanding the Government' s attempts to run it down and discredit it in various ways, generally performs well. However, there is room for improvement and a need for a more rapid process of learning from past errors. My experience on the Public Accounts Committee has shown me the extent to which senior public servants in particular are prepared to go to great lengths to prevent the Parliament, never mind the ordinary citizen, knowing too much about certain activities. Some senior public servants seem to be of the view that the work they do and the decision processes in which they are involved are the property of the Government and not of the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they think we are irrelevant.

—Yes, they think the Parliament is irrelevant in certain ways. This attitude must be changed if we are to have a worthwhile democratic system. The Executive not only has too much power within the process but also seems to have a monopoly on information. It has created this attitude in public servants so that even what might appear to be perfectly harmless material is not available to ordinary citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: It is along those lines that I wish to point out the exemptions contained in this legislation. Some bodies need not release a single piece of information to citizens; they will do so only if they or the Government cares to make it available. Among the bodies which are totally exempt are the Australian National Railways Commission, the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation, Aboriginal land councils and land trusts, the Canberra Commercial Development Authority, the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation and the Pipeline Authority. For God's sake, what is there about these bodies which makes them so mysterious, so strange, that the Government has to exempt totally from this legislation all information in relation to those bodies? Is it a conspiracy between the Executive and certain senior public servants to cover up mistakes and inefficiencies? If it is not, why has the Government made all these organisations exempt? Further organisations are exempt in respect of particular documents. For example, the Australian Broadcasting Commission is to be exempt in relation to its program material. In other words, if a program appears on the ABC and I want to know something about it, as a citizen who is paying for the ABC, for some strange reason that information is to be exempt under the freedom of information legislation.

These points illustrate the central difficulty that the Opposition has in supporting the Government on this legislation. We demand that the Government reconsider our carefully thought out amendments so we can say that in a bipartisan way we have given the people of Australia a Freedom of Information Bill that is really worth its salt. I wish to mention a couple of other objections to the legislation before the House. These objections were put most concisely by Senator Evans last year in another place. He said:

In the first place, despite the very extensive and elaborate character of the report of the Senate Committee, to which I have referred, the Bill simply does not adopt more than a relative handful of the recommendations of that Committee. Those who presented it have not done the Parliament and the nation the courtesy of giving a fully argued, careful response to all the very detailed provisions and arguments in that report which have been rejected. The other ground for disappointment, to summarise it, is this: Not only is the new Bill not a really significant advance on its 1978 predecessor, despite the hopes which many of us had that the Committee's recommendations would be picked up in this way, but in fact it goes backwards in a number of significant respects, with a whole series of new exceptions and exemptions and procedural obstacles contained in it which were not contemplated, and certainly not contained, in the original version.

So, not only do we have all these exemptions but also we have a series of procedures designed to frustrate the process, to make it difficult even for those people who want to operate under the legislation to get information. Let us suppose someone requests certain detailed information. It is possible that a government department that does not want to give out this information will say to this person, 'We are sorry but you have to specify exactly the date, time and situation relating to that information. We would love to help you, we really are great democrats and people who believe in open government, but unfortunately we cannot quite find the piece of paper to which you have referred'. In that situation the citizen is left up in the air, without any redress. So it is necessary that we provide checks on a government department's refusal to provide information and do not put obstacles in the way of the availability of information.

Finally, I believe this should have been a matter on which we had total bipartisan support but it has turned out to be a matter on which there is substantial disagreement. It is to the great discredit of the people who mislead the nation by calling themselves members of a liberal party but which is in fact a conservative and closed government party that they have not accepted the sensible amendments which we have put forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —An essential feature of the Freedom of Information Bill is that it is an experiment. It will almost certainly be amended in the not too distant future, after a year to three years of testing, as the Attorney- General (Senator Durack) said in another place. On that basis it deserves the support of the House. As almost everyone who has spoken in this debate has agreed, the Bill is an attempt to strike a balance between openness and confidentiality; between public access to government records and the preservation of necessary confidentiality. A particular balance has been struck. Some want more openness, based on the model of the United States Freedom of Information Act, and others want less; but a system has been launched. We can see how it works and make changes as we go along.

SPEECH.PARA: Since most of the Opposition critics of the balance struck in this Bill have held up the American system as a model it seems useful to draw attention to some of the very serious criticisms that have been made in the United States of the American system. The Bill before us can and should be seen as an attempt to establish freedom of information arrangements that deliberately avoid in particular the six defects that have emerged in discussions of the American law. In comparison with the American law the Bill before the House attempts, firstly, to reduce administrative costs; secondly, to reduce retrospectivity; thirdly, to reduce litigation; fourthly, to tighten the exemption of criminal intelligence; fifthly, to use ministerial certificates to exempt disclosures where necessary of national security and defence information; and, sixthly, to schedule a number of agencies which are in whole or in part exempt from the operation of the Bill.

In all those six ways it departs from the American model. I would say that in all those six ways it attempts to improve on the American model or to get away from serious defects that have emerged in the American model. These variations on the American system may tend to strike the balance between openness and confidentiality too much in favour of confidentiality. I am inclined to think that they do and will, in due course, require amendment. But each one of them is based on an awareness of criticisms or defects in the American practice. The Bill, in short, attempts to avoid the mistakes of the Americans. Let me refer to some that are taken to be mistakes.

The American freedom of information law of 1966 was radically amended in 1974 to maximise, speed up and cheapen disclosures of government information. This amended 1974 law has certainly worked-no one would deny that-but at a price. Let us look at administrative costs. I know that costs are only one consideration in the whole mix and there are some who would argue that the public's right to know must prevail over questions of costs or departmental efficiency. Nevertheless, one ought to be clear about what is or may be involved.

The United States House Committee of Government Operations was reported in 1976 -a little after the law was amended-as estimating that the administration of the amended 1974 law would cost no more than $100,000 a year. In fact, in 1977-a year after that estimate-according to the congressional research services' annual overview, costs were approximately, not $100,000 but $36m. The Federal Bureau of Investigation in that year estimated its costs as $10m; defence was $5 .5m; health, education and welfare costs were $5.2m; and Treasury costs were $5. 2m.

Further, dollar costs are not the only measure of criticism. Processing of freedom of information applications usually requires qualified analysts who are consequently diverted from their primary duties. The United States Senate Judiciary Committee reported in 1978 that the Drug Enforcement Administration then had a freedom of information division processing applications larger than any of its six internal security field offices combating the drug trade. It had to put more manpower into freedom of information than into combating the drug trade in particular fields.

The Central Intelligence Agency complained that it had had to expend four man- years meeting the freedom of information request of a writer who was dedicated to exposing the identities of overseas CIA employees whose lives were subsequently put at risk and at least one of whom was murdered. So the dollar cost of administration and the diversion of departmental resources are considerations that cannot be just brushed aside. The limits on retrospectivity and litigation and the exemptions in the Bill before us ensure that these American excesses are avoided. It may be that this Bill goes too far in avoiding those excesses but it seems to me to be a reasonable basis on which to start.

Let us look at the Bill's treatment of business information. Every private enterprise of any consequence is portrayed in government records. Government, in its dealings with business is, at various times, licenser, regulator, taxer insurer, investigator, auditor, inspector, subsidiser, customer, seller, lender, landlord and tenant. It inevitably collects something approaching complete information about most businesses. The complaint in the United States for many years was that much of this information became available to business competitors under the Freedom of Information Act.

At the hearings of the House Committee on Government Operations of the ninety- fifth Congress, the deputy-general counsel of the Environmental Protection Agency stated that the greatest use of Environmental Protection Agency records had been by business corporations and their law firms seeking information about competitors. The Food and Drug Administration's testimony was that in 1975 it received 20,000 Freedom of Information Act requests, 86 per cent of which came from industries and private attorneys seeking confidential information about competitors. It also said that it received 25,000 requests in 1977.

Companies such as Freedom of Information Services Inc. of Rockville, Maryland, specialise in handling Freedom of Information Act requests on behalf of corporations. For the price of a postage stamp, under the 1974 United States law , anyone could obtain confidential information about someone else's business. The vice-president of the Dow chemical company quoted a case in which his company had been negotiating the sale of technology to a foreign company. The negotiations abruptly ended when the foreign company obtained the technology under the Freedom of Information Act. Other businesses claimed at the hearings that the release of information relating to equal employment opportunity programs and affirmative action plans allowed knowledgeable competitors to deduce labour costs, sales volume, plans for expansion, profit margin, vulnerability to price changes and new products. Indeed, they could obtain all the confidential information about a competitor that they needed to know in order to compete more than successfully.

After much litigation in the United States the District of Colombia Court of Appeals in the famous case National Parks and Conservation Association v. Morton adopted the 'substantial competitive harm' test for exemption from disclosure. Commercial and financial information may be withheld under this exemption if disclosure is likely to, firstly, impair the government's ability to obtain necessary information or, secondly, cause substantial harm to the competitive position of the person from whom the information was obtained. After examining the American practice I see that the Bill before us, in clause 43, adopts almost the very words of the National Parks case. This seems to me to be typical of this Bill's attempt to learn from American errors and not simply adopt the 1974 US law while ignoring the criticisms that have emerged since 1974.

The same can be said about clause 37 of this Bill dealing with records concerning the investigation of crime. The 1974 US amendment limits exemption from disclosure to records of active police investigations if disclosure would put the lives of police or informants at risk or undermine enforcement proceedings or a fair trial. But it also requires the disclosure of associated or segregable portions of otherwise exempt records. The result is that by obtaining various non-exempt segregable portions requesters, in particular criminals, can put two and two together, identify police sources and take appropriate criminal action against them.

One in six requesters for FBI documents under the freedom of Information Act in America is the inmate of a prison and two in five requesters for information from the Drug Enforcement Administration are inmates of prison, all seeking to piece together information about the police's sources of information concerning them. The result is that the FBI complains that State, local and foreign law- enforcement agencies, let alone private citizens, have become increasingly reluctant to co-operate with the FBI through the fear of the facts involved in their co-operation being disclosed. One may argue that the FBI is being self- serving in this line of criticism but one has to give its complaint due weight.

Clause 37 of the Bill before us has done this and has given this complaint due weight. It not only exempts documents which would prejudice a fair trial or put lives at risk but also-to overcome the risks in the American practice of disclosing associated information in segregable portions-exempts the documents which could reasonably be expected to do so. Clause 45 also exempts documents, the disclosure of which would be a breach of confidence. This, it seems to me, is another example of learning from American experience and tightening exemptions in relation to police investigations of crime.

To give one last example, one should consider the criticisms made by the US defence and security organisations of their 1974 law and compare that law with clause 33 of the Bill before us, Parts VI and VII and the Schedules. Spokesmen for the CIA and the National Security Council have repeatedly attacked the 1974 law in terms similar to those made by spokesmen for the FBI and, in particular, the role of the courts in requiring these government agencies to diclose publicly in court documents they claim to be exempt so that the courts may assess the claim-in other words, defeating the claim to exemption whilst purporting to judge it.
Sitting suspended from 6.1 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was comparing the Freedom of Information Bill before this House with its model, the United States Freedom of Information Act, as amended in 1974. I was making the point that this Bill, while following the model in its essential details, departed from the American model in the light of the criticisms that have been made of the American 1974 law and the defects in it that had emerged in the years since. I was just referring to the criticisms of the American law by the United States defence and security organisations. I would continue to make the point that the Bill before us meets those criticisms by exempting the relevant security and defence documents on the basis of a ministerial certificate; that it exempts security agencies in the schedules and, while providing for a document review tribunal, limits its powers.

SPEECH.PARA: These provisions are also attempts to avoid the American abuse of that country' s Freedom of Information Act. They may well go too far. I think that they may do so. But we have the Attorney-General's assurance in another place that after a period of between one year and three years these measures will be reviewed and possibly amended. I am sure that they will be amended. But at least it can be said that they achieve the object of providing freedom of information while avoiding the defects in the American arrangements.

To sum up, the Bill before us sets out to strike the balance between openness and confidentiality that avoids the mistakes made in America-mistakes in particular in relation to costs, diversion of departmental resources, and the disclosure of business, police, defence and security information. It is fair to say that on those grounds the American model for this measure has been very trenchantly criticised. This Bill meets those criticisms. If the Americans struck a balance too much in favour of disclosure, it may be that this Bill strikes a balance too much in favour of confidentiality. We shall see.

When it becomes law, this legislation will obviously be constantly monitored and I believe that there will be amendments to encourage greater openness while still avoiding the American excesses. I hope I have shown that the Opposition's uncritical reliance-one might even call it hypocritical reliance-on the American model is naive and ingenuous. The American law is, indeed, a model-a great one, but one that also has serious defects. The bill before us is, in any case, an historic first step that deserves support and fair trial as a very progressive experiment.

We could take the Opposition's criticisms more seriously if it were also using its influence in the State Labor parties to introduce State freedom of information laws. The New South Wales Labor Government for example, will not look at a State freedom of information Act. The Liberal Government of Victoria has such a Bill before its Parliament-and an excellent Bill it is. I need not mention the provinces of Canada, particularly Ontario-even Canada itself. But the New South Wales Labor Government will not look at what all advanced communities have under review.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Lionel Bowen), attacked the Bill before us with great passion, but one wishes that he would persuade the New South Wales Government to take some action . It has, after all, Professor Wilenski's draft of a freedom of information Bill , but ignores it. The New South Wales Labor Government could take the Bill before us as a model and improve on it if it could.

It would be of great value, and a great public service, to have freedom of information access to the records of the Electricity Commission of New South Wales, to see how that Commission and the State Government have bungled electricity production in that State. We know why. We know it is because of the 35-hour working week that the State Government introduced in the electricity industry. We know that it is because the Government has gone behind the back of management to make sweetheart deals directly with the union, despite management policy, and we know it is because the Labor Government of New South Wales has raided and used up the cash reserves of the Electricity Commission so that it is unable to finance maintenance, which has fallen off over the past two or three years and has led to the crisis that New South Wales is now facing.

We know this, but it would be of great help and in the public interest to have the citizen's right of access to the records. However, the Labor Government of New South Wales would not dream of giving the citizen access to these records. He would then have documented evidence of the mismanagement and bungling of electricity production in New South Wales by the Labor Government of that State.

The Victorian Government has introduced, and has before the Parliament, the sort of legislation that will allow the Victorian people to have access to such records, but the New South Wales Government will not contemplate that, for obvious reasons, because the sort of legislation that we have before us now, that the Victorian Government has introduced and that the Liberal Party of New South Wales is committed to introducing when returned to government there, would expose the humbug and sham of the most secretive government in Australia- possibly the most secretive in Australia's history-the Labor Government of New South Wales.

It would be a wonderful thing in New South Wales to have access not just to information about the Electricity Commission but also to the records of the Department of Main Roads in order to see how the labor Government of New South Wales has bungled the freeway policy in New South Wales and the traffic situation there. It would be a wonderful thing to have access to the Education Department's records to see how it has bungled education policy in New South Wales. I need not mention the records of the Department of Corrective Services, from which we could see the bungling of the prison system of New South Wales.

Would it not be of great help to have access to the Premier's Department's records in New South Wales? That would really be a horrifying, but salutary, measure. Would it not, again, be of great help to have access to the records of the Health Department, to see the bungling in relation to hospitals in New South Wales, or access to the records of the Department of Industrial Relations to examine its dealings with the unions in New South Wales which have led, through its appeasement, to the strikes and the dissolution of civil life that we see in the State?

Would it not be of great value to have access to the records of the Department of Industrial Development in order to examine the smelter policy in Hunter Valley which, because of the crude location of smelters, will destroy the great and historic wine industry in New South Wales?

Those are the sort of things that a Freedom of Information Act in New South Wales would give to the people of that State, but these phoneys on the other side of the chamber, while asking for a better freedom of information Act than the legislation before the House now, are doing absolutely nothing to urge the New South Wales Government to introduce such legislation. Indeed, the New South Wales Government has gone even further and has introduced the notorious Evidence Act to prevent the disclosure in the courts of government information which has been available for years, despite the historic Sankey v. Whitlam case of 1979, and despite the condemnation of the Senate Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, including the condemnation of the Labor Shadow Attorney-General of the Government of New South Wales.

If the Labor Party is serious in its criticism, it could do something about its own government in the benighted State of New South Wales. The Labor Party's criticism of this measure can only be described, once again, as always, as hypocritical and fraudulent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is unfortunate, on an occasion when we are discussing a Bill of some importance and about which there is a measure of agreement, that the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) chooses to demean both himself and the debate by alleging that the standards by which we judge the merits or demerits of this legislation are to be determined by the actions of a government in another State of a political complexion that is different from his. I say to the honourable gentleman that if he looks at the history of State governments and State bureaucracies, he will find that they are all very much like the Commonwealth institutions and its bureaucracies; they are all very much products of their own history and tradition.

SPEECH.PARA: Having spent many years in the Parliament of Victoria, I believe in one of the simple systems that came down from the Westminster system-that any member in the Parliament had a right to ask for a government file. The tradition of that Parliament, which was honoured when I was there, was that, unless there was some compelling reason for security, or if perhaps some sensitive negotiations pertained to the file, the file was made available. It was laid on the table of the library and made available to all honourable members. That is one of the better traditions of the Victorian Parliament. It has been honoured by governments of all political colours. If other State parliaments are not as good , that can quite properly be the subject of comment in terms of their tradition and practice. I believe that the Victorian system has much to commend it, for this very simple reason.

In the final analysis, in contemporary society, given the growth of government and the responsibilities that fall upon parliamentary institutions and individual members of Parliament, why should not a member of Parliament on behalf of one of his citizens, if that citizen believes he is being affected by a decision made within the bureaucracy, have access to the files which in many ways affect the rights and liberties of that citizen? It is not just true about this Government; it is part of the tradition and the way in which the Commonwealth Parliament has evolved. The real struggle against this legislation has not been merely within sections of the Government parties; the real struggle has been waged by one of the most centralised bureaucracies that exists anywhere in the Western democratic system.

As a new boy to this place I had the experience of asking for a file in respect of a government factory which was being closed down in my electorate. The Minister at the time, who was also a Victorian but a new Minister, was perfectly happy to make the file available. I came to Canberra for the purpose of going through the file because, as the local member, I believed it was important for me to know the basis upon which the Government had made a decision which could affect the livelihoods of some 150 people. The Minister was perfectly co- operative, but when I arrived here I was told that I could not see the file because the relevant public servant, the man who handled it and had his fingerprints on it, was not available to come with the file. I said: 'I did not come here to see the public servant; I came to see the file.' After a number of exchanges, and a telephone conversation with the Minister in which I reminded him of his undertaking, the Minister insisted upon the file being made available . It was brought over by two very senior public servants who were thoroughly embarrassed.

The reason that nonsense went on for something like four or five hours was not because of any opposition from the Minister, who acted throughout this time in a thoroughly principled manner; it was because the permanent head of his Department felt a complete sense of outrage that a Minister would dare to make a file available to a member of Parliament without the knowledge of the permanent head, and also because the permanent head was not too happy about some of the contents in the file. That is the essence of the struggle being waged in this Parliament; it is the essence, I think, of some of the problems in the whole relationship between this Parliament, its members and the bureaucracy. Quite frankly, before we got to the stage of this legislation, I would have preferred to see how this Parliament would have gone as a parliamentary institution had we adopted the very simple principle which operated for years in the Victorian State Parliament, and which was honoured by Ministers and members alike-while I was in that institution it was not, to my knowledge, the subject of any abuse- whereby a member as of right asked for a file to be laid on the table of the library and, unless there was some security reason or sensitivity in terms or perhaps current commercial negotiations for it not to be made available, it was made available.

That system established the proper relationship between the member and the Minister, but, more importantly, it established the proper relationship between the member and the bureaucracy. In the final analysis, although a bureaucrat may have been unhappy with the system, he understood both the role of the parliamentarian and the parliamentarian's role in the scheme of our governmental processes. What I believe is destroying any concept of effective federalism in Australia today is the fact that, because Australian society is growing larger, government at every level is growing larger. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) may say he wants to cut back, but the reality is that, at both State and Commonwealth government levels, the bureaucracy is growing. Therefore, as a parliamentary institution, we need continually to ask ourselves how the Parliament operates, in order to establish a proper relationship between members , the Executives and the bureaucracy.

Quite frankly, it is one of my profound regrets that, in terms of Commonwealth institutions and Commonwealth bureaucracy, the rights of the average member in the Federal Parliament have been continuously eroded and demeaned. There would not be a permanent head who would not fall over at the mere thought of having to produce a file. Every day we deal with transactions, some of which affect businessmen and some of which affect individual citizens. In the final analysis, the bureaucracy does not believe that it ought to be subjected to that kind of simple exposure which, if all is in order, ought to be part of the due process of government.

Government decisions can be made which affect our rights as citizens. A decision may be made about a pension entitlement or it may be that some Government department has decided to build a road through someone's front room. It may be that some Government department wants to have access to someone's property for public purposes. Why in such situations is not an individual and his member of Parliament entitled as of right to have available to them all the documents so that the basis upon which a decision has been made can be fully examined? We are not running some kind of secret society. The concept of government in our democracy is a concept by which we see governmnt as an instrument that serves the people. Therefore, we must strive continuously to create within the framework of our political institutions a degree of responsibility that gives to the member of the Parliament and to our citizens inalienable rights both against the process of government and the functions of the Executive but, more importantly, against the bureaucracy which, by its very growth patterns must, by its very nature, be making decisions which affect citizens in all sorts of ways in the normal operations of their lives.

What is disappointing to me and to my Party about this Bill is that there comes a time when one says: Is this a good Bill or a bad Bill? What is the basis for comparison? What is the standard by which we judge it? With respect to the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) it is not, in my view, a proper procedure to compare it with an American or a British system. Given the way in which the Commonwealth has evolved, in a sense we have to act in terms of our own principles and our own guidelines. The standard of and the judgment about this Bill have to be determined by the work that was done by what I believe is one of the most competent of standing committees which examined it. I am talking about the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which, in its 1979 report on freedom of information, established what it believed were the essential ingredients and the proper boundaries and principles upon which a Freedom of Information Bill ought to be founded. That is the starting point.

Does any member on this side of the House say that the Committee perhaps was a little too radical? Its composition was like any other Senate standing committee ; it represented the balance of the Senate. It has been my experience that when a group of experienced parliamentarians come together on an issue such as this they tend to make fairly balanced recommendations. Paragraph 3.7 of the report states:

The essence of democratic government lies in the ability of people to make choices: about who shall govern; or about which policies they support or reject. Such choices cannot be properly made unless adequate information is available. It cannot be accepted that it is the government itself which should determine what level of information is to be regarded as adequate.

That is the sentiment that I believe this Parliament can readily endorse and enshrine. One can express only disappointment when comparing the recommendations of the Senate Committee with the legislation that is now before us. When one looks at the heads which are involved in this Bill, one can only reach the conclusion that, whilst the Government has taken some steps and has established some framework and procedures, it has not been prepared to accept the spirit or the terms of the recommendations of the Senate inquiry report.

It is important if we as community and as a parliamentary institution are to make decisions about the future of this nation that we should do so on the basis of being properly and effectively informed. As you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would know from your experience sitting in the chair, there is no member in any part of this House who does not have a political philosophy and does not hold his views somewhat strongly. We saw some examples of that this morning. The very strength by which views and prejudices are held make it very important, if we are to make the right decisions, to do so on the basis of all the information being available. The tragic fact is that in so many areas information is not merely not made available but it has to be gouged out of the bureaucratic process.

Let me give the House two simple examples with which I am personally involved. As a member of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, I am interested in the defence structure of this community. We have just produced a report which states that the real threat to Australia is the problem of involvement in nuclear war. We reached conclusions about the presence of joint American bases within Australia. The reality is that no effective information is contained within this Parliament as to the nature or the operation of those bases upon which an informed and rational debate can take place. Any member of this Parliament who wanted to inform himself about the nature and the structure of those important facilities could get more information out of the American congressional records than from his own government. That is the reality; we accept it.

I refer now to an important book produced by Dr Ball. Honourable members might agree or disagree with the conclusions; it does not matter. The significant contribution of Dr Ball was that at least he produced, in concise form, the only real information which is available to any member of this Parliament. How can we have informed debate if that is to be the level of information? No department in my view has excessively used and abused the concept of security for the purpose of seeing that this parliament is not properly informed than the Department of Defence. I cite my own experience with, and involvement on behalf of, young Vietnam veterans who had been affected by exposure to defoliants in Vietnam. At every point the information needed from the Department of Veterans' Affairs has taken two years to be supplied. Question after question has been asked. Most of the answers have been more significant for what they fail to admit and for their attempts to avoid providing evidence. We are dealing with individual rights. I have set out the history and the tradition that has developed within the bureaucratic structures that are related to the Commonwealth.

I for one believe that, if this Parliament is ever to play an effective role so that once again it becomes an institution where real debate takes place and where individual members have a capacity to protect the rights of one individual citizen and to argue his cause in a way which compels the attention of not merely the Ministry but also the bureaucracy, we must take our role seriously and ensure that we have the best information available. It is time that this Parliament was sufficiently mature to deal with whatever political crisis it has to deal with on the basis of information being freely available and not on the basis of documents falling off the backs of trucks. In my opinion that has been the basis upon which this parliament has operated for far too long. That is the nature of the process. It is time we all agreed that we have to so structure ourselves that we do not need the secret document and can dispense with the leak . As an institution we are capable of solving the great issues that face this nation if we have the best information available.

My regret about this legislation is that the unique opportunity given to move this institution forward was not accepted. Any honourable member who views the legislation honestly can feel nothing but disappointment when he compares it with the details of the Senate Select Committee report. We need, therefore, to try again and to do better.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Freedom of Information Bill which is one of the more unusual proposals put before this Parliament. It marks a substantial departure from the practice of some centuries of Westminster tradition in legislation. It is therefore a measure that needs to be introduced with some caution. There has been much debate on it. There has been a very good inquiry by a Senate committee. There is some argument whether more of the recommendations made by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs should have been adopted by the Government. I think that members of my own party have made quite substantial speeches and put forward powerful arguments to say that the Government perhaps should have gone further than it has in accepting amendments. Nonetheless, the Government has accepted a number of amendments to the legislation. It is a better Bill than the one that was first laid on the table. It has been the subject of considerable analysis by members of both Houses and it is also, of course, subject to review, according to the Government, after about three years of its being in force. The Government has also undertaken to review after 12 months operation the question whether additional access might be given to documents already in existence at the time the legislation came into force.

SPEECH.PARA: So I think the House should consider the legislation as a Bill that treads into new areas in our system. With reasonable goodwill we can all watch closely what its effects are. I have certain concerns about how far it goes. It marks an important departure from previous practice and will give great opportunity to those who take a genuine interest in the workings of our democracy to examine, perhaps in more detail, how that democracy works, to suggest improvements in the way the democracy works and to suggest improvements in the way this legislation gives us access to the workings of the democracy.

There is a real question as to how far we should go in the first instance in using essentially an American idea within the Westminster system. The Americans have tended to pioneer this kind of legislation. They have done it with that peculiar ferocity of which we know they are capable. The American republic, which is a great democracy, is given to extremes of enthusiasm on occasions and the Americans often take a lot of working out. We have had the opportunity of observing what they do. As my colleague the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) has pointed out, there are various ways in which we have been able to learn from their experience.

Equally, I would say that we have been able to learn from the experience of the Westminster system that we have inherited. I would say that for this day and age the old Westminster system is totally unsatisfactory in its capacity to provide adequate information for the sensible discussion of public issues. It is certainly true that the Westminster system, with Cabinet responsibility and a great deal of secrecy attached to the workings of Cabinet and of Government, has provided a barrier against destructive interference with those processes. But it has also, in a very complicated modern world, led to an obstruction of serious analysis. I am afraid that in some of the derivative parliaments of Westminster it has led to even greater obstruction than perhaps was intended or is practised in the Mother of Parliaments. There is a certain measure of civilisation in the discussion of issues in Westminster which is not always followed in the derivative parliaments, particularly perhaps when one goes into the derivative State parliaments. I will have something to say a little later about an area where enlightenment ought to have occurred but seems not to have done so.

I would like to refer to issues in respect of which it would be better to have a more informed discussion. I have been involved in a number of these areas. I think we can all sympathise with the experience recounted earlier this evening by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) when he was given access, he thought, to documents by a Minister who considered that as the documents related to the honourable member's electorate it was sensible that the honourable member should be allowed to look at them. He considered there was nothing terribly secret about them. But the decision of the Minister was not taken very kindly by the departmental head concerned and there was a clamp-down on information which was overcome only by reference back to the Minister's instruction. That is a fairly common procedure. Ministers fresh from the back benches where they suffered the frustrating experience of finding it difficult to get information would have some sympathy for back bench attempts to break down some of this departmental exclusion. In most cases it is exercised in good faith by people who believe they are guardians of something that is purer than democracy itself. That is very hard to combat because there is almost a theological basis for this belief and it is very hard to break down.

There are problems in defining the access that one can give to public documents . There is the problem, for example, that access itself affects the nature of the information available. Of course, there is a good side to that in that if one insists that documents prepared by public servants are going to be made available the people who are preparing them and who are working through the problems that will subsequently by publicised will be that much more careful about being straightforward in their dealings and being totally honest in their analysis. That certainly is the good side of this kind of legislation and it is the one that its proponents are always arguing in favour of.

Equally, there are some bad consequences of this promised access. One is that people can be more timid in action if they are in the process of making decisions which are documented and that documentation will be available to the public. Timidity is not always a good attribute when one is examining difficult issues. Indeed, the kinds of issues we face in today's world as they become more and more complicated often require more daring action than is contemplated by entrepreneurs in the private sector and that kind of action is not such that, when documented, it will always look good in public scrutiny afterwards. So that is a difficulty. The legislation probably will breed timidity if in fact all the important actions are recorded. That leads to the second problem; that is, that the promise of access to everybody after the event might lead to a certain deviousness in recording, that the box that one opens in the hope of having exposed to one all the innermost thoughts of those who decided various things or examined various things may not contain anything of any value whatsoever and that most of the transactions and thoughts that went on were left out for the very reason that people engaging in those activities did not welcome subsequent scrutiny.

So there is a bit of a problem in that the kind of thing we are really looking to find out may in fact cease to exist in any real form in a number of instances once we enact the legislation. I ask people not to dismiss that as frivolous; I think it is quite a natural thing. I can think of very many cases both in the ordinary course of day-to-day administration and in dealing with quite difficult problems, some of them very personal and some of them very sensitive, where people would rather act and not record or where people might record something which they thought was more palatable to posterity. This is something which is well known, of course, in respect of memoirs that are written by politicians. Politicians have the advantage of writing these things well after the event with a very firm eye on posterity and their own reputations. What is written, of course, is very much for the public eye and has to be regarded very much with scepticism when compared with the writings of others which are perhaps equally subject to scepticism. So there is a bit of a problem. It is analogous in my mind to registers of public interest by politicians or public officials whereby such people are legally required to register their public interests. There is absolutely no doubt that such a register would disclose to the world at large the interests of those who are honest. But there is no guarantee that the interests of those who are dishonest would be disclosed to the world at large. The Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) has said on a number of occasions that one cannot legislate for honour; that honour is either there in the first place or it is not. A register of public interests is something that makes a lot of people feel happy but if one delves beyond the surface of it one really wonders whether it is anything other than a protection for those who are dishonest.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be a start.
—I think that the honourable member will concede that there is some measure of truth in what I am saying. It is not a simple subject.
—One would not preclude the other.

—It would not preclude it. I have no particular problem about such arrangement except in relation to spouses and so on and the honourable member would know about all of those problems. But it nonetheless has certain difficulties in that it can provide a veneer of respectability for crooks and that is the main worry I have with it. Whether that is a greater harm than not having one is a matter that the honourable member for Batman and I could discuss at some stage at greater length.

SPEECH.PARA: On balance I think this legislation is a sensible start and since I have a very great interest in the more civilized and sensible discussion of critical issues that affect the future of this Commonwealth I certainly welcome the opportunity to look at more information from the public sector than I currently have available to me as a back bencher. In general I am very much in favour of this first relatively tentative step. I do not carp at the various exclusions, although I could, as did the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) who made some remarks on this earlier. I would tend to agree with him because it is pretty hard to understand why in the Schedules certain exempt agencies appear in Part I and others appear in Part II. For example, the Australian Egg Board is exempt in relation to documents in respect of its competitive commercial activities yet the Australian Shipping Commission is an exempt agency in toto. I find it a little difficult to understand why, for example, one agency is exempt in one part and not the other. These are relatively minor criticisms.

The actual boundary of the legislation, that is, how much of the recommendations of the Senate Committee have been accepted or not, is a matter which can be determined over the course of two or three years of re-examination. When one looks at how important this kind of legislation is in the history of the Commonwealth one sees that these are relatively carping criticisms. Consequently I will not shed blood in re-examining the Government's acceptance of amendments or otherwise. I am quite happy to accept what has been accepted, to get on with it and to see how it works.

There is another area in which I think we have to be careful. There are exclusions based on quite important considerations. I do not think anybody at first sight would disagree with these. The exclusions, that is the exempt documents, include documents affecting national security, defence, international relations and relations with the States. The definitions are in the Bill. The exclusions also include Cabinet documents; Executive Council documents; internal working documents; documents affecting enforcement of the law and the protection of public safety; documents to which secrecy provisions of enactments apply-that is in respect of certain legislation-documents affecting financial or property interests of the Commonwealth; documents concerning certain operations of agencies-I have referred to those which appear in the Schedule-documents affecting personal privacy; documents affecting legal proceedings or subject to legal professional privilege; documents relating to business affairs and so on; documents affecting the national economy; documents containing material obtained in confidence; documents the disclosure of which would be contempt of parliament or contempt of court; and certain documents arising out of companies and securities legislation.

There is quite a long list of documents to be excluded for reasons which, if one looks at them, one will see are fairly sound. But there is of course the question of classification of such documents. Again one should look into the future. We are talking about the classification of documents that will exist in the future, and the legislation does not apply retrospectively for the moment although it may do when we re-examine it in 12 months time. There is a danger that documents can be written in such a way that they let intrude matters which may not be directly relevant but which might bring them into one of these excluded or exempt categories. I think that is a problem. There is provision for appeal and having a look at this. This is important and perhaps this area could be strengthened. It is terribly important that people within the Public Service or even Ministers directing people within the Public Service are not in a position to include in documents matters which bring them within exempt categories. For example, if we are talking about matters affecting relationships between the Commonwealth and the States it is not beyond the wit of almost anybody to include in a document something which might affect the relationships between the Commonwealth and the States and for that to be argued. I think that is something we have to watch.

Sometimes when one raises this kind of question people say: 'Are you questioning the integrity of Ministers or of public servants?' All I know is that in view of the pace of modern administration, the volume of matters that come before Ministers, the tiny length of time that Ministers have to reflect on anything-given the incredible pace at which they have to work-the extraordinary number of things they have to do and also the absurd restrictions on their activities which are brought about by the ridiculous Standing Orders of this House, I think it is well to be careful of the kinds of pressures that can be put on Ministers or things which can be slipped past Ministers which might bring documents into an exempt category unwittingly on the part of a Minister, perhaps wittingly on the part of those who put it before the Minister or the other way around. One always has to legislate for an unsatisfactory case. To legislate always for the best cases and the most honourable motives or the most leisurely consideration of things is to make an error. One should legislate knowing that there are tremendous pressures on these people and therefore they should be protected by legislation just as much as the public ought to be protected in terms of this access to information.

All that having been said I ask the Opposition to treat with some gentleness the matter of amendments and the boundary between what parts of the Senate Committee's recommendations have been accepted and what have been rejected. After all, we are not all absolutely clean in these matters. As my colleague the honourable member for Wentworth pointed out in his speech earlier tonight, the Government of the State of which I am a citizen has been in office for some five years and it has not yet legislated for freedom of information to be allowed to the citizens of New South Wales. It was very distressing, I must say, for me today to read in my local newspaper the Sydney Morning Herald report on the Premier of New South Wales. It stated:
