. . . it was not the Government's policy to table internal reports, but he was prepared to let Mr Dowd see it if he agreed not to reveal its contents.
Mr Wran was referring to a report commissioned by a previous Premier, Mr Tom Lewis, on the Electricity Commission of New South Wales which is a matter of very considerable public concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was to protect the former Liberal Premier.

—My friend the honourable member for Hunter says that was to protect the former Liberal Premier; it was not. It is beyond my belief that the current Premier of New South Wales would wish to protect a Liberal predecessor. I can merely say that if this report is as supportive of the New South Wales Government, as he claims it is, the obvious way to prove that is to make it public. But also I think that to adopt the recommendations of Professor Peter Wilenski as regards the freedom of information legislation would give a very good lead to the Labor Party and to the New South Wales members of the Labor Party in this House who are somewhat muted in their criticisms of the Government in this case because of the failure of their State Labor Government to introduce legislation which has anything approaching the value of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have just heard quite a thoughtful speech with that characteristic tendency to understatement that one gets from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). I did agree wholeheartedly with his introductory remarks when he pointed out that the Westminster system-I think I quote him more or less accurately-has proved to be completely inadequate in providing for effective discussion of public issues, and it is partly to that theme that I want to direct my remarks tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that ought to unite honourable members on both sides of the House, as I think the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) pointed out, is our commitment to democracy. Whether we be liberals or democratic socialists, we are supposed to be committed to democracy. This commitment, of course, is critical in terms of the kinds of complex issues that we are confronted with in modern society. I will begin by quoting from Tony Wedgwood Benn who sometimes is painted as something of a radical socialist. He made some introductory remarks within the context of a lecture on the subject of Democracy in the Age of Science. He stated:

The relationship between Science and Democracy is central to any discussion about the future. Unless they can be reconciled power may be abused, and the development of knowledge may be restricted. My thesis is that secrecy is the great enemy of democracy and science, and the key to the advance of both lies in the wider spread of knowledge. It is in the joint interest of the scientific community and the general body of citizens to formulate such clear demands for greater openness, and to press for them with such strength, that the present tradition of secrecy is broken down and replaced by an open system offering freedom of information. This is necessary if we are to reveal the issues, and the choices that are available, so that individual citizens may exercise their judgment upon them, and press their policies according to their interests and opinions within our democratic system.
He continues:

The choice between the private and the public ownership of knowledge is a major scientific and political issue . . . Science and the scientific method, engineering and applied technology now permeate every part of a modern society. But they have also helped to create great power-and the organisations which control it-for good or ill. If the men and women who are now in charge of those big organisations-be they governmental, industrial or financial-are successful in shrouding their thinking, decisions and their policies in secrecy then it could be that the resources of science and engineering which they command could enslave humanity instead of liberating it. And if mankind is excluded from understanding the knowledge which is now available he will be deprived of his inheritance.

What Benn is getting at is that one needs to look at the question of freedom of information not only within the context of the scientific revolution and the rapidly changing march of technology, but also within a social context and a political context. This legislation which we are looking at tonight is a response, perhaps inadequate, but nevertheless a response which is necessary primarily because of the growing concentration of power in modern society and the inter-relationship between various powerful institutions, whether they be economic, political or military in their essence.

We have the existence in modern society of what C. Wright Mills called the power elite; what President Eisenhower called the military industrial complex; or the technostructure or the managerial class in the thought of J. K. Galbraith . It is an immense concentration of power; indeed, the interlocking of elites in modern society which makes some kind of freedom of information legislation-we hope rather stronger legislation than this-not a choice but an absolute necessity. Furthermore, the possibility of the corruption of that establishment reinforces this necessity.

The example of Richard Nixon behind the veil of secrecy which governs affairs of high state reveals that the body politic can be absolutely rotten. This fact can be hidden from ordinary people-indeed, hidden as it was in the case of Nixon from the whole society. We have had in this Parliament some glimpses-perhaps not quite as widespread and not quite as devastating as in the case of Nixon-of the way that our establishment is affected by corruption even in the example of Asia Dairy Industries scandal. Even to dig out that particular example required what has amounted to a major research project.

Unlike the United States, we do not have the diversity which is present in the United States media nor do we have the muck-raking tradition which enables journalists to pursue a matter when they sense there is a hint of scandal. Further, we have a different tradition of law which means that people are dissuaded from speaking of facts of which they may not be entirely sure by the very strict laws of libel. In addition, the honourable member for Mackellar alluded to the fact that within the traditions of the Westminster system with its heavy emphasis on ministerial responsibility and the entrenched tradition of parliamentary government it is often difficult to properly examine matters which are essential to government decision-making processes. This will often illustrate the inter-relationship between government and other dimensions of society, such as the economic dimension and the military. In this respect the parliament has in terms of its capacity, to throw up information and to illuminate what is really happening in society. How real decisions are made has become a kind of a farce played out for the benefit of members of the Press gallery who write more of the theatre than they do of the substantive issues involved. Few parliamentarians are able to break through the barriers which exist to reveal the underlying issues.

We are aware of departments within this Parliament only barely through glimpses of public servants advising Ministers on the other side of the House. Face to face communication with the mandarins of the Australian Public Service is extremely rare and, when it does occur, is quite superficial. When such people do appear before committees their loyalty is to Ministers in the 'Yes, Minister' tradition. They are not anxious to have parliament scrutinise the actual operations of their departments. In this Westminster tradition we have developed a tradition not of freedom of information but a limitation of information, not of revealing the truth to people but excluding, parliamentarians perhaps especially, from access to the truth. We have inherited a situation where public servants in preparing submissions for parliamentary committees do so in a way which is devoid of any hard information but is often couched in a bureaucratic language and style designed to confirm Ministers in the view that the department which they administer will never be the subject of controversy and will never ruin an argument with a hard fact.

There is no doubt that we need legislation which is designed to free up decision making so that ordinary people can get access to the kind of information they need to assess decisions or even-and in this Parliament one almost says: 'Perish the thought'-proposed new directions in which policies or programs might be directed. We have nothing like the capacity which is present in the United States congressional system of committees for committees to be presented with initiatives, programs and ideas on the way fundamental problems that face our society might be resolved.

This legislation before us is not to be totally rejected. It clearly takes us in some of the direction that is required. The trick that is always employed by the honourable member for Mackellar whenever he speaks is to suggest that any progress, no matter how small, no matter how minimal that one might identify on the Government side, indicates that somehow in the end it will finish up in the right direction. This is a government which survives very largely because of its capacity for public relations and very largely because of its capacity to delude people into thinking that something which is devised for the purpose of reassuring people represents any kind of substantial initiative. It has been clear in terms of the debate that has taken place over a very long period over the freedom of information legislation that rather than this legislation being devised to deal with the fundamental problems which exist for ordinary people in our community to get access to information-not only existing information but also to have information put together for them so that unrelated facts are seen to have the significance which they really do have-that this legislation in fact represents tokenism. It represents simply a very small step in a direction which would require a very large step and very strong initiatives to have any impact.

I go back to the point that I began with: It is not as though power is relatively dispersed in our society; power in our society is heavily concentrated and there are very close interrelationships between the various elements of the power structure. A power elite does exist. I do not include the honourable member for Mackellar in that. He may well be part of the power structure of the Liberal Party of Australia represented on the other side of the chamber, but on the other hand he may not. Clearly most backbenchers on the other side of the chamber are not. Power in this Parliament is concentrated in the hands of a very small number of Ministers indeed. They exercise power and co -operation with sections of the Public Service and, no doubt, with sections of economic establishments and other interests outside in the community. We live in a society in which there are very few actors in the crucial game of deciding what the direction of our society will be in the future.

If the Government were serious about this it would require very strong legislation. What we have is very weak legislation. What we have is, indeed, a situation in which so many of the recommendations made by a bipartisan inquiry conducted by the Senate, presumably agreed to by both sides in the Senate, were put aside by that small elite inside the Cabinet that makes the decisions about the direction in which this Liberal-National Country Party Government will proceed. Then, quite unbelievably, as Senator Evans has pointed out, notwithstanding the failure of the Government to accept recommendations, the Government in its new Bill has introduced a whole series of new restrictions and prohibitions on the freedom of information.

I think the honourable member for Mackellar concedes that they include a substantial broadening of exemptions prohibiting documents on law enforcement issues, trade secrets and business information and information on matters related to the national economy and internal administrative efficiency being covered by the provisions of the legislation and the specific adoption, without limitation, of all existing secrecy provisions in other legislation. They include an extraordinary new power in agencies to refuse even to retrieve and examine a document when the document as described in the request appears to be exempt. They include a complete exclusion from the provisions of the Bill of 24 specific agencies, many of which have no commercial or sensitive intelligence functions, including the Auditor-General's Office, the Health Insurance Commission, the Aboriginal Lands Trust and 15 other agencies in respect of their competitive commercial activities and all external territories. They include vesting a new power in agencies to refuse disclosure of a non-exempt portion of a document if it would be misleading. They include vesting in the Minister an unappealable power to prevent an agency from compiling documented indexes if that would unreasonably divert its resources from other operations.

I go on very briefly to refer to an example which I think fits into the context of what I said when I began this speech, when I referred to the fact that what we are talking about is a society in which power is concentrated, a society which is undergoing rapid scientific and technological change. Let us simply take the example that has been thrown up and has been before this Parliament. It is associated with the chemical industry. I refer to agent orange. We see what a struggle it has been to have information released, even when people who have been affected by a substance have a necessity to gain access to information to establish the causes of their illness. In the post-War period we have produced thousands of new chemicals. Most of the chemicals which have been introduced into commercial use have been untested for their effects on health. They have simply been introduced on the basis that they are commercial chemicals that are of some use. They have not been tested by the companies concerned. They have not been subjected in Australia to an examination by any agency.

The outstanding example of a dangerous substance which is in use in the community and which has been before the Parliament is that of 2,4,5-T. It contains dioxin, which many people believe has lethal side effects. That has been argued by the Vietnam veterans who were sprayed with agent orange. I ask a question. It is a test question that perhaps others can answer. In what way will this Bill provide, for example, the war veterans with the freedom they require to get the facts they need to establish even whether they were sprayed with dangerous chemicals in Vietnam? What access have they been able to gain to documents within the Department of Defence which would show what was known in the Department of Defence or any other government departments at the time of the Vietnam war of the dangers associated with that chemical? I believe that, in that kind of case, this legislation, if enacted, will make very little difference. I believe that this legislation will not enable veterans to gain, for example, access to certain Cabinet documents or even to information gathered by the Department of Defence on knowledge that was available in the late 1960s about the dangers surrounding the chemicals associated with agent orange.

No doubt the problem which has been established in the case of the Vietnam veterans has its parallels in the case of people exposed in a domestic situation to dangerous chemicals, perhaps even to the chemicals to which I have been referring. I refer, for example, to information that will be available on the nature of chemicals contained in certain herbicides which no doubt are being used by farmers right across the country. What in this legislation will enable farm workers spraying with herbicides to gain access to information which will tell them even what constituents of chemicals are contained in herbicides with which they might be involved and which, indeed, might have been proved in the United States of America to have been extremely dangerous? The reason why the agent orange inquiry is not being pursued and the reason why this legislation does not go to the heart of the matter is not really commercial secrecy, although that is a clue; it is the fact that behind agent orange, behind the chemical industry and behind this legislation is a government that is unwilling to invade, if you like, the territory of capital. We read again and again of commercial secrets. The commercial activities of government are excluded from the provisions of this legislation because this Government is not willing to apply against the commercial enterprises the rules of democracy which it espouses in general. It is not prepared to talk about economic democracy. It is not prepared to talk about industrial democracy. It is not prepared to talk about freedom of information for ordinary people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can recall no legislation that has come before this Parliament in recent years which has been the subject of such intense level of debate, not only here in both Houses of the Parliament but also in the community at large. In every sense of the word, the introduction of freedom of information legislation is unique, not only in Australia but also in the Westminster concept. This is the first time in the Commonwealth that legislation of this type has been introduced in a democratic Westminster-style parliament. Those of us who have made a study of democratic developments over the past 200 years-of course, the democratic system had its genesis over 1,000 years ago- would have to conclude that in the past few years we have seen significant steps forward in the capacity of the individual to gain greater access to his rights as a citizen, especially his rights to know how the government of his country is meant to be operating.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the weakness in our traditional position has been that under the Westminster code it has been presumed that the member of Parliament is to be the essential link between the constituent and the government of the day. The realities of modern government, the problems of a very intense and complicated system of public administration, have made it quite obvious to all of us who have participated in this field that it is now no longer possible merely for members of Parliament, whatever their side of politics and whatever their capacity to get access to information, always to be in a position to look after the interests of the constituents in all fields. It is interesting, therefore, to note that it was not in the Commonwealth democratic system but rather in the United States System that the concept of freedom of information was first developed. The legislation which the Americans introduced in 1966 has demonstrated a number of very real problems. The legislation we are debating tonight is a serious attempt to address those problems with the intention of introducing a set of criteria in which the rights of the individual can be balanced against the capacity of the governmental structure to meet the legitimate needs of the citizen.

In many respects this Bill has attempted to reduce a range of problems which first came to light in the American experience. These can best be described as the problem of the administrative costs involved; the problem of the retrospectivity of information which has gone through the system in previous years; the very real problem of litigation which can be before the courts and the impact new information coming from government files could have in that context; the major problem of criminal intelligence and the capacity of those who wish to use the system for their own ends to obtain through government information which could basically be of criminal intent; the whole series of problems related to the rights of the individual, including the capacity of the individual to maintain a high level of confidentiality and personal privacy; and , above all, the problems of business confidentiality in terms of both government instrumentalities and, more than that, the private sector. The exceptions under the proposed Act are contained in clause 36 of the Bill. A series of schedules in Part IV also gives a range of exempt Commonwealth agencies which are not covered by this legislation. Later I will refer to the exemptions because, like colleagues who have spoken before me, I believe there are a number of problems in this area and I hope subsequent examination of the legislation after it has been in force for the proposed three years will give us the opportunity to make the necessary reforms.

Under the legislation as it is currently before the House the principles and objectives may be best described as being the object to extend as far as possible the right of the Australian community to have access to information in the possession of the Government of the Commonwealth by making available to the public information about the operations of departments and public authorities and, in particular, by ensuring that rules and practices affecting members of the public in their dealings with departments and public authorities are readily available to persons affected by those rules and practices. It is the desire of the Government to create a general right of access to information in documentary form in the possession of Ministers, departments and public authorities, limited only by exceptions and exemptions necessary for the protection of essential public interests and the private and business affairs of persons in respect of whom information is collected and held by departments and public authorities.

Therefore, the impact of this legislation in many ways will be of tremendous importance to the capacity of the average citizen to exercise his right to safeguard his fundamental responsibilities. The appropriate balance, however, between the openness and the need for respective confidentiality has been one of the prime motivating factors which have limited the capacity of this legislation to enter into what can best be described as a free-for-all. As an ex-civil servant and one who has spent most of his time in this Parliament involved in the administration of the Public Service, I have to say that many of the comments made by a colleague on the opposite side, the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe), have some merit in terms of the attitude and the role which the civil servant feels he has to play relevant to the safeguarding of what he believes is public information. Unfortunately, the tendency over the years has been for many civil servants deliberately to upgrade the confidentiality or secrecy provisions on papers and on files, often as not to protect them not only from the would-be snooper from outside but also, and often just as importantly, from the would-be snooper from some other department.

Of course we cannot accept the situation in which we have internecine strife and warfare in what is meant to be the efficient administration of the Commonwealth, but the fact of the matter is that this attitude of mind has been found in the past and I suspect that we will continue to see it in the future. The passage of this legislation will make officers of the Commonwealth consider very seriously what they are prepared to put down on files which may become public. I am concerned that the impact of this in certain areas could result in the creation of formal files and informal files and in a substantial increase in the telephone bill. As a matter of fact, this has already taken place in a range of departments. It has been caused essentially by the relatively modern tendency for the leak to become almost an official means of communicating with the opposition of the day. Nevertheless, the impact on the attitudes which civil servants have towards the safeguarding of information, towards the usage of information and how they will see the rights of the citizen to get access to that information, is something which this Parliament will have to continue to watch most carefully, especially over the next three years, which is essentially the trial period for this legislation. Because of the Bill's uniqueness it is obvious that after it becomes an Act some of its aspects will require examination. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) made the observation that there is also provision, after 12 months, for examination to be given to the question of whether some form of access could be devised for material which has already been filed away and which possibly has gone to the Commonwealth archives.

The cost of maintaining this kind of legislation will be very significant indeed. I do not think members of the Opposition should be prepared to pass over the reality that the cost of freedom of information must be faced by whoever is the government of the day. As a result of a congressional inquiry prior to the passage of the first United States legislation, it was optimistically believed that it would cost approximately $100,000 a year. However, after the first year of its application it was reliably estimated to have cost the United States Administration in excess of $36m. The reality we are therefore facing in Australia is this: If we are to demand access to a very wide range of information, somebody has to sift through the files, collect the relevant information, set up a bureau which can service the public and make sure the information is made available. The realities of the Public Service today, with cost cutting and the establishment of very difficult personnel ceilings and so forth, make me seriously doubt whether it will be possible, at least in the short to medium stages, to make available sufficient officers with the training and capacity to make what really will be most important decisions. In other words, how will we have the machinery in every department and in every statutory authority, except those which are subject to exemption, to make adequate information available to the community?

Nevertheless, the Government has faced the situation because it believes, it being a fundamental Liberal principle, that the Australian constituent, the elector of respective governments, has the right to get information which he regards as relevant to his own interests. That is a fundamental principle which must be protected in this legislation. The principle of openness identifies and defines those circumstances in which confidentiality should be maintained. For example, we must continue to protect personal privacy, confidential commercial information, information of vital national interest such as that involving security and defence and the conduct of government activities. Confidentiality is undoubtedly essential, particularly within the relationships inside a government, the attitudes and the assistance which may be given by civil servants to Ministers, the relationships between one Minister and another and, equally, the relationships which take place between the departments. It is essential in the maintenance of an effective governmental system that there be a level of trust between all sections of the governmental machine. If we lose that sense of trust there is no doubt that every Australian citizen will significantly lose as a result, whether he has access to information or not. The good order and government of the Commonwealth must be the principal responsibility which we must keep in mind throughout this whole operation.

As I mentioned earlier, the traditional view has been that parliament is the principal safeguarder of the people. There is no argument against that. However, in recent years, because of the complexity of government we have seen the introduction of new instrumentalities and statutory officals such as the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court of Australia. All of these instrumentalities operate under powers conferred on them by this Parliament and all in their own way, will have some responsibility to bear in terms of the administration of this legislation. For example, if a citizen is not given access to information to which he believes he has a legitimate right, whether or not it is information which has been previously the subject of a declaration by the Minister of the day of that specific department, he has the right to make approaches to the appropriate organisations established under this legislation and ultimately the right to take questions of law as high as the Federal Court of Australia.

The Freedom of Information Bill will operate on a wider scope than any existing means of obtaining information we have ever had in the past. The Bill provides the legally enforceable right of access to documented information. It is a radical change of approach from what we have seen in previous years. It will require Ministers or departments seeking to withhold information to justify their decisions to deny access to that information to the citizens by the application of criteria which are quite clearly specified in the Bill. It also imposes a positive obligation on departments and authorities to make public their organisations and structure and the functions they perform.

One thing has always concerned me as a member of this Parliament and that is the incredible lack of basic knowledge which most Australian citizens have on even the rudiments of the governmental system. We have all been confused between Federal and State members of parliament. That is something we tend to take for granted. But many citizens of Australia are even further confused about exactly what the constititutional basis of the Federal parliamentary operation may be as distinct from that of the State. I hope that with the passage of this legislation it will be possible to enter into a much deeper capacity to give to Australian citizens, schools, universities and institutions much wider scope to be able to get a better understanding of how the Australian system of government in fact operates.

I will go further and make the observation that there is really little point in the citizen saying that he lives in a democracy and little point in the citizen saying he has to vote for his representatives every three years or so if he really does not even understand the system of government under which he is meant to be administered. In recent years-this has been a trend for at least the last 100 years-we have seen the steady encroachment and growth of governmental involvement in the lives of every single citizen. Recently I was reading a book on public administration written by an American. He took the rather interesting story of a person who woke up in the morning and he followed that person through the day. Literally every single decision that person made-for example, whether he ate a poached egg in the morning, what type of car he drove, where he got his petrol, where he worked, whether he went up in a lift and where he had his lunch -and every single aspect of his life was subject to governmental decisions taken by either local government or State or Federal authorities. We tend to forget these facts.

But we also have in recent years, because of the sheer complexity of government , lost sight of the fact that as citizens we do have a responsibility to acquaint ourselves with the basic functioning of our administrative system. It is not simply enough for the citizen to take the view that he elects his representative and, therefore, he obviates any need to take any further responsibility. The ultimate responsibility of the citizen must always be the need to keep a watch, to be aware, to be interested and to keep informed. With the passage of this legislation I sincerely hope that the capacity of the citizen to keep informed, in particular, will be significantly improved.

My colleagues before me, both the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) and the honourable member for Mackellar, drew attention to the fact that with the passage of this legislation we hope that the various State governments of Australia will also see their way clear to introducing similar legislation of effect to the States. Whilst in Victoria there has been very appropriate legislation along similar lines to our own, it is a matter of great concern to me as a citizen of New South Wales that there is no freedom of informatin legislation in that State. In recent years under the Wran Government we have seen the tendency for the Government literally to take the Parliament for granted. It has become little more than a sham. It was described to me recently as being almost legislation by ambush because the Opposition is lucky if it gets two hours advance warning of legislation to be introduced into the House.

Time after time we see reports which have not been tabled. They have then been leaked from various sources which the government of the day has either denied existed or, if it does admit that they exist, it refuses to give them to anybody . As was mentioned this morning in the Sydney Morning Herald the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Dowd, was informed by the Premier, Mr Wran, that he could have access to a confidential report on the state of the Electricity Commission of New South Wales, which I understand was commissioned in about 1976, on the condition that he did not make the information public. Obviously, Mr Dowd being the Leader of the Opposition, that was an absurd request for any Premier to make of a fellow member of the Parliament. Nevertheless, this is the situation which exists in my State today. It is a scandalous situation which cannot be continued .

I would say, on the other hand, that there has been at least some improvement in terms of the establishment of a public accounts committee in that State. It has taken over five years of constant badgering to get the New South Wales Government to realise the fact that the Parliament does need effective review machinery to enable the members of the Parliament, from whatever party, to perform their constitutional responsibilities to their constituents. We have seen only in the last two days the tabling of a report on New South Wales hospitals which demonstrates that at least and at last there is a group of people who have been given the capacity to take a serious look at areas of public administration which quite obviously require very fundamental reform. But any government which thinks it can hide behind the ignorance of the public is courting disaster because ultimately the people who are not fools will see through this charade and will appreciate the fact that they have a right to know what is going on in their States. It is not good enough simply to use public servants as a protective device against the fundamental rights of the citizen.

I draw the attention of the House on this subject to the fundamental views of Lord Hailsham who drew the attention of the community to the fact that information is indeed power and that because it is power it must be diffused throughout the community. He made that view clear. It is one which I totally support and it is certainly a view which is supported by this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene in this debate very briefly just to express a few views about some of the aspects of it. The first thing I want to say about the Freedom of Information Bill, its origins and its very tenuous and tortured life to this stage is that the basic approach of this Government and, indeed, the Australian Labor Party Government which first initiated the freedom of information proposals, has been that the public servants, who are supposed to serve Government, started from the basic premise that one does not let anyone know anything if one can possibly avoid the revelation of that information. That means that if one can find any flimsy reason for concealing information one should conceal it. That is the basic approach which has continued through to the legislation that is before us tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: It starts from the premise that the information is not made available unless it is absolutely necessary to do so. Obviously the alternative approach is to say that we should let everybody know everything unless there are particular circumstances why, for very clear and agreed reasons, that information would be deleterious either to individuals or to the national interest. On reading the legislation and the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which looked at the earlier proposed legislation, one can find throughout it this basic premise that information should be withheld unless it absolutely has to be revealed.

One of the public reasons for adopting this approach which is advanced by a number of speakers-not only those who are basically opposed to freedom of information legislation but also some of those who are apparently in favour of it-is that this sort of legislation is really incompatible with the Westminster system of government, which is the system we apparently follow. Heaven knows what the Westminster system really was, or is today. Certainly, one does not see within our existing structure any of the sorts of guarantees, any of the sorts of procedures, which would require the revelation of information which is pretended by those who proceed with that argument. Some people argue that because, under the Westminster style of government the Executive is directly accountable to the parliament, freedom of information legislation is not necessary. They say that because Ministers have to be accountable to the Parliament-to every single member of it-in that way a curb can be placed on the Executive and information extracted from it. But of course we know that over the years Ministers have raised the whole art of concealment to a very advanced stage indeed; Ministers do not come into this Parliament with the objective of providing information. They come into it with the objective of withholding and concealing information. Honourable members have to be some sort of an Houdini to work out the mechanism involved in extracting information from an unwilling Minister. If a member of this Parliament dares to develop any sort of inquisitive zeal it takes only one Question Time to kill off that zeal absolutely.

If we turn to the area of Questions on Notice, which are supposed to give effect to the right of members of parliament to place before Ministers questions which those Ministers must answer, one has only to read the answers themselves to learn that Ministers go to very great lengths to avoid answering questions, conceal information or provide all kinds of elaborate ruses for not revealing the information sought by members of Parliament. So the purpose of asking Questions without Notice during Question Time is not to seek information. The value is apparently in the question, not the answer. Indeed, in relation to Questions on Notice, honourable members do not seem to care much about the answers given. All they care about is engaging in some sort of competition to see who can ask the greatest number. I daresay that the Government goes to a great deal of trouble and expense to avoid answering those questions but I would not suggest-I would be surprised if anyone would-that that mechanism represented any real opportunity for members of parliament, let alone the public as a whole, to extract information from the Government.

Anyway, people have said that because we have a system under which Ministers are responsible to the Parliament, it is inappropriate for us to adopt the United States practice. Of course, the system there is theoretically quite different. The Executive is not directly accountable to the Congress and therefore one needs other sorts of mechanisms to extract information from the Executive, to require it to provide that information not only to the Congress but also to the public at large. I suggest that it is not so much a matter of transplanting or grafting an American solution onto a Westminster style of government, but rather one of recognising that our system has become very close to that of the United States. In Australia, and indeed in the States of Australia, the executives no longer operate in such a way as to be accountable to parliament. They are accountable, apparently, to no one but themselves. They provide only the information that they want to provide.

Because of that distortion of the theoretical processes of the Westminster system, this sort of legislation is indeed necessary. My very great regret is that it proceeds from the assumption that one must try to conceal, try to contain, information unless one absolutely has to give it out, rather than let everybody know, unless there are overwhelmingly valid reasons for withholding it . If we are talking about the ordinary people of a country participating in a democratic process and having the information that is necessary for that participation, what on earth is wrong with letting everyone know as much as possible?

Indeed, I would go one step further and say that this legislation, in itself, has become almost entirely irrelevant to the processes of informing the general public as a whole. It is no longer simply a question of extracting the information from governments. More importantly these days it is a question of getting that information, once extracted, out to the ordinary members of the community. That, it seems to me, is where the real problem lies. Between the provision of the information by the Government and the receiving of the information by the general public there lie very restricted means of communication indeed. There is a myriad of ways in which the media, the newspapers, television and radio, can apply rules which, in fact, prevent the dissemination of that information, once extracted from the Government.

What we really have to do is look not only at the question of getting the information from the Government but also at the ways in which that information, whether readily provided by government or provided under duress, is made available to the general public. Only when the general public has access to that information will we have made any advance at all. If just a small coterie of people have additional access to information we have not advanced very far at all the cause of democracy. It is only when hundreds of thousands or millions of people are in a position to make judgments on the basis of knowledge that we begin to improve the whole fabric of democracy. Instead, we have a situation which apparently is quite persistent, still alive and well, whereby there is, on the part of governments, a terror of letting anybody know anything about what governments are up to, or about what Ministers are thinking.

What people seem to ignore is that the value of information is largely determined by its availability. If information is in scarce supply it gathers certain value which, of course, disappears as soon as everyone knows it. Who cares if everyone knows a certain piece of information? What is valuable about it is that only a few people know it and that others want to be amongst those few. So those governments which hide behind this sort of cloak of secrecy and try to deprive people of such information misjudge the whole nature of the exercise. If they were prepared to reveal the information quite openly the damaging consequences that they imagine would follow would of course disappear.

I will give a couple of examples: Recently I was speaking to a senior journalist in the Press gallery who has, for years, followed meetings of the national decision-making body of the Australian Labor Party. At one time that body met behind closed doors-as it still does-but in very great secrecy.

TALK.START.PARA: —And all of the information leaked out bit by bit.

—The honourable member for Port Adelaide has had a wealth of experience in these matters and makes very well the point that I want to make. This journalist was one of the few who had access to the leaks. He was one of those who were able to find out what happened behind those closed doors. He told me that it was a matter of great regret to him when the national secretary of the Australian Labor Party-the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) was the first to do it-decided to brief the Press after meetings of the National Executive, which was then called the Federal Executive. He said that all the fun went out of it because everybody knew what went on and therefore his role in the whole process was immediately diminished.
—They could not colour their stories.

—What the honourable member for Port Adelaide recognised at the time, and obviously quite clearly still recognises, is that, so long as the information is made available, there is no skulduggery, intrigue or any possibility for distortion and, indeed, the information becomes that much less valuable to those who have the objective of using it in a mischievous way. There are other examples. We have had the example of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) who has been caught out time and again in this Parliament simply because he attempts to delude, to deceive and to withhold information. If only he would come clean, tell it how it really is and reveal the sorts of mistakes he has made and the sorts of intrigues that he has been involved in, he would not get into nearly as much trouble as he has in recent times. He has an additional problem, of course, in that he has an inability to distinguish between falsehood and the truth. He will always be in that sort of dilemma.
—Get on with your speech and stop the bible-bashing.

—That is my speech. My speech is to discredit the Minister for Industrial Relations at every opportunity because the Minister for Industrial Relations has no respect for this Parliament. He has no respect for the truth and no respect even for the honourable member, if he cares to ponder on it. The Minister does not care for anybody except himself. He is one of the greatest deceivers and concealers in this Parliament. That is why he has come unstuck in all the portfolios which it has been Australia's misfortune for him to occupy. Then, of course, we have the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) who is gesticulating in his usual way this evening. He has suddenly discovered the importance of the freedom of information. He notes with some great horror that the New South Wales Government is withholding information at the same time as he makes a speech in support of this Government's withholding information, that is, prescribing limits on the sort of information which ought to be withheld by this Government. The honourable member for Wentworth has discovered the very great difference between being in opposition and in government. He has fallen for the three-card trick. He wants to be as secretive as he can while his party is in government but he wants other governments to be as open as possible when he and his party happen to be in opposition. One thing we can say about the Australian Labor Party is that we pioneered freedom of information and, although some of our earlier attempts might have been still-born and a bit defective, at least we set out on the very difficult and hazardous course of providing freedom of information. Indeed, had we had the opportunity to proceed with that course, we would have had a much better Bill before this House than the pallid form of the original intention that in fact has arrived in this House from the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I make a couple of other points about exclusions because this Bill is more about excluding and preventing access to information than providing access to information. The particular area I refer to appears in Part IV where reference is made to exempt documents, including those dealing with relations between the Commonwealth and the States. I cannot for the life of me understand why relations between the Commonwealth and the States cannot be more open. Why should not relations between the Commonwealth and the States be as open as relations between one department and another department within this Government? The States, we have come to understand, are the most secretive of all governments in Australia. They have been the most recalcitrant in terms of providing information to the people whom they seek to govern. State governments are supposed to be the closest to the people and those most in touch with the people but, in reality, they are the ones who set about an elaborate course of denying information and of deceiving the communities which elect them.

I do not understand why this Commonwealth or any Commonwealth should fortify that process. Why should we not make available to the people of Australia as a whole the information that flows between State governments and the national government? After all, it is in the interests of all of the people what happens between governments. To deny that information only encourages the sort of grandstanding, mischief and outright politicking which goes on between Premiers and Prime Ministers of this country. We must stop that process. We must make Premiers stand up and be counted in relation to the things they say, currently, behind closed doors in Premiers Conferences. I am sick and tired of having occasional leaks from Premiers Conferences, to find Premiers revealed as having said something quite different from what they have in fact said when they have gone home to their own little bailiwicks and, in the safety of their closet media, have revealed what they think the communities they serve want to hear. It is about time the whole system was opened up. If it were opened up, the whole system of government in this country would be better and, indeed, Australia might for the first time become somewhat governable. It is an outrage that this legislation should seek to fortify the secrecy of and the deception by Premiers, which has gone on for far too long. State governments are secretive and surreptitious and the Commonwealth should have no part in encouraging that. The honourable member for Wentworth and the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) both said 'But what an enormous cost is involved in revealing this information'. The honourable member for Bradfield told us what the estimate and the actual cost was in the United States. I suspect that most of the costs in the United States involved with the freedom of information legislation in fact result from finding ways of not disclosing information. The freer information is , the cheaper it is to provide. If these sorts of exclusions and exemptions are provided, of course it will cost money to determine which is available and which is not. It would become very much cheaper if those limits were removed or at least partially reduced.
Debate (on motion by Mr Baume) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Anniversary of Bombing of Darwin-Sinai Peacekeeping Force-Mr John Sanders: Solo Circumnavigation of the World-National Semiconductor Corporation-Government Departments: Appropriation Reductions-Bushfires in Tasmania-Petrol Prices-Report on the Children's Services Program-Tariff Policies-Purchase of 'HMS Invincible'- Parliament House: Conduct of Members-Commissioner for Housing Loans

PROCTEXT.PARA: Anniversary of Bombing of Darwin-Sinai Peacekeeping Force-Mr John Sanders: Solo Circumnavigation of the World-National Semiconductor Corporation-Government Departments: Appropriation Reductions-Bushfires in Tasmania-Petrol Prices-Report on the Children's Services Program-Tariff Policies-Purchase of 'HMS Invincible'- Parliament House: Conduct of Members-Commissioner for Housing Loans
Motion (by Mr MacKellar) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tomorrow is 19 February and it marks the fortieth anniversary of the bombing of Darwin. The 19th February 1942 was a very significant day in the history of Darwin and, more importantly, in the history of Australia. My generation, as a person aged under 40, and probably a majority of the people now living in Australia, do not have a personal memory of the events of the first enemy attack on Australian soil. But I think it is important that we-that is, those of us under 40 years of age-should be mindful of our obligation to those who died and to their families. We have an obligation to remember the service of the thousands who served in the defence of northern Australia and in particular the 243 who died and the 253 who were wounded on 19 February 1942. Tomorrow we must think of their families with sympathy. In addition to the two raids on 19 February, in total there were 58 occasions on which Darwin and other centres in northern Australia were bombed between March 1942 and November 1943.

SPEECH.PARA: The first and most comprehensive book about the bombing of Darwin is undoubtedly Douglas Lockwood's Australia's Pearl Harbour. I bring it to attention to be read by many people in Australia today. The book covers the events of that infamous day very graphically and from the author's personal experience. It covers the tragedy, the mistakes and the destruction and highlights very graphically the unpreparedness of the Australian nation on that occasion. I believe it is incumbent on all of us to remember that 40 years is a very short time. We should be very mindful, when putting together our defence policies, of the need to maintain a very strong Australian Defence Force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The latest government cutbacks will have a grave effect on Canberra's economy. They have further reduced public confidence in the Government's ability to manage the economy. Already, there has been an angry response from local business and industry leaders. These cutbacks have been rushed through in an ad hoc manner with no thought for the consequences for business people, contractors, developers or the ordinary citizen. The building industry has been particularly hard hit once again. The Commissioner for Housing loan scheme has been frozen. If the decision is not reviewed, it will seriously affect the number of new houses that will be built this year. It will put builders and employees out of work and further reduce the opportunity for home ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: The cutbacks will also prevent cyclical maintenance on government houses. Cancellation of overtime payments will mean that maintenance work will take longer and the reallocation of government houses will be slowed down. There are already 2,400 families on the waiting list and up to 100 each month are approved for priority allocation, but none of these people can get houses at present. The latest cutbacks will place further pressure on these waiting lists and we can expect the present waiting times of 2 1/2 years for an ordinary house to lengthen considerably. All of this means further hardship for the many needy Canberra families. The latest cutbacks have placed the government's commitment to build 300 new houses in jeopardy. These houses were promised in this year's Budget and are urgently needed to replace those sold from the existing pool and to alleviate the ever lengthening queues for government housing.

It is essential that the Government stick to its budget promises if the private sector is to have any confidence at all in Canberra's future. No business can survive the continual stop-go decisions of the present Government. No business can operate in an unstable and unpredictable commercial environment for long. The Fraser Government is clearly bad for business and it will certainly suffer the electoral consequences. The Chief Executive of the Australian Capital Territory and Southern New South Wales Division of the Housing Industry Association, Mr Laurie Evans, has said:

The private sector, traditionally linked with Liberal-Country Party coalition policies, might now look to ALP platforms to find the solutions to the continuing problems of interest rates, unemployment and economic mismanagement.

The new Parliament House is another victim of the cutbacks. Only a few months after a Government commitment to the future of this important national project, it was announced this week that $3m is to be slashed from the $26m project budget for this year. This significant cutback will have a serious effect on local contractors and will cause an uneven employment distribution on the project. But, of greatest importance, is the fact that the cutback will not even save any money. On major building projects, delays always cost money and have a significant multiplier effect on the final cost of the project.

Within the Public Service, the directive from the Department of Finance has thrown the work of the Public Service into confusion. Midway through the financial year, and hard on the heels of disorder generated by the razor gang, each department is now expected to turn itself inside out because the Government cannot get its Budget sums right. No wonder people have lost confidence in this Government. Cutting out overtime, cancellation of major equipment acquisitions and freezing of discretionary expenditure in one swift ad hoc decision are probably the most inefficient method of achieving financial savings that could be devised. The ludicrous suggestion that the Australian Federal Police should eliminate overtime payments, and presumably educate the criminal element to work regular nine to five hours, indicates the extent of the Government's mismanagement. The people of Canberra are bearing the brunt of nearly all Federal Government cutbacks and they are sick and tired of the Fraser Government 's chaotic anti-Canberra policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that both sides of the House would want me to extend sympathy to the Tasmanian Government and Tasmanian people as a result of the disastrous bushfires this week. It is pleasing to see the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) in the House. He went down to Tasmania during the week and monitored the situation. I think we all felt very uneasy. I think all members of Federal Parliament are torn between their homes and here. When there are problems at home I am sure all members want to be there. One never knows with bushfires. We get so many varying opinions and a variance in media reports about what can happen. The other House of Representatives members and the Tasmanian senators, including Labor senators, probably felt the same as I did; they were very uneasy and worried all the time.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not want a repetition of 1967. I applaud the Tasmanian Government for declaring a state of emergency and for making sure that Tasmania was prepared for the unforseen. We could have had a repetition of 1967. I hope to goodness that everything is cleared up. I hope to goodness that we do not have any tragic loss of life. We have already lost one person, apparently; I believe another was seriously injured. I am sure all Australians feel the same as I do. Bushfires are unexpected and can create terrible problems for the people involved. There can be loss of life, limb, land and goodness knows what. That aside, I am sure it has been an uneasy week in Tasmania. We are all very pleased that the weather has changed and the problems appear to have passed.

I raise another point tonight. I listened with great interest to all of the arguments about sales tax. Many people mentioned that the sales taxes that would cost the average family about $1.50 a week. I thought to myself about the great rip off in petrol charges in this country. I thought of the arguments that are being presented by many State and Federal politicians about the variation in the price of petrol. I compared Victoria with Tasmania and Melbourne with Hobart. Probably many members are not aware that the oil companies individually have to go to the Petrol Products Pricing Authority to seek an increase. If they can justify an increase it is granted. A maximum wholesale price is charged in every capital city of Australia, and it does not vary that much. In Victoria it is 37c to 38c a litre. In Hobart it is 37c to 38c a litre. There is not very much variance.

I have been involved with an argument with a person-I cannot think of his name- from the Australian Institute of Petroleum who is probably very heavily involved with the oil companies. He made a statement after a few remarks from me that competition lowers the price of petrol. I thought to myself: Fair enough; if competition is enacted correctly it may do so. I wondered to myself how he could make that assertion when in fact the maximum wholesale price in Melbourne is 37c to 38c a litre and in Hobart it is 37c to 38c a litre and the selling price in Hobart is 42c to 44c a litre and in Melbourne it varies from 33c to 37c a litre- quite a disparity. The same thing is happening all over Australia. In every capital city there is a variance.

In the capital cities of Sydney and Adelaide there is a freeze on the wholesale price and consumers know roughly what it will be. There is a freeze on the retail price. When the people of Australia have been asked in the national interest to pay a high price for petrol there should be a bit of fairness in the market place. There should not be a variance of about 10c a litre between Melbourne and Hobart. A person who has to use about 10 gallons of petrol will pay about $5 a week more in Hobart than in Melbourne. Yet we argue about $1.30 or $1.50 a week. Governments win and lose elections on issues involving $2 a week. The people of Hobart are paying an additional $5 a week for petrol. This gentleman from the Petroleum Petrol Institute had the audacity to say to me that competition makes a fair and cheaper price. Those days are gone. I plead with the Government and the Opposition to get involved in this petroleum problem, this marketing problem, which varies from State to State.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been considerable debate over the so-called Spender report, which reviewed the Children's Services Program. I might say that I object to calling reviews of various programs by the name of the chairmen. I have earlier asked that this report be officially released to the public and I now repeat that request. The document should be the subject of public perusal and debate before any of the recommendations are adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: I am in accord with some of the recommendations. I agree that the funding formulae should be reviewed and I endorse the emphasis on good business procedures of accountability. However, no matter how unsatisfactory the existing Child Care Act may be, it would be the height of lunacy to repeal the Act before more satisfactory legislation is provided. Such legislation should not even be considered before those people with long-standing and in-depth experience in child development and child care have had the opportunity to debate publicly this latest report. Apart from anything else, if the present legislation is repealed, this would leave the Children's Services Program without a statutory basis.

I have serious concern about a number of the recommendations in the report. I am concerned particularly about the total lack of consideration given by the report to the issue of the quality of care to be provided. The report appears to assume that it does not matter whether qualified staff are or are not employed to provide child care. In recommendation No. 8, it is proposed to probe the feasibility of providing a subsidy to enable children of low income parents to attend commercial child care centres. If implemented, such a subsidy would support the care of children in conditions considerably lower than those required for the receipt of the Government subsidy at present. For example, commercial centres in Victoria may operate with minimal care provisions, providing they meet requirements for registration.

The only requirement for a person to be in charge of a group of 30 children and responsible for the functioning of the Centre is that such person be over 18 years of age and that such person be physically and mentally capable. Other staff members may be 15 years old. There is no requirement that staff be trained in the care of young children. In spite of public agitation over many years, the standard requirements for registration of child minding centres has not been raised. Many commercial centres provide a high standard of care, but this type of subsidy would condone the use of public money to place children in situations where there is the possibility of institutionalised child abuse occurring.

It is difficult to accept the argument presented in the Report that families, and not commercial child minding centres, would be subsidised, since the intention is to select certain centres in each State and Territory. In any case, subsidy to needy families is open to abuse since proprietors of commercial centres can increase fees when subsidies apply without allowing reductions. We have seen this happen with similar provisions in Nursing Homes. Few commercial centres are in the areas of highest economic need, so access for needy families would not be increased.

The Government has already declared that no funds have been allocated for new or expanded programs in 1981-82. This means that dozens of applications for new programs which have been sitting with the Department of Social Security for up to 2 years cannot be funded. The Office of Child Care, on instructions from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), sent out 500 rejections to community organisations. Many of those rejected were admitted to be high priority. This means they were desperately needed. Cabinet rejected that part of the Report that proposed that $5m be provided to cover these applications in 1981-82. The Minister appears to be using the excuse of no new funding to look at a re-allocation of the existing funding, but not to meet the needs of children.

The proposals propounded by the Report will do little or nothing to improve children's access to care. Our primary concern must be to ensure that children in need of care are not denied care by factors of cost or by lack of services. Clear evidence exists to support the contention that high quality care and education during the pre-school years is of critical importance to the optimum development of each individual. It is essential that services for children and their families continue to expand, improve and develop. High quality child care is expensive in simple financial terms but extremely effective in terms of prevention.

Subsidising commercial centres and introducing a standardised means test are the thin edge of the wedge. Together with the withdrawal of the Child Care Act 1972, these initiatives would let the Government right off the hook on child care. The Government could easily move towards a system of tax rebates and vouchers for children below school age and let the market provide. Then we would see the conservatives' dream-private programs for the rich and tough luck for the poor. The bulk of the Australian families which fall between the rich and--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pay a brief tribute. On my return to Parliament House for this autumn sitting I was delighted to find a letter waiting from a distinguished Western Australian adventurer and yachtsman. I speak of Jonathan Sanders. On 7 February of this year Jon Sanders completed his singlehanded circumnavigation of the world in his yacht Perie Banou and started his second non-stop circumnavigation. In an age where individual achievement and effort do not always attract recognition, it gives me pleasure to pay this tribute to this latest achievement of a fine Australian.

SPEECH.PARA: The first half of his lonely journey was not without its problems and that is not surprising, given the goals Jon Sanders set for himself. He tells me that his first circumnavigation via the Southern oceans took 142 day 7 hours and 49 minutes, which may well be a record. Despite his yacht being turned turtle during a gale, the ensuing damage requiring running repairs, loss of one of two solar panels essential for recharging batteries and the permanent loss of engine power which may have been needed in an emergency this man has coped with, and risen above, all the challenges the southern oceans could offer.

In traversing the southern oceans route he follows in the metaphorical wake of Captain James Cook in command of one of only three sailing vessels which have completed similar journeys. The others were commanded by an Argentinian, Vitto Dumas, and a Frenchman, Bernard Moitessier. The latter is credited with the longest sea journey of its kind ever, another record I am confident Jon Sanders will break. While, as I have said, achievements by individuals acting alone are rarely newsworthy, Jon Sanders has already attracted great credit to himself. His cheerful letter to me was written over the period 4 December 1981 to 4 February this year and kindly mailed to me in Hobart by those responsible for re -provisioning the Perie Banou at sea off Hobart recently. I assume he is now in or again approaching Antarctic waters, well into the second of his circumnavigations. I wish him well for the remainder of his journey and join his parents, family and friends in looking forward to his safe return to Perth around May of this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight on the Australian Broadcasting Commission' s Channel 3 news in Canberra the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) was interviewed by a Mr Ron Miller. In his introduction Mr Miller said that Mr Hodgman had a piece of bad news, that National Semiconductor Corporation had deferred its plans to build a mult-million dollar silicon chip factory-it is not a chip factory; it is a wafer factory-in Canberra. Mr Miller went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hodgman stressed there was only a deferment by the company, not a complete pullout. And he had strong words for one of his detractors over the issue, Labor Parliamentarian Barry Jones.
The Minister is then quoted as saying:
Mr Jones was reported to me yesterday as having said that nobody had heard of me in California--
That is certainly true-
that I had finished with egg on my face--
That is also true-

that there was never any proposition of 1,200 jobs being available in the Capital Territory. I am so annoyed about Mr Jones, he might be very good at Pick A Box as far as I'm concerned I'd invite him to Pick A Box and the place I'd suggest he starts looking is Gungahlin. Because quite frankly Mr Jones has done a lot of damage and in my view has behaved in a manner which has not been in the interests of the Capital Territory.

I would have thought that the elementary principles of journalistic ethics would have led Mr Miller to approach me for comment. He made no such contact and when I rang the ABC to claim the right of reply I was told that Mr Miller had knocked off but I could ring him back tomorrow if I chose. The Minister was forced to concede that the Natsemi project was not going ahead but by saying it is simply deferred he lets himself down lightly. It is dead. Actually it was never a goer and if it was not for the extreme gullibility of the Minister-no one else ever believed it was a goer; the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation always disregarded it; the Department of the Treasury always regarded it as absurd and it certainly was not possible to find anyone who publicly or privately was prepared to say explicitly that is was priority No. 1 as to what anyone would do in the area of microelectronics.

On 9 April 1981 I told the House that the Natsemi project had no chance of success and that experts in microelectronics both here and in California regarded the project as a ludicrous misapplication of funds which could be used in far more valuable and more labour intensive ways in high technology. I quote from the Press release I issued yesterday:
The Fraser Government's ill-conceived project-

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—If you prefer I can incorporate it. The Press release stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Fraser Government's ill-conceived project to provide $19m in Commonwealth assets to induce the National Semiconductor Corporation of California to set up its silicon wafer fabrication plant in Canberra has collapsed.
This emphasis on componentry would have committed Australia to only a part technology-and we would have no control over the end product.

Natsemi is already under serious threat at home in the US. Japan is gaining a much larger share of the world's chip market. Many of Natsemi's key personnel have left for other companies. The Pentagon has 'de-certified' some of Natsemi's circuitry because the Defense Department was dissatisfied with its performance.
I quote from a paper called The Relevance of Silicon Valley to Australia by Stuart Macdonald of the Department of Economics, University of Queensland. He said:

The Minister for the Capital Territory has, however, been exuberant in pointing out the advantages to Canberra of acquiring National Semiconductor. According to the Minister, the plant will employ directly between 1200 and 1500 people-though the domestic employment of the whole American semiconductor industry was less than 90,000 in 1978-and will 'lead to the establishment in this country, without any shadow of a doubt, of an applications industry with a capacity to employ in excess of 100,000 people at the end of the decade.'
He is no piker, this Minister. He says that in little old Canberra you will have an industry that is bigger than the biggest industry in California. Mr Macdonald went on to say:

That is quite remarkable in the light of the estimation by the Minister for Science and Technology that the many hundreds of millions of dollars so far spent on research and development projects aided under the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme will yield only a paltry 29,000 new jobs by the end of the decade.

The hypocrisy of this Minister was shown in a speech that he gave when he introduced a symposium on Starlab at the end of last year. He could not have expressed more enthusiasm for the Starlab project. What he failed to point out in his speech, and the only thing he did not say, was that the Government had declined to provide a single dollar, a single cent for it. That was the one thing he left out in his speech. With $19m of assets one could set up in Canberra a scientific instrumentation facility that would be equal to anything in the world; far more labour intensive. But he is not doing that. This is a case where 'the mouth from the south' is only concerned with grabbing headlines and does not understand the issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House a serious anomaly in the operation of tariff policies that has severely affected from 1 January 1982 the operations of, and jobs provided by, a small business whose directors live in my electorate. It is, I fear, a representative case and it is alarming to find that business people, who are prepared to make their living and create jobs for others through the discipline and opportunities of free enterprise, suddenly find their enterprise threatened not by market forces but by a government decision which is against the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission and is wholly unrelated to the facts of the situation. It is a mixture of protectionism gone mad and of the bureaucratic fetish of uniformity for its own sake.

SPEECH.PARA: The Albart Trading Company, whose premises are situated in Alexandria, employs seven people whose jobs are now at risk. This may seem, I say, a small affair but it is, I fear, representative. The company, as one of its major lines, retails imported American pantyhose. In fact, what the company deals in is support pantyhose, a special item sometimes medically necessary to aid circulation for women such as those who stand all day, pregnant women and so on. The Albart Trading Company's only competitor which manufactures this item locally is Courtaulds Hilton Pty Ltd. This latter company under the tariff arrangement formerly existing has retailed its support panty hose at $6.75 a pair; Albart has had to pay a tariff of 30 per cent on its product, which last year retailed at $9.85 a pair. In other words there was ample opportunity afforded to the local product as against Albart under these tariff arrangements. This interpretation has been supported by the IAC reports of 1978 and 1980. The result was that the IAC recommended a tariff rise of only 5 per cent to take effect from 1 January 1982. Despite this, the Government, overruling the IAC, decided to raise the tariff in question by 20 per cent, and as from 1 January 1982 it has therefore been a full 50 per cent. This new tariff will have the most serious consequences for Albart as 60 per cent of the company's total hosiery imports consist of this item. The tariff increase will make the item unmarketable and I am informed that the result of this will be that the company' s other operations will be drastically affected to the extent that the company may find it impossible to carry on trading at all and a small business will have gone to the wall with the loss of seven jobs.

Two reasons have been given for this sudden change in tariffs. One is that the increase has been necessary to bring about uniformity in the application of tariff measures in this area. It is hard, however, to understand why this item in which Albart Trading has dealt, with no disruption to the market afforded to local producers, should suddenly be lumped together with other items with no regard to the facts of the case being apparent but merely for the fetish of uniformity. The second reason for rejecting the IAC recommendation is that the tariff increases were necessary to preserve jobs; it is hard so see what jobs will be lost by continuing to protect the already highly protected domestic producer while to introduce the proposed new tariff rise will very possibly lead to the definite loss of seven jobs provided by the importer. I must also point out that the domestic producer, so favoured, is an international concern with its base in London. Yet in order to continue protecting this firm without any increase in the number of Australians it employs, it is proposed to harass, if not close down, an Australian firm.

It is hard to believe that putting Albart out of business, as these measures threaten to do, will aid employment. It will certainly not reduce inflation. I strongly claim that this is a very serious oversight, perpetrated perhaps because of bureaucratic generalist desire for mythical consistency. Those responsible should look at the individual facts, human as well as economic, in this matter. I commend this matter to the attention of both the House and the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.
