TALK.START.PARA: —One of the matters that has concerned the Opposition, albeit a minor one but nevertheless an important one, in the Government's commitment to the Sinai peacekeeping force is our belief that the Government has made commitments on the detail of the force-how it will be planned and how it will be structured-but it has not seriously set about thinking how those details ought to be implemented and every now and then a piece of evidence comes to the fore which indicates that that is quite clearly the problem. The aspect of the Government's commitment to the Sinai peacekeeping force that I want to raise tonight relates to one part of the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in a release to the Australian public long ago, in October last year, in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: No part of the peacekeeping force-including the United States component-should have any association with the United States Rapid Deployment Force.

About that same time I pointed out to the Prime Minister that there had been widespread reports in the United States, some of which had been picked up here, that units or specifically one battalion of the 82nd Airborne Division were going to be used as the American component to the Sinai peacekeeping force. The 82nd Airborne Division is well known in defence circles as one of the two designated for the Rapid Deployment Force, the other being the 101st Airborne Division. The Prime Minister came down on me from a very great height when I raised this matter in the Parliament, starting, as I remember his answer, with a discussion on socialist republicans and moving on further afield. But he did have the decency to say in the course of his reply:

The condition that we attached in relation to the multinational peacekeeping force and the United States involvement in it relates to the time when any particular United States unit is allocated to that force.

I did point out to him at that time that the 82nd Airborne battalion would be the battalion designated and I asked what did he intend to do about it. The implication in his answer was, absolutely nothing. We now find, four or five months later, that when the report emerges again-old news getting recirculated but this time seriously because it is now quite clearly the unit that will be designated-the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) has asked for urgent details from Australia's Embassy in Washington. What has this Government been doing for the last four months? Does this country run an independent foreign policy or does it not? Is it serious when it says to the United States that it is going to commit itself to an American operation under strict conditions-that as a mature nation it will follow through those conditions, have its views considered and will insist upon those views being considered-when we discover that after he has been alerted to it from albeit public sources what he ought to have had privately for four months the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) is obliged to ask for urgent details on the matter? That really is not good enough.

We are making a commitment which has notably elevated our diplomatic posture in the Middle East and has exposed us to far closer scrutiny from both the Camp David powers and the other powers in the area which are now watching our performance and particularly the view that we have been putting to them that we are capable of operating independently of the United States, that we are capable of having our own view on how this peacekeeping force will be used, that we are mindful of our own particular interests in the Middle East. Yet we are now demonstrating to them that we are going to go along with and have done absolutely nothing about giving warning of a designation of a particular unit which is associated with a force that is particularly feared among many friendly Arab States.

As I mentioned in this House before, I was recently a member of a parliamentary delegation to the area. In Saudi Arabia and in the United Arab Emirates-two very friendly powers with this country-we found very considerable concern about the rapid deployment force. I think we owe it to those countries with whom we have good relations at least to view seriously a move into an association with that force even if that battalion from the rapid deployment force is not going to be considered with the rapid deployment force when it is in the Sinai Peacekeeping Force. We could have pressed the Americans back in October to take one of their battalions out of one of their units in Europe. It would have had no association with the force and would have performed exactly the same purpose in the Sinai. We did not do it. I think it is the measure of our immaturity that we did not do it. It is only one of the many aspects of the Government's conduct on the question of the Sinai Peacekeeping Force that is to be deprecated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to correct some false impressions created by two totally inaccurate Press reports about a meeting in the Government party room yesterday relating to discussions of the possible purchase of HMS Invincible as a replacement for HMAS Melbourne. The problem is a very simple one. Reports on the ABC 6 o'clock news last night and in the Australian newspaper this morning totally misrepresented what happened in the party room and both fly in the face of the briefing, which was a factual one given by the appropriate Minister at the end of that party room meeting, to the Press. I cannot understand on what basis these two reports would have been prepared. I have tried to contact both the journalists involved and neither has phoned me back.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem seems to me to fit into a very serious political context because there is no doubt that the Labor Party, for example, has been running a strong campaign against HMS Invincible denigrating that ship which has performed so outstandingly well in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation excercises in conjunction with our potential allies in the Pacific. it has performed extraordinarily well in NATO exercises in the Atlantic showing its capacity to be effective in that context. It is notable that the Americans have since underlined the point that it would be useful if Australia were to purchase an aircraft carrier. The total misrepresentation in both these reports lies in the allegation that the Government has had to delay further its decision to purchase Invincible because of back bench pressure. The ABC news item said that the back bench had forced the Government to defer its decision on purchase. The Australian article stated:
The Federal Government has further delayed a decision on the purchase of the aircraft carrier HMS Invicible in the face of increasing doubts among back bench MPs . . .
The report continued:
The Minister for Defence, Mr Killen, yielded to backbench pressure yesterday and told a meeting of government parties no decision would be taken by Cabinet until MPs had been briefed by the RAN.
The fact is that the question of when the decision was to be made was not raised at any time. The Minister for Defence made no such statement. This was clearly stated by-

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a secret meeting and you were not invited.
—There was no secrecy about this because this was clearly stated.
—I know you are a crook.
—Order! The honourable member for Port Adelaide will cease interjecting.

—The sounds made by the honourable member for Port Adelaide bear an inverse relation to his knowledge. That is well known in this House. The louder he becomes and more he interjects, the less he knows. This is represented once again tonight.
—Well, are you a crook?
—Order! The honourable member for Port Adelaide will withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw.
—The honourable member for Port Adelaide will rise to his feet and withdraw.
—I withdraw.
—I call the honourable member for Macarthur.

—I am grateful to the honourable member for Port Adelaide as he has reminded the House of the calibre of his character and the nature of his interjections. It is typical that when the honourable member for Port Adelaide is caught out being silly he responds with personal abuse. There is nothing unusual about that. I am glad to see that he is maintaining his record and keeping up the level of integrity to which this House is accustomed from him. The fact is that in the briefing given by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) the question of when the decision would be made and when the briefing would take place was not mentioned. Yet the journalists have had the capacity to report that Mr Killen said something in the party meeting which simply did not take place. I want to stress that I am overjoyed that at last the case for this outstanding ship will be presented by senior naval people so that the benefits of this ship will be clearly known. I hope that this might encourage the Labor members of this House to cease denigrating what I hope will be a sensible purchase in Australian defence expenditure.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my intention at this time to enter this debate to speak about the purchase of an aircraft carrier. I hope that when the decision is made it is made on the basis of the needs of Australia's defence, not some attachment to a particular form of vessel or the needs of any section of the Australian community, be they the needs of the electorate of the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) or otherwise; nor should the decision be made in accordance with the needs of another country's defence forces. This is too important, too much money is involved and the future of Australian defence depends on the decision being the correct one.

SPEECH.PARA: In the few minutes that I have to speak I want to raise a matter which is of extreme concern to me. On a couple of occasions this House has descended into serious uproar as a result of, I think, a continuing abuse of the procedures of questions and answers during Question Time in this House. I do not want to comment on the rights or wrongs of the actions of any individual persons in this context, but I do want to comment on what I consider to be the most pious and dishonest nonsense that I have ever seen coming from individuals inside or outside this place; in this case I speak of outside this place.

Yesterday and again today Government Ministers, including the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) complained about disorderly conduct in the House and its reflection on the Parliament as an institution. It would be a legitimate complaint if the persons concerned had ever shown any respect for the institution and had been prepared to conduct themselves in a manner that their office suggests they ought to conduct themselves. I was a member of this House in 1975; so were some other honourable members here today. Some of the short memory television journalists we hear conducting interviews today were also in the gallery. The then Opposition engaged in the most disorderly, disruptive and contemptuous behaviour that has occurred in this Parliament. It was led by the present Prime Minister and the present Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair). When they make pious statements about order in the Parliament, they might look at their own records. If they are upset or they cannot cop it now, they should see who the culprits are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I require the debate to be extended.
—The debate may be extended to 10.40 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks will be brief. I commence by saying that I relish the opportunity to participate at the conclusion of this evening's adjournment debate. It gives me the chance to congratulate the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) and the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) on their excellent contributions to the debate. I regret that I cannot make the same comment about the contributions made by honourable members from the Opposition, some of whom I believe did less than justice to themselves, their constituencies or, indeed, their causes, by what they said. I shall refer to but two of the contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) devoted the entirety of her speech to a decision announced in the media that $1.4m of Commissioner for Housing home loan funds had been frozen. Had she made her speech yesterday, it would have been spot on. I am rather surprised that the honourable member is unaware that today a decision was made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) and an announcement was made by me that the $1.4m in frozen funds had been released. I say that because Senator Margaret Reid, Mrs Grant, M. H.A., Mr Leedman, M.H.A., Mr Cornwell, M.H.A. and Mr Webb, M.H.A., all elected Liberal members in the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, not only made the strongest representations about what the situation would be if that money were not released but also were amongst the first to congratulate me and the Government when the announcement was made that the frozen funds had been released. Yet, at approximately 10 o'clock tonight, the honourable member for Canberra was not even aware that the money was back in circulation.

Now I come to the contribution by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), who is the Opposition's official spokesman on science. In the horrible event of a Labor government coming to power, that man, the honourable member for Lalor, would be Minister for Science. He, on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, has been one of the most constant critics of a plan to bring to Australia and specifically to Canberra a $100m microelectronics industry. I have never in my life heard as much clap trap, rubbish and utter nonsense from any member of the Federal Parliament in the past 12 months as I have heard in the invective, the absolute hatred and the determination to destroy this project by the honourable member for Lalor on behalf of the Labor Party. Of course, what I say about him is nothing--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, the Minister is using improper language. I ask you to call on him to withdraw.
—There is no point of order.

—What I am about to say about the honourable member for Lalor is nothing compared with what will be said to him in the next few days and weeks by the honourable member for Canberra and the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Fry) and all the Labor members of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly when they know that their Federal spokesman has publicly opposed in this Parliament a project which would be a major asset to this nation. I suggest to the honourable member that he ought to talk to the Leader of the Opposition about the briefing he got on this proposal. I put it to you very bluntly, Mr Deputy Speaker: There is a world of difference between a decision being deferred and a project being abandoned.
—Come on! You know it is dead.
—It does not mean anything to the honourable member for Lalor. He is concerned to seek publicity and to destroy a project which he believes--
—That is a strange accusation coming from you.
—Order! The honourable member for Lalor will remain silent.

—He believes in his twisted way that such a project is not good for Australia. I suggest to the honourable member for Lalor that the next time he makes a speech in this House he might check his facts. He said, for example, that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is opposed to the project. Is he not aware that the Australian Government sent a study team to California which comprised two of the top CSIRO scientists in this country? The honourable member for Lalor says that the top science people in Australia are against the project. Has he ever heard of the Australian Science and Technology Council? Has he ever heard of Sir Geoffrey Badger? Before the honourable member stands up here and condemns a $100m project which will give this country a microelectronics technology--
—With 100,000 jobs?

—Yes. The honourable member is making a fool of himself again. I did not make that statement; I repeated what was said. This is where honourable members opposite show themselves to be so ignorant. I repeated what was said by one of the finest businessmen in Australia, Sir Laurence Muir, Chairman of the Canberra Development Board; he is one of the top 10 businessmen in this country.
—He went down too.
—I beg the honourable member's pardon. He takes unto himself not papal infallibility but the likeness of deity. He believes that everybody else is wrong and that he is right.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.
—That is a great pity, but we will get the project, notwithstanding the honourable member for Lalor.
—Mr Deputy Speaker--
—The honourable member for Swan has a point of order?
—No, it is not a point of order; I thought we had until 10.40 p.m. I intended to speak.

—The honourable member for Swan has no entitlement to a call from the Chair. The Minister was speaking under the Standing Orders by an arrangement which permits him to respond to matters raised in the adjournment debate.
—I thought the time was extended until 10.40 p.m.
—The Minister is seeking the call? There being no other Minister rising to speak, he may speak again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. I come back to what the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) said because it is seldom that I get an opportunity to respond to his remarks. He is the one who was in tears in the House tonight because on the Australian Broadcasting Commission news report he was the subject of comment. But what did he say yesterday? He said that the project is not coming. He said that they have never heard of the Minister for the Capital Territory in California. He said that the Minister had said that there would be 1,200 jobs. He said that the Minister has finished up with egg on his face. He further said tonight that the Minister said that 100,000 people could get jobs in an applications industry. Let me just--

—Order! The Minister might like to resume his seat briefly. I remind him and the House that the purpose of extending the adjournment debate for a maximum of 10 minutes is to provide Ministers with an opportunity to reply, in the spirit of the arrangement, to precise points raised in debate and not necessarily to open up an expansive and free-ranging debate but to provide information which in the Minister's current case would rebut the assertions made. I suggest that the Minister may be ranging fairly freely.

—Thank you, sir. If the honourable member for Lalor can maintain silence for about two minutes, I will make the points very quickly. The figure of 1,200 jobs was the figure given by the Managing Director of the National Semi Conductor Corporation in Australia, Mr Jack Rutherford, in a Press statement issued at the Press conference held at the National Press Club following Cabinet 's decision to enter into negotiations. When the honourable member challenges that figure, he is not challenging what I said but what the Corporation has said . The figure of 100,000 jobs for an Australian applications industry comes from Sir Laurence Muir. He must be an absolute nit wit and the honourable member for Lalor a genius! Sir Laurence is a member of the board of Australian Consolidated Industries Ltd and a member of the board of General Motors-Holden's Ltd. He is probably one of the top 10 businessmen in Australia. He says-it is a matter of record-that 100,000 jobs is the capacity of an applications industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Last but not least, I place this on record: I do not believe that the honourable member knows what an applications industry is. In every comment that he has made, he seems to relate an applications industry to either wafers or chips. I point out to him that a wafer fabrication plant, on anybody's understanding, is the catalyst from which other operations develop.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the wafers were going to Singapore.

—Order! The honourable member for Lalor goes too far. He will resume his seat. It would be a pity to spoil an otherwise pleasant evening by the Chair having to deal with him at this hour of the night.
—The honourable member for Lalor is incorrigible. I take it no further than that. I say to Labor Party members in this Parliament that they are opposed to Natsemi and everybody in Canberra knows it.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat.

—My point of order is that you have made it quite clear to the honourable gentleman, Mr Deputy Speaker, that his answer must be germane to the argument put by the honourable member for Lalor. Statements concerning the incorrigibility or otherwise of the honourable member for Lalor are not within the framework of the discussion.

—Order! The honourable member has made his point. I am sure that the Minister would have been equally sensitive to the proposition if he had not been massively distracted by the honourable member for Lalor. It being 10.40 p.m., the debate having concluded, the House stands adjourned until 1.45 p.m. on Tuesday next.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Use of Civil Plutonium for Nuclear Weapons

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a proposal of the United States of America Secretary for Energy that plutonium could be extracted from the spent fuel rods of United States civilian nuclear power stations for use in nuclear weapons production to help overcome a projected shortfall in military plutonium production.

(2) If so, in view of the arrangements which have been made to export uranium from the Ranger mine to the United States of America, can he say whether the Government has expressed any attitude to the United States Administration regarding this proposal; if so, what attitude has been expressed.
(3) Would the Government be prepared to approve the extraction of plutonium from Australian-origin nuclear material on behalf of the United States Government for use in United States nuclear weapons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. It is to be noted, however, that on 19 November 1981, in testimony before the Sub-Committee on Energy, Nuclear Proliferation and Government Processes of the United States Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, Mr James Malone (Assistant Secretary of State for Oceans and International Environmental and Scientific Affairs) stated that the United States Administration has 'made no decision on the feasibility or desirability of using plutonium from such fuel for military purposes; nor are any recommendations for decision pending before us'.

(2) The Government considers that it is important to maintain a clear distinction between the peaceful and military uses of nuclear energy in the interests of upholding the international nuclear non-proliferation regime. It has expressed to the United States Administration its concern about any possibility of plutonium separated from spent nuclear fuel from civil nuclear power stations being used for nuclear weapons.

(3) No. All uranium supplied to the United States by Australia under the Agreement Between Australia and the United States of America Concerning Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy, signed on 5 July, 1979, is subject to a peaceful, non- explosive use pledge.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the development in the United States of America of high powered lasers which promise to be capable of producing highly refined bomb grade plutonium from the plutonium extracted from civilian nuclear power stations operated in an ordinary fashion.

(2) Has the Government investigated the possible implications of this technology for nuclear weapons proliferation and existing nuclear safeguards; if so, what were the results of these investigations.

(3) Has the Australian Government expressed any attitude about the further development of this technology to the United States of America or within the forums of the International Atomic Energy Agency; if so, what attitude has been expressed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. In testimony on 18 November 1981 to the Sub-Committee on Energy, Nuclear Proliferation, and Government Processes of the United States Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, Dr F. Charles Gilbert (Acting Deputy Assistant Secretary for Nuclear Materials, Defence Programmes, U.S. Department of Energy) also stated that: 'At this time, plutonium isotope separation technology has not been demonstrated on a practical scale'.

(2) As part of its continuing assessment of non-proliferation and nuclear safeguards issues, the Government has been closely monitoring reports of this development and its possible application to the production of weapons-grade plutonium from plutonium extracted from spent fuel from civil nuclear power stations and will continue to monitor this subject. As noted above, laser isotope separation technology for plutonium is understood to be still in the early stages of development. The Government is aware that laser isotope separation technology is sensitive from the non-proliferation point of view, as stated by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in 1979 (Hansard, 22 November 1979, page 3527). During consultations on nuclear issues held in Washington in July 1981, Australian officials advised their United States counterparts during a discussion on international nuclear export controls that Australia would favour laser isotope separation facilities for uranium being specifically added to the international lists of items that should be covered by IAEA safeguards if transferred to a non-nuclear-weapon state (IAEA documents INFCIRC/209 and INFCIRC/254).

(3) The Government has expressed to the United States Administration its concern about any possibility of plutonium separated from spent nuclear fuel from civil nuclear power stations being used for nuclear weapons. As the reports concerned the development of laser isotope separation technology for plutonium in the United States, it was considered that Australia's concerns should at this stage be taken up directly with the United States, rather than within the forums of the International Atomic Energy Agency. As noted in the reply to (2), Australia has expressed the view to the United States that laser isotope separation facilities for uranium should be specifically added to the international lists of items that should be covered by IAEA safeguards if transferred to a non-nuclear-weapon state. The Government is maintaining a close watch on all aspects of the matter including the question of whether and, if so at what stage, it would be appropriate to express Australia's attitude within the forums of the IAEA.
See also answer to Question No. 3672.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the CSIRO undertaken an internal investigation into its water research activities.
(2) If so, when was the investigation completed and when will it be made public .
(3) What re-organisation of CSIRO activities will result from this investigation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes: following a review of the Divisions of Land Resources Management and Land Use Research and the holding of an Executive seminar on Water Research in June, 1981 CSIRO undertook an internal examination of priorities for water research and of organisational arrangements to facilitate the conduct of research in identified high priority areas.

(2) The investigation was undertaken in two parts. A Working Committee representing CSIRO Divisions with major water research responsibilities prepared a report in October 1981 which identified water research opportunities and needs . This report formed the basis for the CSIRO submission in November 1981 to the Review of Water Research in Australia being conducted by a working group under the Australian Water Resources Council and is available on request to interested groups and individuals. Subsequently three priority areas for expansion of CSIRO 's water research were identified, namely:
salinity and other water quality aspects, and

Most recently, in February 1982, decisions were taken on organisational arrangements to facilitate the conduct of research in these priority areas. The final report on the CSIRO investigation is now being prepared and will shortly be made available.

(3) See (2) above. Some aspects of the proposed CSIRO re-organisation of its water research are dependent on the outcome of proposals that I and the Minister for National Development and Energy are currently discussing.
